39393976.review:
Sadly in its current state I can't recommend this game: I played it years ago when it ran without any issues and I basically never had any hard crashes. I recently picked it up again but sadly the recent patches/introduction of the deluxe version seems to have made it extremely unstable: It's been practically impossible to play this game without getting a hard crash at least every hour. In the last hour it even crashed 5 times. 
The game itself is really fun, probably one of my favorite TD games, the story is actually quite intriguing which is unusual for a game of this type, plus it has a lot of wacky humour. The gameplay is what you would expect from a TD game, with some twist but most importantly some of the best QoL features I've seen in any TD game. 
However 5 crashes in a single hour? That's definitely a dealbreaker which is such a shame considering how good the game itself is. I might even try to go back to the old nondeluxe version to see if its actually more stable than the deluxe version

39286985.review:
This game is excellent and I highly recommend it.

I grabbed it because it was on sale and I'd remembered liking a Defender's Quest game on Kongregate many years ago. I was expecting a fairly basic Kongregate-y tower defense game that I could run through once and get bored.

78 hours of play in (in under a week), I still have a bunch more achievements left to get and I'm still having fun.

New Game+ I was expecting to be the base game over again but harder and with better stuff - nope, there's a huge extra plot reveal and new sidequests. And your equipment upgrades and leveling up transfer between regular and NG+ play! It's so well integrated.

There's also the Hero Mode achievements, which are what I'm working on now. I kind of expected to be bored playing through again to get them, but you have to completely revamp your strategy when you don't have generic heroes, and it's way more engaging than I expected.

I also really, really appreciate the accessibility options for extra XP and treasure. They allow me to get through the hero mode game without having to do a bunch of boring grinding to get my level up high enough to be successful, which makes it way easier to stay engaged with the game instead of getting bored and wandering off because I'm sick of replaying the same fight. And I was stunned and delighted to find that the achievements don't punish me for using the acessibility scrap/xp boosts. Bravo, devs, I appreciate that so much.

Oh, and it actually has an interesting plot, which is the last thing I expected from a tower defense game!

This was absolutely worth what I paid for it on sale, and I would happily pay full price for it knowing what I do now. My only disappointment is that there aren't any other games by the dev for me to buy :)

38773912.review:
OK, so the hilarious deluxify update ad video is what convinced me to put this on my wishlist. I'm very glad I did. The quality and hilarity of the writing does indeed extend to the game itself, and so much more really. This is easily the best story I've ever seen in a tower defense game, and indeed it ranks among the best stories I've read in a game period. The journal adds a ton of depth to the characters, and the game has made me gasp, worry about the characters, and at one point at least openly weep. The writing is AMAZING. I cannot hammer this home enough. 

"But I don't care about all that namby pamby story and characters and emotion and stuff, how's the GAME play!?" I hear you say, as I slowly reach for the lever on the makeshift guillotine poised precariously over your head. Fine. You want to know about the gameplay? I'll tell you about the gameplay. It's excellent. Tower/Hero defense games will never be earth shattering when it comes to innovating mechanics, but this is a very solid, tightly balanced tower defense game, and the most fun one I think I've ever played. Placement and tactics can make all the difference, but in true RPG fashion, you can always go level up and unlock some new skills or upgrade your equipment if your strategy of choice isn't -quiiiiitttee- cutting it. 
(A word about difficulty: if you play the game on normal, it's pretty easy, possibly distressingly so if you want a challenge. Play on advanced if you want the challenge, though you may want to come back later with new classes for certain enemies.)

It's the RPG side of the gameplay that really has me hooked, trying to move the story forward to unlock new shops for better gear and then using that gear to go back and try the expert level which lets me get some extra scrap for new gear or even better unlock a new UNIQUE ITEM (oooh, aaahhh) which, in new game + can be upgraded with delicious magic skulls for extremely epic unique items that have unique abilities as well. The gameplay loop is so engaging I have more than once looked up and noticed that 6 hours have gone by without me realizing.

TL;DR: It's great. buy it. If you want to wait for a sale go for it, but seriously, buy it. amazing writing, excellent tower defense gameplay, and excellent RPG gameplay.

36167937.review:
Im Grunde ist das ein richtig gutes Tower Defense Game. Es hat eine Story - wenn auch eine etwas flache. Es hat Rollenspielelemente und "Türme" (Charaktere), die durch ihre Eigenart (z.B. Mindestreichweite) strategisches Geschick erfordern. Wenn man mal eine Map nicht schafft, kann man eine vormals gespielte Map in höherer Schwierigkeit nochmal spielen, um sich dadurch Geld oder Waffen zu erspielen.
Warum ich dann einen Daumen nach unten gebe? Nach einigen Maps wird das Spiel so schwer, dass man gezwungen ist, ältere Maps auf höherer Stufe nochmal zu spielen, um nötiges Geld/Ausrüstung zu bekommen. Hebt man den Schwierigkeitsgrad aber nur um eine Stufe an und es ist immer noch zu schwer, kommt man nirgends weiter. Dazu kommt, dass jedes Mal, wenn die Bibliothekarin stirbt eine Geldstrafe anfällt - das Spiel wird dann noch schwerer!
Für mich ist eine Sackgasse erreicht durch die ich das Spiel nicht mehr spielen kann.
Investiert eure Kohle lieber in ein anderes Tower Defense Game.

35701105.review:
Defender's Quest z początku przyciąga, wciąga i jeśli chodzi o gatunek TowerDefense to z pewnością jest warta uwagi, natomiast przy dłuższej rozgrywce pojawiają się liczne problemy, głównie związane z mechaniką, ale może po kolei:

Na + :

1. Grafika jest przyjemna, kolorowa, niemalże cukierkowa.
Animacje ruchu jednostek, czarów i ataków są niezbyt obfite, ale w zupełności wystarczające, jeśli chodzi o ten typ gry.

2. Muzyka jest momentami ładna, łagodna, przechodząca następnie w niepokojące motywy i smutne melodie w kolejnych odsłonach rozgrywającej się historii, by w końcu wybrzmieć mocno w bitwach, gdzie dzięki bardzo starannie ułożonym dźwiękom i dudnieniu bębnów staje się intensywna, żywa, bardzo dobrze oddając klimat walki.

3. Przedmioty i czary, które pozwalają się nam jednocześnie cieszyć z ich nabywania, jak i oglądać efektywność ich działania w bitwach.

4. Historia - samo jej dodanie jest już plusem. Jest ona dosyć prosta, ale to, że opowiada o tajemniczej istocie zwanej Eztli-Tenoch, która powraca zza światów, aby wprowadzić swój despotyczny porządek, czemu przeciwstawia się prowadzona przez nas główna protagonistka, oszołomiona zmianami otaczającego świata i pozyskująca moce, które możemy wykorzystywać w walkach jest ciekawe i wątek fabularny jest ogólnie bardzo dobrze napisany i poprowadzony.

I na tym niestety muszę przerwać, gdyż...

Na - :

1. Bohaterowie, którzy swoją "kliszowością" i płytkością psują prowadzony wątek fabularny. Są tak przewidywalnie i infantylnie ucharakteryzowani, że psują nam całą zabawę z odsłaniania kolejnych rąbków fabuły. Miałem wrażenie, że prowadzę podróż z bandą dzieciaków, przekrzykujących się nawzajem, z masą nieśmiesznych żartów i w efekcie postacie z których mamy się pośmiać wychodzą bardziej energicznie i sensownie, natomiast "mistrzowie retoryki i inteligencji" wychodzą tu na głąbów, tam na tchórzy i nie chce się tego po prostu czytać i zaznajamiać z nimi bardziej, niż na wstępie (chociaż przeleciałem każdy dialog, niemniej jednak były one momentami katorgą).

2. Mechanika. Rzecz najważniejsza dla tego typu gry. Mimo, że ogólnie wszystko ładnie pasuje i przyjemnie się nam broni przed falami przeciwników, to po paru misjach wkrada się problem rpgowy tej produkcji. No właśnie... Niestety, ale okazuje się, że aby misję przejść na wyższym, czy najwyższym poziomie trudności wystarczy postaci po prostu dopakować na późniejszych misjach i przez to gra traci na elemencie strategicznym, taktycznym. Jeśli natomiast leveling obrońców nie wystarczy, to można "Łańcuchem Błyskawic", czy nawet zwykłą "Błyskawicą" wyklikać przeciwnika na z walki, a przy większych wyzwaniach gra ma tendencje do wieszania się.

Wiem to i podpieram swoje słowa tym, że spędziłem z nią 105 godzin i przeszedłem ją od deski do deski, na 100%, każdą misję na poziomie "Extreme" w NG+.

3. RPGowe elementy. Mimo, że obecne, to poza różnicą w odblokowaniu nowej umiejętności z drzewka bohatera niewiele wnoszą, jeśli nie pójdziemy w czyste obrażenia i sporadycznie efekty kontroli tłumu, które to z resztą zazwyczaj w rozwoju danego typu jednostki/bohatera niewiele wnoszą dobrego, gdyż ich skalowanie jest bardzo słabe i niebardzo efektywne.
Gdyby chcieć zrobić sobie z gry wyzwanie, to zazwyczaj okazuje się, że istnieje tylko jeden kierunek - czyste obrażenia, w którym to da się każdy kolejny, trudniejszy etap przejść.

Nie mamy więc tak naprawdę żadnej pociechy z rozwijania naszych bohaterów, prócz wczesnych momentów, kiedy zyskują nowe umiejętności.



Podsumowując: przez parenaście godzin cieszyłem się rozgrywką, by przez kilkadziesiąt później powoli się coraz bardziej tą produkcją rozczarowywać.

Za obecną cenę na pewno nie polecam kupna. Sam nabyłem w promocji za 5.99$ i jeśli ktoś ma ochotę spędzić więcej godzin przy tej gierce, to radzę się uzbroić w cierpliwość i stalowe nerwy.

35610518.review:
Tower Defense games used to be a bit rare. Now they're a dime a dozen on Steam. The real question is "which ones are worth a damn?" and in my opinion, Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is one such worthwhile TD. Why? Well, let's see...

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
It has a cartoon-like look to it, and has a smooth design, in my opinion. It's nothing visually jaw-dropping, but it gets the job done, and I feel like the characters' facial expressions and body language did an excellent job emoting and making me like the characters more. I won't say more on that until the story section, though.

[h1]Music[/h1]
I really liked the music in this game. I wouldn't compare it to memorable tracks from a Final Fantasy game or a SuperGiant game (Bastion, etc.), but it's still good stuff that fits in well and was enjoyable while it played.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Your protagonist summons different combat characters into a maze-like pre-established battle map, and as per the typical TD, you can place the characters where you want. The protagonist is locked down in a pre-set starting position and is the "core" or "lives" you're trying to guard. Each of the characters you summon can be "boosted" (i.e. leveled up per battle) up to five times, unlocking new abilities for use in the fight which will help out.

I played this game twice: once something several years ago...a little while after it first came out and got a discount, and again just last night and tonight. The first time, I hired recruits, and the extra unnamed characters deteriorated my interest in the game and I stopped playing for a couple of years because I didn't like the recruits. This time, however, I was compelled to complete the game, as a "hero mode" setting (new, I think) was available where you only use story characters in battles, meaning a maximum of six combatants plus your spell-slinging protagonist.

Each level has different rewards and star ratings with various difficulties to play them at. You can get unique gear that can't be bought in the game's various shops that is often better than what's offered in shops lby doing the tougher difficulties on maps. When you complete the game, new game + is unlocked. You can either go back to your first playthrough and try to get more stars/items unlocked, or you can start over in new game + with your gear and XP, and try to take the game on again. That said, I got my butt handed to me badly on new game + so I went back to the first playthrough. Unfortunately, despite my best efforts and doing a respec on my protagonist, I was not good enough to get the higher-star scenarios done in the latter part of a cave system onward. I could have tried the second hardest difficulty, but I didn't really want to bother with that.

[h1]Storyline...Wait, Storyline in a Tower Defense Game???[/h1]
I know I'm being redundant here, but this is a tower defense game...with a [i]storyline[/i] that's not awful. In fact, the good ending (there are two endings!) was rather satisfying and felt like a better conclusion than I've seen to a lot of movies, and certainly better than I've seen in most games. The dev kept the number of characters small enough to be fairly memorable and give different characters screen time, and the aforementioned facial expressions and the characters' dialog are bursting with charm. He enjoys being silly, and I found myself smiling many times throughout the game's storyline, thanks to the more entertaining characters' lines. 

I even really liked the lead protagonist. Leaders of groups are often very uninteresting, portrayed as perfectly balanced and level-headed, not doing anything exciting or interesting, and lacking fun dialog. With Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten, this was handled well in my opinion.

Azra, the lead character in Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten, is fairly straight-laced externally, but does have some playful dialog with different characters, and you can read her journal which has tons of updates, both lore-filled and incredibly silly. It makes her a far better character than most group leaders I've seen in entertainment, and I cared about her and the other team members.

NOTE TO DEV: In the "bad" ending, I can't recall it perfectly, but a word was missing in the text across the screen when it's dark. They're talking about a length of time that passed, and a word is missing on the screen. It may have been "to" or "for" or something like that. It was a brief word that was missing.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is graphically simple, yet attractive in a nicely-drawn cartoon fashion, with enjoyable tower defense gameplay, and perhaps the deepest storyline I've seen in a tower defense game, at least from a character depth and lore depth perspective. This game obviously comes from a developer who was very into what he was making. Many people can be developers these days, put out a garbage game, and put no effort into it. Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten couldn't be further from that. It is one of the TDs I have enjoyed the most. I came for the gameplay, but I stayed for the storyline/characters. It's bizarre, but I'm okay with this. :D

Gelungene Mischung aus RPG und Tower-Defense mit unterhaltsamer Story.

Positiv:

+ Ausgeklügeltes Spielprinzip, schnell zu verstehen, anspruchsvoll zu meistern.
+ Interessantes Skill-System der Charaktere, welche zudem mit den verschiedensten Waffen + Rüstungen ausgestattet werden können.
+ Mit zunehmender Spieldauer (und vor allem im Game+-Modus) taktisch immer anspruchsvoller (zu Beginn ist das Spiel noch nicht besonders fordernd – siehe unten).
+ Komfortable Features (wie man sie sich für ein TD-Game wünscht) die ein flüssiges Spiel gewährleisten.
+ Unterhaltsame Story mit mehreren verschiedenen Enden.
+ Lustige Charaktere + Dialoge.
+ Gelungener Soundtrack.
+ Game+-Modus mit neuen Eigenschaften der Gegner und zusätzlichen Nebenquests – ein dickes Plus.

Negativ:

- Die ersten 10 – 15 Level spielen sich etwas eintönig, Schema F führt meistens zum Erfolg.
- Bei vielen Runden in einem Level kann die Performance schonmal recht ruckelig werden.
- Das Level-Design ist manchmal etwas einfallslos.
- Die Hilfe-Texte (z.B. bei der Beschreibung von Skills und Ausrüstung) sind teils sehr spartanisch.

1 вариант: заходите в опции и выбираете сохранение на другой диск (или на флешку)
2 вариант: находите исполняемый файл с игрой (по умолчанию Program Files - Steam - steamapps - common - DefendersQuest - deluxe - DefendersQuest.exe), жмакаете правой кнопкой, выбираете "Свойства" - "Совместимость" и ставите галку "Запускать от имени администратора".

Понимаю, что досадно и разрабам за это жирный минус, но, поверьте, игра стоит того, чтобы потратить пять минут на одну дополнительную настройку.

34403168.review:
Defender's Quest is not your average Tower Defense game, but what it does, it does really well. It has a nice story, good cartoon art design, whacky characters and a simple to learn yet hard to master core mechanic of tower placements and upgrades as well as about 40 different maps counting all bonus levels and challenges, all of which have an alternate harder version in NG+. Complexity wise it's on the smaller end of the spectrum with only 6 different hero (tower) types and a maximum of 36 towers in total. It also requires to shift heroes (towers) on demand during a map which makes the whole game also a resource management game under great pressure, although it is always possible to completely halt the game while being able to issue commands as well as to up to speed up the game by a whopping factor of 16.

All in all: Great accessibility, time well spent and a good game to recommend to fans of the genre.

34373068.review:
I have about 13 hours into this game at the time of this review. I have completed the base game and am about half way through NG+.

While this game doesn't have big-budget production value, it pleasantly surprises in many ways.

The game runs well and I have not noticed any bugs or glitches. Sound, music and graphics are all acceptable and do not detract from the gameplay experience.

The story is surprisingly good and the dialog is generally well written.

There is a reasonable amount of strategy involved, as some levels will take a little trial and error to complete without taking any damage, and the unit cost and unit limit are well balanced in this regard.

Shortcomings are mostly that the game could have had much more depth on the RPG side - equipment is fairly limited in variety, and characters and units have relatively low skill/level cap compared to most games. This game has a more gradual progression to character power as you play rather than some games that ramp up quickly or more dramatically.

Overall a perfectly enjoyable tower defense and certainly worth playing for fans of the genre.

I repurchased this after my original copy had stopped working due to flash/OS compatibility problems. To my delight the it located all my previous save data and let me start where I had left off! 

The game itself is pretty basic like most tower defense games, you build your army, they stand in one spot, and wreck anything that comes in range of them, all the while trying to keep them from reaching you while managing resources. It does get a little grindy at points where you need to level your troops and fill out character skill tree's, however it's challenge modes offer plenty of opportunity to reduce the mundaneness and speed that process up.

One point that makes this game stand out from other TD games is it does have a rather good story, with plenty of character interaction, humor, and dark undertones, and spaces out new troops far enough apart you get more opportunities to play with new setups rather than get everyone within the first half of the game and just try to grind through the rest for more story.

33453496.review:
[h1]Enjoyable Tower Defense game with RPG elements, decent music, decent story and amusing dialogue. There is a lot of grinding involved, but the leveling and item system of the characters / 'towers' make the game satisfying enough to overlook the repetitiveness for the most part. [/h1]

I played through the normal game mode in around 13 hours, completeing the highest difficulty on about half of the levels.
Defender's Quest plays in a rather novel way, where the 'towers' placed to defeat the incoming waves of enemies are actually characters with health, items, levels and individual abilites. Some of these characters take part in the story, which is surprisingly not as awful as in most other Tower Defense games. 

Leveling up, getting new items and some hilariously written dialogue lines make for a very addicting start of the game. 
However, about half-way through the repetitiveness of the gameplay really shines through.
Moving down hordes of enemies is highly satisfying and thankfully levels can be sped up and slowed down any time, significantly lowering the time where you wait for your next action.

I enjoyed my time with this game a lot. The 13 hours I put into the game over the course of a few days. It sets itself apart from the vast majority of Tower Defense games by giving the towers some actual life.
Ultimately I did stop after one playthrough, forgoing the New Game+ mode, as I have become tired of the repetitiveness.
But I rarely ever go for a NG+ mode in any game, so you might actually revel in grinding through some more of the levels.

33452165.review:
Addictive tower defense game with a twist: the turrets are characters who can be equipped, trained and taught new skills/attacks. Each stage can be cleared in different difficulty settings for different rewards, or just to farm EXP/money.
The game is strictly 2D with nice little sprites during battle and good-looking art during cutscenes.
There's a "new game plus" feature with stronger enemies, more unlocks and a dev diary containing both making-of entries and a diary of the main girl, which gives more insight on the characters and how they get along during the main campaign.
Definitely a great game, with tons of replayability.

33109626.review:
I've recently purchased this game during steam summer sale, since I've been missing a proper tower defense game for a longer while. And woah, what a surprise it was!

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
 [*] The gameplay for tower defense is extremely hooking! I suffered from "just one more stage" syndrome. I thorougly enjoyed it!
 [*] Game experience is customizable - you can adjust how much experience and gold you earn from battles - whether it's 100%, something less, or something more, up to 300%. I personally recommend something close to 200-300. With 100 the game feels very grindy and you have to repeat older stages over and over and over to get some exp. I think higher exp set up eases the grind while not making the challenge itself much easier. There is also decent option of changing speed of battles which lets you fluently change the speed, from 1/4x to 16x of normal one.
 [*] Game has some rpg elements - you can choose skill trees for your main units and it tries to have a decent story.
 [*] For an indie game music is quite decent. Nothing extremely memoriable, but it's fine and doing it's job well.
 [*] With skipping grind by boosting received exp, the length feels about right - about 20-25 hours to 100% I imagine. Very good value for current discounted price (~5 euro as of time of the review)
 [*] The game feels like labour of love from developers and not just a venue for making money. From what I see, it received free HD "deluxe" update in the past, and there was an update less than 2 weeks ago adding new languages support! Doesn't happen very often for over 4 years old game. I'm impressed by developers' care of it.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
 [*] This is one of the worst presentation-wise game I've played in a very long time. While tower defense gameplay itself is a cool pixel-art, dialogues presenting story are very bad - just a still arts with static comic bubble speeches. It feels very lackluster and uniteresting. I'm also not a fan of the art - some characters, like an archer heroine just does not look good. It made story hard to follow for me, and ultimately I couldn't engage seriously into adventure of the main group and what was going on in the plot. I really wish there was anything to make presentation more lively. Some animations during dialogues akin to Neptunia? Some noises other than music during dialogue? Simply text appearing in a pace mimicking speech? Different fonts or effects to express emotions such as shaking of dialogue box to express fear? I'm not sure. Quite a decent writing was sunken by this in my opinion.
 [*] RPG trees are a facade for most of the characters - for example it's quickly quite obvious that any defensive option is a bad choice, since characters are more than enough durable. I don't think there is any meaningful choice or trade-off in build creation.
 [*] "Experience as intended" (aka 100% of exp/gold) is extremely grindy and I don't recommend it. It requires heading back to previously completed stages to grind them over and over to get more experience for the characters. It also leads to sudden difficulty spikes where you find out your characters are not good enough and need to grind again. Thankfully, developers added option to customize experience gain up to 300%, so it's not a major con.
[/list]

If I had to give number score to the game, it would be [b]9/10[/b]. This game to me is a proof that gameplay is the most important component of the game. Sure, the presentation is abysmal, one of the worst I've ever seen. But it doesn't change the fact, that it was extremely engaging and hooking indie game to me. It's very well done tower defense with decent and funny at times story, albeit terribly presented. It's a steal on a sale for 5 euros! I thorougly recommend it if you like tower defense genre. If you do not, I don't think this game is for you then - this is definitely not a game to buy to simply enjoy the story or miniscule RPG elements.

32629257.review:
An art in making a RPG grind fun.

Imagine the game where your typical RPG party become towers in the typical Tower Defense game and you have Defender's Quest in a nutshell. The game consists mostly of mowing down a conga line of various enemies that constantly move towards your main character as an end goal. Place your Knights, Berserkers, Druids and Ice Mages like buildings beside the highway and enjoy the fireworks, swords and arrows flowing. Recruit more units and upgrade them while spending experience points or buy them better equipment.

While looking at the bare game, RPG and Tower Defense mechanics aren't that much complicated. There aren't that many character classes, statistics and different weapon types like in a classic RPG game and Tower Defense parts aren't that much complex either. It's quite a simple game in reality, but this doesn't deter me from stating the fact that the game can be very enjoyable when you get the right flow for it, which is quite important and enforced by one of the weirdest difficulty curves I have ever seen in gaming period.

While attending the battle, you have a choice between several difficulty levels. You level up and get cash after the fight, but even playing on Normal, you will find yourself struggling with keeping up with the enemies. Eventually you will hit that unmovable roadblock which might be very frustrating if you don't know what to do. [i]And what you should do? [/i]  Every time you hit that unreachable challenge, go back to the previous missions and play them on higher difficulties. You will find your team extremely overpowered while gaining wind in the sails back again. At this point the game starts becoming a task of choosing the right battles, backtracking and creative grind, while still getting meaningful progress with it by obtaining unique equipment, experience and skill points. You will be constantly switching back and forth between story progress and grinding to stack up. Your team will meander between being very powerful and unable to advance in this endless circle until the end credits, and truth be told, this somehow ends up as a satisfying experience. Because of those constantly shifting roadblocks, you will often times witness your party taking on previously unimaginable tasks and it is very cathartic to experience those situations. Mowing down tons and tons of zombies that previously were relentlessly biting your back? Those moments drive straight home.

While this system creates a game where experience grinding is fun, it isn’t without its flaws. This whole circle of  progress, backtracking and shifting difficulties is quite hard to notice and tune in to, making beginner’s experience quite frustrating. People are conditioned to stick to one difficulty for a singular playthrough of a game. Break from that habit may come only after a few “quits” that I personally experienced. It takes some time to get the right clue and to find the flow. There is also that problem of New Game+ which basically extends the whole cycle for “another round”. Unfortunately, staying ahead of the difficulty curve becomes a real challenge, resulting in more roadblocks than I would wish for, putting progress to a crawl. This can be mitigated a little bit by using the punishment-free experience gain modifiers in options menu, but it kinda feels like cheating to me.

Liking everything so far? That’s very good, because the presentation sure wouldn’t win you over. Even after the Deluxe update, sprites don’t really look that good and story parts remind me of Newgrounds with its below-mediocre art and music. This is a big shame because the story itself isn’t half-bad and also fits the gameplay in the sense that it also likes to flip-flop between several states: the [i]Deepest Lore[/i] mode with the serious, classic fantasy shtick and [i]Absolutely Don’t Give a Damn About Convention[/i] mode where interactions between characters are so hilarious that you can be sure that writers had some real fun writing those. In both modes the quality stays on a decently high level, so I cannot really complain on that department. Those humorous moments can feel a little out of place, but most jokes hit that sweet mark leaving a positive impression.

Overall, I’m recommending Defender’s Quest. If you like building your little snowballs of death, constantly tripping out while climbing the mountain and getting even bigger snowball in the process, then I invite you to put some dosh to dev’s pocket. It is a curious little title which doesn’t like to be put in a single niche and those looking for something different yet familiar to their tastes will definitely appreciate that.

31567990.review:
This is one of my favorite games. And Yes, I've actually played it for hundreds of hours. There was a time when every day while I was winding down I'd put youtube videos on and just play this game, for hours. It's hard to pinpoint what exactly about it is such a draw to me. I think that the gameplay is super satisfying, the story is well-written and actually interesting, and the progression of equipment and levels feels fair and gives you a lot of choices.

Beating the game is really only the beginning and throughout your entire first playthrough the game won't be too challenging, your main strategy choice is where to put your archers, which are easily the best class early on. In New Game +, the enemies have various strengths that go beyond just "more health and damage" which is nice. Stuff like 50% ranged damage resistance to make you switch up tactics, fading in and out of targetability to make it harder to clump units into a death zone, etc.

You also get a new type of reward: in the first playthrough, you accumulate legendary weapons and armor by completing the levels on harder difficulties, which is great but has two issues. They don't feel very unique since it's just high stats, and eventually the stuff you can buy becomes better than the legendary stuff so they're useless. NG+ gives Skulls as a reward for beating higher difficulties that you trade in to upgrade the legendary items, and the upgrades fix both issues. The upgraded legendary items are better stats-wise than the stuff you buy, and they get unique abilities like extra bleed chance, higher crit damage, etc.

Another cool thing in NG+ is the addition of several levels where you can only use certain classes, so you might have a level with only berserkers and healers. These levels also introduce a new character who is cool. 

Basically if you like tower defense games this game is perfect for you, or if you just want a game to relax and wind down with it's been prefect for that for me.

31328647.review:
Che dire di questo gioco?
Si tratta di un tower defence con tocchi di RPG: le "torri" sono in realtà personaggi (uno per ogni classe assegnato dal gioco, altri "acquistabili" in appositi villaggi), il gioco segue una sua trama, gli scenari sono quindi consecutivi, intervallati da "villaggi" dove è possibile comprare potenziamenti sotto forma di armi ed armature. Ogni personaggio/torre fa esperienza in ogni scenario e i punti così acquisiti possono essere utilizzati per potenziare alcuni attacchi.
Il gioco di per sé è carino, i dialoghi molto divertenti e la trama, anche se classica, comunque godibile. La pecca è la durata, in 10 ore si finisce tutta la trama principale. Una volta finito il gioco è possibile rigiocarlo in modalità Gioco+ , quindi gli stessi dialoghi, appena 7 scenari in più, con difficolta maggiore. Un pò deludente.

Pro:
- Bella trama e dialogi molto divertenti
- Interessante poter potenziare i personaggi/torri sia con l'esperienza che con le armi
- Il gioco di per sé è bello come Tower Defense

Contro:
- 10 ore sono poche
- Modalità Gioco+ che è una semplice ripetizione del gioco appena finito

In sostanza un bel Tower Defense, con trama carina, bei dialoghi ma troppo corto. Se lo trovate in sconto vale la pena, a prezzo pieno il rapporto prezzo/durata non giustifica l'acquisto

Voto:
6,5

30900692.review:
Defender's Quest is an excellent tower defense game that, while not perfect, is one of the better offerings in the genre.

The pros (+) and cons (-) are as follows:

+ Solid tower defense gameplay. It follows a typical X unit is good against X enemy type formula, and for the most part this works well.

+ The story in this game is much better than you'd ever expect from a game of this type. You can more-or-less ignore it if you don't care, but if you take the time to read the journal entries, you'll find that the world and characters are very fleshed out. A lot of the characters and situations are very tongue-in-cheek, which relieves some of the tension a game like this can inspire. :)

+ Level design constantly pushes  you out of your comfort zone. You often find that you can't quite use units in the way that you'd want to because of the limitations on the terrain. Things don't get as monotonous as a result of this.

+ For a tower defense game, it's pretty long. If you're a veteran of the genre and can breeze through tough fights with effortless tactical accumen, you'll find that getting maximum stars on each level takes about 10-15+ hours.

+ New Game Plus (NG+) adds sidequests that aren't available in the normal game, which includes new story and cutscenes. The behind-the-scenes journal entries are also really interesting.

+ Hero Mode makes for an even more challenging game (you can only use the 6 story characters).

+ Lots of customization for loadouts, units, etc. Branching skill trees make the customization feel a little more fleshed out, although some options are clearly better than others.

+ The DX version of the game vastly improves the graphics. The biggest mark against the original game was that it was in SD and the art looked very amateur. With this update, the game supports HD/Widescreen resolutions, and all sprites/cutscenes look 1000% better.

+ You have the option of increasing the amount of XP and Scrap (money) you get after each battle by up to 300%. Scrap isn't all that useful, but XP is mana from heaven. This is great, because if you left it at 100%, it'd take a metric fuckton of grinding to get to the end of the game. See cons for reasons why even this feature doesn't save NG+ from grindiness, unfortunately.

- In the normal game, Rangers are by far the best unit. You can win almost every fight by just using them, even on Expert. It seems that the developers were very aware of this, which is why --

- In NG+, the Ranger (the only [i]real[/i] ranged unit in the game) is the subject of immense nerfs. Many enemies that appear in large numbers and have high speed either have 50% resistance to ranged damage, or 60-70% ranged [b]evasion[/b]. These are the kinds of enemies you'd want an archer for because they can slip past your melee, but your archers can't hit them. This really hurts the unit's viability in a lot of fights. I feel like the challenge could have been increased without this frustrating change. There are some enemies that the Ranger is still really good at dealing with, but mostly you'll be relying on melee in Expert modes.

- Most of the added difficulty in NG+ is artificial. Inflated HP and stats, enemies that phase out so that you can't target them, etc. You're often forced to spam global spells to deal with certain situations because your units simply can't no matter how you have them set up. This mode just isn't very well done in my opinion. It's frustrating and tedious, not fun.

- The super sheep levels are tedious and not fun at all. You kill a slow moving sheep (that you can slow even more) that has about a bazillion HP and takes optimal tactics and resource management to kill before it reaches the end of the level. It is a very boring, very long fight even with the game sped up to 16x speed, and you have to do it TWICE in order to get all the achievements. If you're a completionist, you'll be subjected to several grindy annoyances, which brings me to the final gripe:

- If you complete the game in Hero Mode (can't recruit units), once you've finished those achievements (after finishing NG+), you'll want to recruit units because there are some levels that are impossible to get 3 gold stars on with only the main 6 heroes. Unfortunately, the recruited units at that point will be so low level that even setting the XP to 300% is an unbearable grind to get them to 60. Battles take a long time to fight, and the XP from a battle -might- give your units half a level. You can imagine how long this would take. This was originally a community challenge that the developers put into the game later (along with associated achievements), but they didn't really balance the post-achievement gameplay for it. I actually gave up with only a few achievements left to get. Not worth it.

Overall, if you're interested in a tower defense game that's challenging and satisfying in the base game, and aren't too concerned with unlocking every last achievement, then this game is for you. If you love punishing grinds, NG+ has you covered.

Нет, правда. У такой записи может быть очень плохой звук, украденные идеи у всех кумиров гитариста, обложка нарисована в пейнте и напечатана на домашнем принтере, но в этом материале есть самое самое главное. Неистребимая искренность в том что эти люди делают.

30288254.review:
Greetings as always!  The short of it is that if you like tower defense this is a good addition to your collection.  Even without a sale the price is worth it, though this game could have been more appropriate for a tablet I didn’t feel cheated and was left satisfied overall.

Graphics and Audio:  The art is basic, no way around that, but it gives a certain charm with that understanding.  Unlike many games this one understands that the core is gameplay not graphics and audio.  Instead of doing a poor job I feel that the developers made the most of they could without cutting quality or requiring a tripple A budget., can’t really complain and the second game looks like they are bringing it to the next level without cutting that charm.

Tower Defense:  The game is simple enough, you ‘build’ towers by summoning characters and level them during the match which dramatically increases their power and unlocks a new attack (assuming they know the skill).  The combination of skills needed (like piercing armor or slowing) along with the unique pathing of each unit type gives a lot of strategy.

RPG:  The leveling system is decent but a bit shallow; this really isn’t an issue as the game’s leveling mechanics do exactly what is intended.  Along with some gear (weapons, armor and books) and a small bit of color customization for your characters it certainly could be better but I left the game content.  This small addition gives you something to work towards, a reason to 'grind' levels over and a method to make levels harder wtihout require silly levels of micro or creating a game that simply overrun with templates and walkthroughs that anyone can copy.

Story:  The narrative is good, the background and story told is very interesting in the premise although it could use a bit of work in the telling.  The mix of silly humor and playful tones keeps the game light without undermining the games overall serious story (looking at you Slak!), no, you aren’t getting BioWare story telling, but you aren’t getting generic forgettable story arc A either.  I’d definitely read a novel based around this fiction.

I’m not really sure what else to say, it is a solid game, especially for the price.  Even more so if you are looking to scratch that tower defense itch that seems to be dried up for now.  I hope you manage to enjoy it as much as I did.

29879674.review:
[b]Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten (DX edition) is a fun yet somehow shallow tower defense game.[/b] It's one of these cases where Steam's binary review system forces me to give a 'thumbs up' rating followed by a long text with all the caveats.

[b]TLDR[/b]
If you're looking for a relaxed, not-to-deep tower defense with colorful graphics, thematic music and some tongue-in-cheek dialog you might try this out. If you're looking for the best-in-class tower defense game, this is not it.

[b]details[/b]
The game has us accompany Azra, the royal librarian of a fantasy land, through her journey across the land where she must overcome various evils. You wouldn't play this game for its story per se but the dialogs and well crafted scenery and overworld make for a compelling reason to keep playing. Via overlay tutorials the player is introduced gently into the actual gameplay of placing and managing your figthers. While the start is great you soon realize that there isn't a lot of depth to the gameplay. I've played Warcraft 3 custom maps that had more mechanical variety in their tower defense than this game.

The mechanics merit a closer look because they are the Achilles' heel of this game really. There just isn't a lot to do other than the basics : placing your figthers (towers) and upgrading them, using your global hero powers now an dthen. There's no option to call a wave early for extra cash, no towers that teleport mobs to the beginning of the maze, no flying units that ignore the ground paths altogether, no possiblity to send your own troops against the enemy, etc., etc.
Mostly you'll be fighting against zombie like creatures which is justified by the story but it gets stale fast. There's a missed opportunity here for including a much more diverse set of enemies that challenge the player to adjust their strategy and tactics.

Outside of combat you'll have the opportunity to manage your party by purchasing equipment, acquiring new fighters up your fighters by assigning points in a talent tree. The game limits itself to 6 classes of figthers (towers) all of which are nicely integrated into and justified by the story. Every figther has a unique role and there's little possiblity of straying from that role via the talent tree. You want your archers exel at ranged combat and your freeze mages to excel at slowing down foes. That is that. I dare to say that this game suffers from a mild sort of RPG syndrome: the inclusion of RPG elements (experience bars, talent trees, interchangeable equipment) for the mere sake of it.

The developers have included many interface features that are very useful in this type of game, like being able to slow or speed up time at will or being able to reuse your previous tower layout if you failed a mission. Being able to control the game's speed at will makes for relaxed play sessions and there's even the option to scale experience points and loot rewards if you feel the pace is to slow or to fast. 

One of the decisions that astonishes me is that the developers decided to hide away some content like side missions and additional dialog in new game plus (ng+) mode. Since this game's story and presentation are on the strong side (for this genre) this baffles me. I've tried my fair share of ng+ and In the way of difficulty or mechanics there isn't much that varants a second playtrough. Defender's Quest is rather the kind of game that you play through once to see the plot come to its conclusion and then move on to something else.

This game supports the Steam controller ouf of the box and the layout is quite sensical. When using it though, the game would often hang in dialog scenes or null pointer crash. No such issues presented themselves however when playing with well though out keyboard layout.

All in all, I've had my fun with Defender's Quest and I'm looking forward to see the devs expand upon it with Defender's Quest 2 which is currently in development.

Edit: the game supports modding via the Steam workshop. While there aren't very many modifications available as of writing (February 2017) this is certainly a big plus!

29611746.review:
Amateur de Jeux de Rôles Medieval Fantastique et de Tower Defense vous trouverez ici quelquechose qui risque de vous satisfaire. En effet, vous avez ici un TD classique mais les "tours" sont des personnages avec leur classe (Barbare, Chevalier, Mage, Prêtre, Dragon et Archer), leurs compétences et leurs équipements. Les compétences pouvant être améliorées en dehors des combats à l'aide de Points d'Expériences. Le matériel est obtenu en récompense ou acheté dans des villes. Les personnages peuvent être Upgradés temporairement (5 niveaux) lors des combats à l'aide d'une sorte de mana.

La réalisation est simple et colorée, elle est très bien adaptée au style de jeu. La musique est plaisante et ne gâche pas l'ambiance, au contraire elle varie et est modulée en fonction des situations. Il faut noter également que les développeurs ont intégrés une véritable narration au récit (entre chaque bataille vous aurez des petits échanges "humoristiques" entre les personnages principaux).

C'est un jeu qui s'adapte aussi bien aux joueurs "casual" que aux "hard core gamers", notamment chaque bataille propose 4 choix de difficultés. 

S'il faut une quinzaine d'heure pour faire presque totalement le mode Normal (avec quasiment 3 étoiles à chaque étape), ensuite s'ouvre à vous le Mode+ qui ajoutera en plus quelques missions annexes et une difficultée accrue... Là c'est une autre paire de manche pour obtenir tous les succès ! Et si vous voulez encore plus vous pouvez refaire l'ensemble en Mode Hero mais vous n'aurez alors accès qu'aux 6 personnages de l'histoire uniquement pour toutes les batailles (alors que normalement on peut avoir jusqu'à 6 personnages par classe).

Une bonne surprise, un effort de présentation et de variété, peut être un peu répétitif sur la durée, mais beaucoup de bonnes choses.

Quelques CTD viennent de temps à autre perturber le jeu, heureusement que la sauvegarde automatique est permanente.

29286143.review:
This is a simple but excellent tower defense / rpg hybrid with an entertaining story told comic book style with great writing and is overall just a ton of fun.

The built in main story provides a lot of content, but they have gone above and beyond by making NG+ more than just the same game with an increased difficulty.  Instead the NG+ version has new side quests, new monster types and mechanics, etc so its actually almost like a full addition to the game (although with the exception of the side quests the story is the same).  The game also comes with multiple endings, multiple difficulties for each level and a set of bonus challenges so all told there is easily 30 hours of content and probably much more for a completionist.

The game is quite easy on the lower difficulties but involves a ton of strategy and efficient management on the harder challenges.  Overall it strikes a good balance in letting you set you own difficulty and providing plenty of challenge without frrustation.

10/10, great value.

29138033.review:
I think I picked a good time to play Defender’s Quest: Valley of the Forgotten (Deluxe Edition). The graphics are much better, the game has improved performance, a x16 speed is included, and much more. The smart changes and relentless support make this an extremely good and content rich tower defense game. I didn’t care much for the main story though, but more on that later.

I rather start with the gameplay where this game shines its brightest. As you progress through the 6-hour campaign, you unlock different heroes that function as your towers. Each hero you plop down on the field has four boost levels that can be purchased. You can only place heroes on predesignated spots as the game isn’t about mazing as much as thoughtful placement in a level’s limited space. Each hero has a distinct role to play such as Knights being able to pierce and destroy armor or Healers keeping everyone alive since some creeps attack and casting debuffs on enemies that amplify your damage. There are six hero types in all – Berzerker, Archer, Priest, Ice Mage, Knight, Dragon – that can be used to defeat the Revenant horde.

Heroes and the player character, Azra, can also be equipped with items. Azra can equip two different books that can enhance spells or affect the stage such as heroes having a free Frenzy buff when placed. Books are earned from bonus stages which are unlocked via the perfect stars earned from completing levels without letting Azra receive damage. Heroes can either equip a weapon, armor, or nothing at all. You can purchase equipment and recruit more heroes at towns. You can also earn unique items from tackling the higher difficulties for specific stages. The unique items are worth it as they can also serve a purpose in NG+

New Game Plus adds a significant amount of content for both the reading type of player or TD lover and does more than make the enemies tougher and stronger. You’ll run into new side-quests that provide additional story content or jokes and run into a couple of new characters. One of them is the Hermit, a crazy person who can upgrade all the unique items you’ve earned and give them new, powerful properties. There are also new developer journal entries that can be unlocked by playing if you want even more things to read. Those entries can be surprisingly interesting to read since you can see the thought process behind some of the decisions made for the game. You can also read about what the different inspirations were for other parts including the names of the unique items or the Ash religion. Both the side-quests and dev entries came with the Deluxe upgrade.

Running back and forth between the standard game and NG+ to perfect all the levels, collect uniques, and upgrade the items will probably take a bit more than 20+ hours for players if the standard settings are kept. Keep in mind that you can alter the experience, scrap (currency), and penalty rates in the accessibility menu which is a great thing indeed. Don’t forget about if you ever start to feel as though the game is becoming grindy as you go back and forth between stages in order to level up or earn more money to overcome the later levels. I had my fill of the game around the 20 hour mark and have no desire to go back for the time being.

Now we come to the main story. I did not enjoy the story told through the cutscenes for almost 90% of it. I thought the main antagonist, Zelemir, had some interesting qualities that were revealed during the later levels, but then there’s also Slak, the Berzerker, with his loud and wacky personality that felt really forced or possibly not meant for my age group. He came off as pretty lame with his style of humor and insatiable need to murder things. Maybe I just disliked how he spoke with Capslock. I thought the writing in the journal entries were better and more interesting as were some of the side-quests in NG+. Some of the journal entries explained the main characters in more depth and made certain events much more meaningful due to understanding the significance of certain actions. Some were tainted by Slak’s handwriting and jests which didn’t make me laugh.

Finally, I’d like to cover some other parts of what this game has to offer. The game saw heavy usage of the speed multiplier from me. I didn’t use the x16 multiplier very often, but man, what a time saver for when you have a solid strategy prepared for a level. You can also go in the other direction and slow down time, but I used the Pause feature instead with Spacebar. B, for boosting, is also another good hotkey to know. In addition to the x16 and performance optimizations, the game runs in 60fps which makes fast forwarding very pleasant. There is also the HD art style version of the game which is on by default now, but you can go back to the older graphics if you wanted to when you’re in the overworld map. The drawings for the cutscenes are vastly improved and I wouldn’t want to go back to the original. The retro aesthetics might be preferred by some people though, so it’s nice that you can switch whenever.  The game is very good with all the options it offers in general. Oh, also Steam Cloud and Steam Workshop are there now.

Defender’s Quest is an incredibly solid TD game with enough content to keep you entertained for a while. That’s assuming that the gameplay sinks its hooks into you as I don’t think the story is the major draw for players, unfortunately. The accessibility options can also make the experience friendly to newer players. DQ has been one of the better Tower Defense experiences I’ve had in recent memory so I hope the sequel turns out well too.

A blend of RPG and Tower Defense style gaming, Defender's Quest is a both entertaining and challenging. With bonus levels, four difficulty settings per level, and an extra challenging secret easter egg, there is a ton of replay value and content.

28952908.review:
Ok, let me start with by saying this is an enjoyable time killer. I binge played this game while being forced to stay indoors because of a flu and tooth removal. It literally erased 2 days of my time and now I have to go back to work.

The game in general is very solid tower defense game. Mechanically it's flawless, and the RPG feature which lets you build your characters and upgrade them definitely adds the charm. Overall, if you enjoy tower defense type games and have nothing better to do for few hours/days, I highly recommend trying this game. It also has a good demo, which lets you play good part of the game for free. So there is no cost of initial admission.

However the best part of this game is the active developers. After the devs being almost dead-silence for 2 years (prepping for a next game/sequel), they returned with HD version and constant updates and patches, which are really nice. Considering the game is over 4 years old, it's nice to see dev sticking to their games. So I recommend the game.

But, I have to nitpick few things before I leave. While none of these were deal breaker for me, your mileage may differ. The story arc is generic, the characters are not really new (by which I mean you saw all of these character archetypes somewhere), and humor in game are at best reddit /r/jokes level. The game is an infinite grindfest unless you change the reward level to 200~300%, which then lets you play a fair game that allows you to progress through all levels. I like the fact that devs included option to choose your own difficulty, but why the default values so low just boggles my mind. Finally, the default graphics option is not very optimized and you should turn off some graphical settings and sprites to prevent the game choking your CPU. 

All in all, it's a solid tower defense game you can enjoy for few hours/days. I recommend the game to anyone who likes this genre.

28699508.review:
There is basically nothing bad I can say about this game; but I have squeezed a few points in the con section of my review. This is a really fun twist on the tower-defence genre with unique gameplay, fun characters and a good story - with HEAPS of replayability.

PROS:
- Everything works as you'd expect it to do
- Many levels of complexity
- Many levels of difficulty, plus expansions on the normal game with "new-game +" mode for extra fun
- Good writing with decent jokes (and a lot of references)
- Attention to detail can be seen in almost everything
- Nice art-style
- Character customisability via skills, weapons and armour!
- Many secrets and freebies to be found

CONS:
- Enemy variety is limited (but in a way that makes sense)
- Can get repedative
- Sometimes the "cut-scenes" seem more like fillers than something with actual importance in the story-telling
- No multiplayer mode (it would be a nice addition; something seperate from the story mode)

TLDR:
If you're into tower-defence games but aren't too happy about the current popular games' offerings and wouldn't mind a twist in the genre, then this game is a MUST BUY!

28576736.review:
An excellent tower defense game that iterates on the best in the genre.  In Defender's Quest, your towers are characters that you can level as well as customize with talent trees and equipment.  Each character class has its niche, and enterprising players can further specialize them using the talent trees.  Spells and character damage and placement keep you engaged during the missions, and the persistence and meta elements keep the gameplay going outside of battle.

I don't generally play tower defense games for their stories, but the one in Defender's Quest isn't bad.  The characters are mostly quirky and snarky, which is fine because their exchanges often succeed at being funny.

Other reviewers have mentioned that they were forced to grind levels, but in my experience, there is enough content at varying difficulties that you won't need to grind unless you want to 100% the New Game+.

Lastly, I want to comment on the puzzles in this game, which are optional but helpful, especially in New Game+.  I assume that, for the most part, they're intended to be community-wide puzzles, because some of them are very involved.  I'm not a fan of this style of puzzle, so I looked the solutions up online and I don't regret doing so.

First off, I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in tower defense style games. A thing to note is that although the description does mention RPG elements, they are very lightly dashed throughout the game and could be attributed to a pretty standard tower defense game. The most RPG-esque element that I can think of after playing through is that every new city you encounter tends to unlock new weapons and armor, which to beat the rest of the game to follow, does require that you purchase. (At least in standard play. There are some specialized modes where this does not hold true.)

There is some grinding. Some modes have more grinding than others.
There is some frustration; some of the levels are very, very hard. Especially if you're trying to get all of the stars.
Actually, I still don't have all of the stars. There are a few levels that are so hard that they seem impossible. (I promise you, they're just very, very hard.)

The story is well-written and fun to follow, the levels are pretty varied (especially for a TD game), and the game is, overall, fun.

28508861.review:
Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten (DX edition) – достаточно интересный Tower Defense, рассказывающий очередную историю "внезапного избранного", но щедро приправленную иронией и отличным юмором. Не отнять у игры и нескольких уникальных геймплейных идей. 

Так, здесь вместо башен такие же герои, как и наш главный персонаж. Все вместе они прокачиваются во время продвижения по сюжету, а уже это открывает простор для кастомизации одних и тех же героев под конкретные нужды. Так один берсерк у вас может сконцентрироваться на нанесении урона одному врагу. Другой же может изучать навыки так, чтобы кромсать и рубить как можно больше врагов за раз.

Как и всегда, в первую очередь задача "башенок" защищать путь к главной героине, которая хоть и способна на великие заклинания, на самом деле достаточно слаба да и завязано на её жизни многое, поэтому нельзя позволить ей умереть. Со временем все герои получают новые навыки (например, дракон со временем не только будет кусаться, но и метать пламя, заодно сотрясая землю мощным рёвом). 

Каждый герой здесь нуждается в оружии и защите. Ладно, берсерк сразу заявит, что броня для девчонок, а на дракона ни одна не налезет, да и меч дракону не нужен, но все остальные нуждаются в обновках постоянно. Это часть геймплея, которую проигнорировать не получится. За прохождение уровня на максимальной сложности могут ещё и подкинуть ценный артефакт, у которого есть свои особенные свойства (вроде обычная броня, а на самом деле защищает от кровотечения)

Следует также отметить неплохой сюжет, закрученный на отношениях героев с главной героиней. Естественно, не обойдётся и без вселенского зла. Приправленный толикой отличного юмора, сюжет закручивается неспешно, но что самое интересное: для полноценного открытия всех нюансов нужно будет перепройти игру на дополнительной сложности. Кроме сюжета новая сложность подкинет и свежих врагов, а старым врагам прибавит способностей и умений. Удивительно, но повторное прохождение почти тех же карт не вызвало у меня никакого отторжения, потому что разработчики подошли к переработке карт и врагов очень ответственно. Возьмут да и вставят где-нибудь почти возле главной героини новую точку выхода вражин. И ты такой чешешь бороду, пытаясь понять, а как это дальше пережить, ведь старая стратегия больше не работает. 

В общем, мне остаётся только рекомендовать игру всем и каждому. Что я и делаю.

28057892.review:
This is one of the few TDs that I can stand, mainly due to the cast of characters. In this  TD your towers are characters, that you will place on predefined maze, in order to stop the creeps from getting to Azra (the main character). The characters have persistent level ups (RPG), along side traditional tower level ups (TD), this makes that game a bit easier to manage when it comes to placing them on the battlefield. Characters automatically attack and chose which ability to attack with, unless otherwise told not to use an ability. Azra has several spells that can fight back against the oncoming hordes such as healing all placed characters and raining down fireballs to continuously burn enemies.


In the game Azra has been tossed into the pit for contracting the plague, which she quickly overcomes to meet a loopy swordsman. The game manages to walk that fine line between seriousness and humor throughout the campaign. As you make your journey across the over-map you gained more survivors to your band with anywhere from 7-37 characters in your company, however only 7 are story related the rest are just generic copies of Azra 6 followers. You can assign all characters in your party with names other than the default ones, and generic defenders can be assign a color schema. There is a hard level cap of 60 for all characters, therefore you will not be able to max all characters abilities (higher difficulties you will have prioritize the best move set for your characters). 


This is game is design philosophy has the old school mentality when it comes to unlockables: new game plus that adds sidequests/challenge maps (like fighting waves upon waves of sheep), harder story maps, and journal entries, books to equip Azra, unique weapons and armor/ their upgrades. Game allows you to fine to how easy or hard you want the game to be like granting no exp upon failure, increase the speed of the game. The game is very well supported by the developer, in fact received an HD upgrade without making the user pay for it again. 

TL:DR
highlights 
[list]
  [*] humorous characters
  [*] a TD game with an actual plot
  [*] persistent level ups
  [*] free HD version and soundtrack
  [*] new game plus
[/list]

I'll confess that I haven't played the new HD update. Someday if I have time and feel like replaying this, I'll check it out. But the fact that I put so much time into this game BEFORE the snazzy update probably says something.

I don't play much tower defense, so I can't really compare and contrast, but this was a thoroughly fun game that you can probably enjoy if you like RTSes or tactical RPGs. It's got a solid story, endearing characters, and fun writing that doesn't take itself especially seriously. The game pretty much always feels balanced and makes good use of the mechanics it's established, at least over the course of the main story.

Some of the end-game challenges can be very frustrating. At one point I decided I wanted to try to 100% this game, but I could never get those last few achievements no matter how hard I tried. I was putting so much time into the game that I got tired of the soundtrack and turned off the music to play my own tunes. (My friends always thought some of the sounds from this game sounded like I was repeatedly booting up a PS1.) Don't be afraid to look up guides if you're trying that stuff yourself.

Still, all that is just post-game content that is by no means necessary to enjoy the experience. You can power through the main story on the lower difficulties in not too much time. The extra content will keep you busy if you want it, though. This game is a bit of an underdog that I highly recommend. Also, absolutely deserving of the Best Use of a Farm Animal award for the Super Sheep secret boss. Oh, and the main character is a librarian, which I am too!

Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is a gem I had lying around unplayed in my Steam library for over 3 whole years, and I regret it now for not playing it sooner. It is a huge story-driven defense game, where you need to place your characters strategically on paths that no monsters get trough to your main character. In includes RPG-like progression for your characters, with leveling and skills. Every completed level will advance the story further, and always making you wonder what's happening next.

Loved the story completely. Without spoilering too much, it revolves about a plague turning people into a sort of zombie that wouldn't die, until the main protagonist Azra, who was about to die because of the plague herself, but a strange series of events granted her mysterious powers to kill these zombies called "Revenant" in a "half-way world".
I hate Slak though (the berserker that joins your party very early in the game). If somebody would scribble into my journal, I'd DEFINITELY make sure he wouldn't do that again, may it be with spells or weapons)

(I also only noticed very late on in the game, that all the archers in this game are female, but I had created "Mitsuhide" (myself) already then, so yeah... read that how you want, haha.)

Really nice art style, in the cutscenes and ingame.

Glorious soundtrack too.

Only downside in the gameplay is that you have to grind at least some times in your first playthrough (when I just wanted to see what's happening next in the story) because the level numbers really don't say anything useful about strength. So it happens that 5 defenders with level 15 can kill level 40 enemies, but 2 defenders level 15 fail on a few level 30 enemies.

I will come back to this game, as it has a new game + mode. Definitely recommended.

27329088.review:
An extremely user-friendly interface, charming graphics, a solid base gameplay (with lots of variations and different levels of challenge) and entertaining, even if not mindblowing, story and dialogue.

The base game doesn't last very long, but that also means that it doesn't overstay its welcome and that each level has at least a little something that makes it unique and prevents the player from always using the same strategy. The fact that each level has two optional challenges and that there's a New Game+ mean that there are a lot of potential challenges for the players who want them.

Most importantly, the user interface never hides any information. You always know exactly what your characters can do and what the enemies will do if you let them. If you lose in this game it's because you did something wrong or your characters weren't strong enough, not because of some obscure "gotcha" mechanic or random chance.

My only problem with the game is the fact that interesting and important story content (a personal sidequest for each one of the major characters) is only available in New Game + mode. When you're replaying the game, you're probably fast-forwarding past the story so you're probably going to see these scenes in a vacuum. On the other hand when you're playing the first time, which is the only time you're actually paying attention to the story, the characters will feel underdeveloped because their development is hidden in their personal sidequests. I think the game would be better if all story content were available during your first "run", and the New Game+ mode was just about gameplay and challenge.

That said, this is an interesting and charming little game that succeeds in fusing RPG progression and tower defense gameplay, and is more than worth the money.

26986634.review:
This game may not have cutting-edge graphics, but it sure has a lot of heart.  Defender's Quest is a strange combination of the tower defense and RPG genres, and it's one of my very favorite games in either genre.  Through the game's substantial and satisfying campaign, you'll assemble a motley crew of heroes who serve as your "towers" in this tower defense game.  Unlike towers, however, your heroes will level up as they gain experience, and you can assign various skills and pieces of equipment to them.  It's fun stuff.

The developers for this game are fantastic, and their continued work on Defender's Quest highlights their "long tail" philosophy.  Rather than abandoning their game after release, Level Up Labs have diligently improved upon their work, adding content, improving the graphics, and rebuilding the engine.  Defender's Quest is far more refined now than it was upon release, and its developers ought to be proud. 

Defender's Quest is an excellent game with a committed development team, and I very much look forward to its in-development sequel.

Même si le Tower defense existe depuis 1990, c’est avec l’arrivée d’un mod de Warcraft 3 qu’il a connu une réelle expansion et un vrai succès. Alors unir le Tower defense avec le RPG était une bonne idée à creuser et c’est Level Up Labs qui a su l’exploiter dans Defender's Quest: Valley of the forgotten. Vendu à plus de 100 000 exemplaires, le jeu a été une franche réussite, d’où l’arrivée d'une suite dans les mois à venir. Sachant que l’on parle RPG dans ce jeu, il était donc normal que RPG France se penche sur le sujet et vous propose de le décortiquer. 
La suite ici : http://rpgjeuxvideo.eklablog.fr/defender-s-quest-valley-of-the-forgotten-a127285540

26517572.review:
[h1]简介[/h1]
Defender's quest:valley of the Forgotten 中译 守护者冒险：遗忘山谷（简称DQ（咦？），老实说我觉得题目怪怪的，女主是图书管理员，不是Defender，这游戏题目就是跟大家说，对这是个塔防（Tower Defence）游戏。我觉得还不如改成Azra's quest。这个游戏是大更新过的，主要是画质改善了很多，官方还是挺有心的。

[h1]游戏亮点[/h1]
[h1]+混合RPG元素[/h1]
这游戏如果仅仅是个塔防估计我玩的兴趣不大（[spoiler]不会的，这个人什么都玩得下去[/spoiler]），事实上这个游戏除了塔防还有剧情、职业和技能、加点等等元素，撇开剧情不说，就培养几个有名有姓的人物，看他们开战前后嘴炮，然后研究一下虽然很简单但还是有点意思的加点系统，都能让这个塔防游戏增色不少。

[h1]+个性鲜明的角色[/h1]
游戏里面6个职业都会有一个官配角色是参与剧情的，他们互相嘴炮实在太有意思了，尤其是女弓和狂战士，还有骑士。

[h1]+适当的挑战[/h1]
游戏每个关卡都有三星难度，其实在这种小游戏里面来说也很常见，作为一个不怎么玩TD的人感觉挑战还蛮恰当的，多数情况下考验的是摆位，有时需要你放点技能，既不会没事干也不会杀死大量脑细胞，当然如果要简简单单看看剧情就玩小星星casual难度可以了。

[h1]+可玩性[/h1]
游戏本身提供多周目的玩法，配合本身多等级关卡，多周目之后的支线任务和无尽守护模式，这个游戏还是相当耐玩的。

[h1]+一些实用的功能[/h1]
游戏在战斗的时候有相应的快捷键，以及攻击策略，技能施放策略，还可以禁掉一些技能，或者加速游戏速度（最高16倍速度！爽！），都非常实用，而且提供了一定的策略性

[h1]+追加中文了，大家不用担心看不懂了，快买[/h1]

[h1]-剧情有点短[/h1]
为什么我要要求一个塔防游戏有长篇剧情呢？

[h1]总评：[/h1]
守护者冒险作为一个有着RPG元素的TD游戏，非常适合休闲得来想看看剧情的玩家，消磨时间的优秀游戏，就是画质比较原始，画质党可以退散了。
[h1]8.5/10[/h1]

[h1]推荐人群：[/h1]
休闲向，RPG玩家，加一壕

[h1]不推荐人群：[/h1]
不喜欢塔防的玩家，画质协会玩家

[h1]有关续作[/h1]
好像没登陆Steam，为什么呢！？

26193517.review: A solid Tower Defense game, with decent storyline, characters, and mechanics.  Instead of just upgrading your 'towers' which in this case are members of your party, you can also level them up, putting points into different abilities, both active and passive.  Although the story is a bit cliche, it is still good, with endearing and interesting characters that I found I grew to like.  The downsides to this game are as follows:  There is a bit of a difficulty spike towards the end of the game, rather than the difficulty continuing its basic climb, and after a while you will have to grind.  You will have to grind a lot.  That nearly had me giving this game a negative review, as the most deadly sin a game can commit is being boring, but the fun of the gameplay balances it out.

Tower defense très cool. Une grosse durée de vie avec le New Game+ et le grind des dernières étoiles pour le 100%. 
La première campagne peut paraître simple et répétitif mais une fois que vous êtes en NG+ les choses deviennent plus intéressantes et il y a du challenge.
Le côté RPG via la possibilité d'augmenter les aptitudes de vos recrus est bien fait et permet différentes stratégies. 
Graphiquement rien d'extraordinaire même après la version HD (même si elle fait du bien). Ca pique pas les yeux comme certains TD peuvent le faire mais on vient pas ici pour le scénario ou les graphismes, simplement pour une gameplay sympa et une grosse durée de vie.

26135367.review:
デベロッパーが謳っている　「ファイナルファンタジータクティクスとタワーディフェンスが融合したゲームを想像してくれ！戦術の奥深さ、ユニットのカスタマイズ性、ストーリーをすごく作りこんだぞ！」　は、大言壮語が過ぎるので信じないほうがいい。
目指しているのがFFTとTDの融合であったとしても、SRPGとしてもTDとしても昇華されていない中途半端で浅いゲームだと思う。

・カジュアルなタワーディフェンス。基本的にレベルを上げて装備を整えるだけで詰まることなくNormalはクリアできる。
・開発環境はFlashのオープンソース版らしい。だから全体的な作りはほぼFlashゲーム。
・レベルが上がるごとに入手できる1ポイントをスキルに割り振るスキル制。しかし有効なスキルとイマイチなスキルの格差が激しいので、スキル制がカスタマイズの多様性に寄与していない。自由度が高いように見せかけてるだけ、と言ってしまっていい。
・基本的にどのマップも単純で、射程や攻撃の集中を考えるとユニット配置は毎回似たようなものになる。
・シナリオはカジュアルゲームにしてはなかなか面白い。とは言え、中学生の黒歴史ノート以上・ラノベ未満くらい。
・個人的にはキャラクター同士の掛け合いが子供が考えた漫才のように絶望的につまらなかったため、キャラクターに全く愛着を持てなかった。
・クリアした後にパーティ強化引継ぎで高難度になったステージを遊べるプラスモードあり。なかなかの高難度。相変わらずの単調さ。
・でもプラスモードを遊び尽くしたくなるほど戦術性に深みがあるすごく面白いってゲームじゃないんだ。

総じて、詰まりなしで1周目をサクサク遊びたい人には良ゲーかなあ。
新鮮なプレイ体験ができる新機軸のゲームをプレイしたい人は買うべきじゃない。
歯ごたえがある戦術ゲームをプレイしたい人も買うべきじゃない。

Great tower defence game with many customization options to suit your gameplay!

You can modify game elements before you start the game such as :

.exp modifier x1-3 exp gain
. currency modifier x1-3 gain.

This allows you to play the way you preferr.

The game also has a variety of speed modifiers allowing you to slow down or pause your gameplay in order to make tactical decisions in the heat of battle.

All in all this game is well worth the money if your into tower defence games!

Once you level up about 75% of the way through the game, all the difficulty levels become far too easy to beat-you can beat everything on 'extreme'. Again, didn't kill the game for me, but it would be nice if they reworked the difficulty settings.

25415144.review:
A really interesting and different tower defence game. You build an army of units that gain experience, new skills, can equip items, and then get summoned to the battlefield as towers, a concept I have never seen before. There is enough enemy varriety to make things tactical, the stages are also diverse enough to keep things fresh, the replayability is also really great, revisiting previous stages for more loot and replaying the whole game for bonus levels and bigger challenge, that's enough to get you going for a long time. Everything wrapped up nicely with a nice soundtrack and a story that ties it all together.

I'd say this is a game that could be enjoyed not only by people familiar with the genre, and definitely worth buying if you are into Tower Defence.

24825517.review:
타워디펜스+RPG 게임

적을 처치하고 얻는 포인트로 포탑을 세우고 포탑을 강화하는 전형적인 타워디펜스 게임이다. 포탑 대신 동료(사람)를 소환하지만 소환된 동료는 움직이지 못하기 때문에 게임 방식은 여느 타워디펜스와 별 차이가 없다. 동료마다 스킬트리가 있고 레벨업을 하며 아이템을 장착하는 등의 RPG적인 요소가 첨가되어 있다.

기본 난이도가 좀 높은 편이다. 하지만 스테이지별로 난이도 선택이 가능하고, 옵션으로 보상(경험치. 돈 등) 비율을 조절할 수 있다. 그 덕에 크게 쉽거나 어렵게 느껴지지 않게 조절하면서 할 수 있다. 전투는 전반적으로 변화가 크지 않다. 맵 형태나 몬스터 구성은 다양하지만 하다보면 비슷비슷하다는 인상을 받는다. 등장 캐릭터들 개성은 강하고 대화는 재미있지만 전체 스토리는 평이하다.

공식 한글판이지만 DX 버전에서는 일부 대사나 일지가 번역이 안되어 있다. (DX판 추가 요소인 듯)

24763907.review: Очень хорошая игра. Купил за 174 рубля по скидке. Давно хотел поиграть в годный тауэр дефенс. В игре присутствует обширная кампания и интересный сюжет. Каждый уровень имеет 4 уровня сложности: легкая, нормальная, сложная и экстрим. Начинаем мы с берсерков -- обычных мечников, которые бьют врагов на небольшой дистанции. Вначале имеется только один такой. Позже, мы открываем первую локацию и можем нанимать там других берсерков. Дальше, по мере прохождения, открываются лучники -- довольно полезные юниты. За всю игру можно открыть 6 типов юнитов: берсерки, лучники, хиллеры (маги, лечащие юнитов), маги льда, рыцари и драконы. Также, в игре присутствуют коллекционные карточки. Игра -- одна из лучших среди игр данного жанра, но хотелось бы продолжения, или хотя бы просто игры этого жанра от разработчиков этого продукта. 10/10!

24605897.review:
I tend to find Tower Defense boring, if it doesn't have a gimmick, or mix in other genres the way Orcs Must Die does. Here, the gimmick is RPG elements, and music reminiscent of Final Fantasy IV. That works for me.

There is a ton of content; each map can be replayed on two higher difficulties for increased rewards, after beating it. And then you can replay the whole game in NG+ where enemies have altered behaviors. You can also change the game speed at will, which is something I'd love to see in more Tower Defense, to speed through the parts where I know my towers have things covered and I don't need to watch enemies walk into them and die.

24555585.review:
This is a great game within its genre. 
It's an atypical tower defense game with a cute story that's interesting enough to keep you playing. Although the gameplay itself does that sufficiently enough, it's a good addition to a genre that usually lacks such features. 
Your 'towers' are people and due to it having a story, some of these characters have a personality and that makes it a lot of fun. You can level your towers and have them learn new skills as well as equip them with better weaponry. 
The game initially isn't hard, but the option to make it so is available for those longing for a challenge. 
All in all, if you enjoy tower defense games but are looking for something new, I'd say you can't go wrong with this game.
If you're not into tower defense games, you might still want to give this game a try as it does certain things common amongst games of its genre differently, and that might just be enough for you. 
I had a lot of fun with this game and picked it up rather cheaply, for having put over 20 hours in this game I cannot do anything but recommend it at this point. 
I am looking forward to Defender's Quest 2, it's coming people!
