I am somewhat disappointed from this game. I really wanted to like it - it has a genuine idea (combination of tower defense + RPG) , it is not expensive (on sales often) and the developers seem to care about the customers. Also I have to admit that the cut scenes are funny.

However, it is simply a grinding game. Some levels are just too difficult, no matter how clever and resourceful you are. You have to go back and play earlier levels, until you grind enough XP and money to buy a better equipment. Then the level becomes easy, and you win it no matter what tactics you use. In other words, the game rewards you not for your talent, but for the time you spend playing it.

In addition, the graphics and sound are just like from the 80's. Perhaps this is the designers' intention, but I didn't like it.

I would recommend this game only if you are a tower defense fanatic and only when it is on sale.

Defenders Quest is a well-balanced Tower Defense game that replaces static towers with RPG-element-laden characters. With six classes, skill trees and weapons and armor there's plenty of customization to be had.

24073135.review:
Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is an RPG/Tower Defense hybrid. At first, wasn't sure how well the genres would mix. Now, I can say they mix well, at least for this game. It reminds me a lot of Shining Force meets tower defense with realtime combat. The storyline is great, and not overbearing. I enjoyed reading the cutscenes quite a bit. Good sense of humor put into the game as well. I have not beat it yet, so this is based on what I have seen a few hours in.

Positives
- Great writing/story. Enough character development to understand the story and the role you play in it. At the same time, not necessary if you just want to skip to the tower defense part (though it is worth reading, I assure you).
- Decent variety of tower/class types to choose from. You can choose if you want to specialize in a particular type of defender rather than being forced to use them all. Like most tower defense games, you will want some variety though.
- Many quality of life features such as individual settings to save for each defender, prompts asking if you want to place defenders in the same place as last time when repeating a map, quick sell options when upgrading equipment, dialogue skip buttons, and many more. The developers were very considerate of our time to include efficient options.
- Good replay value. Can go back to the maps you have done before to grind or to try a more challenging version for better rewards.
- Well composed music. The music assets are very fitting and relaxing. A great addition to an already entertaining game.
- Very robust controls. Clear usable keyboard shortcuts for almost all functions. Many different time controls to slow down or speed up combat to a pace you are comfortable with. And of course, with the ability to pause.
- Permanent gear and skill upgrades for the defenders. As opposed to many tower defense games, there are progression elements that will stick with your defenders between maps. Buying/earning better weapons that will stay with your defender until you upgrade helps this feel more RPGish. Skills can be retrained for a reasonable cost of in game coin.

Negatives (To be honest, there are not many negative points for this game in my opinion)
- Lacking in character customization. While I realize the game is telling a story, I would have liked the ability to choose the gender of the main character. Perhaps if the campaign is completed, there will be something after that for the end game. Not sure.
- On the matter of customization, I would have liked to do more than just change the colors of the defenders. Hair styles, a few different faces, nothing major.
- Not enough variety in character drawings. This one is a bit nit-picky, but I am struggling to find complaints :p The only time you really see the character drawings in a form that matters is in the cutscenes. The problem with that is the same stances and reaction drawings are recycled throughout the game. I would have liked to see a bit more unique drawings for varying situations.
- While the music is a great asset to the game, it does not repeat or transition cleanly in some cases.
- Some of the skill progressions at low level seem a little lackluster. For example, a 2% chance to bleed targets per hit feels a bit useless when many of these things die relatively quick. I would prefer either high chance or guaranteed trigger with low or weakened effects to balance it. Granted, I am sure these abilities work well on bosses and larger enemies.

TL;DR
A great game with a mix of RPG and Tower Defense elements. Excellent musical scores, and a good storyline to boot. Well worth picking up at full price or on sale. I highly recommend this game.

This game was amazing back when I first got it for cheap cheap from a Steam coupon. I saw it was a tower defense game, and I said to myself, "This is only a few bucks, I'll try it out." Oh my, I didn't know how much I would love this game.

Defender's Quest is a tower defense game with RPG elements, mainly experience points, skill trees, and a good story inbetween the gameplay. It the game has humor, which is rather welcome. The gameplay is where this game really shines.

This is simply the best tower defense game I've ever played. You may have played a tower defense game before, but you haven't played Defender's Quest. It has a lot of depth to its gameplay, it has a very intuitive UI and an unobtrusive tutorial that is very helpful. Tutorial can be turned off entirely in the options, if you really want to. While you're at it, you can increase the experience and gold you get from the game to make it easier, or crash it into the ground and make the game harder. The music fits the game's atmosphere perfectly. I haven't even mentioned that you can mod every aspect of this game yet. Go look in the workshop; the creators of the game made a free sci-fi version of the game just to show you how much flexibility there is in regular modding.

Everything I've mentioned was made better with the recent update. I recommend this game wholeheartedly. 10/10.

23667746.review:
Should've reviewed this a long time ago. The game is a fun little tower defense/RPG hybrid with something like six modes of difficulty for each map (with each difficulty mode having different enemies/different enemy abilities, not a simple boost in health), replayability in the form of New Game+ with extra content, and an interesting story with humorous characters. 

The base game consists of thirty maps with a story cutscene before/after each and two different endings. There are five challenge maps and two endless maps that can be accessed after completing enough story maps.  I haven't finished NG+ recently, but it adds at least five more. 

The game was released on Steam in 2012 and was on Kongregate and other sites before that but the devs have continued to support and update it for free - including adding Steam workshop support, sidequests, a journal for the main character, and most recently this HD update. 

The HD update only came out a few days ago, so it's a little buggy (infrequent crashes for me, but since the game autosaves I haven't lost any progress), but the previous version is still accessible and it's possible to port your save file in from the old version. Given the devs' record of support, I'm sure the HD update will be close to bug-free soon.

23648259.review:
Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is perhaps the best tower defense game I ever played. It introduces new enemies and heroes (turrets) at a comfortable and accessible rate, so you never get swamped or overwhelmed, and with 3 difficulty levels for each stage, there is plenty of replayability and opportunity to level up your team.

Every unit and enemy has visible health, damage, range, bonuses and stats readily available for you, such that there is no information or mechanics hidden from the player. You even have complete control over the timing, being able to pause the game to micromanage, or play at various speeds from 0.25x to 16x game speed.

The in-game world has enough charm, and the characters enough personality and depth, to drive the story and the gameplay progression.

I say tower defense, but there are also plenty of RPG elements, such as buying and upgrading weapons and armor, upgrading abilities, and even naming your recruits and heroes, and customising the colour of your recruits' clothing. Naming your knights after King Arthurs' Court of Camelot, for example, or your Mages after your favourite magical girls, lends tremendously to immersion.

The performance is excellence on almost anything. I get around 40fps on an old dual core Thinkpad at 1152x648, thanks to the native C++ engine and the game's 2D nature.

A staple of any tower defense library. I hardly can wait for the sequel.

_____________________________
Note: I have played through this game several times before the Deluxe upgrade, when it still used the Adobe Air framework, (if I recall correctly,) which was bothersome to install on Linux, and had a resolution cap of 800x600 and a framerate cap of 30fps. The Deluxe HD upgrade allows 60fps gameplay at almost arbitrary resolutions.

23610183.review:
TL:DR : This game understands you. (8.75/10)

The graphics aren't the best, but they're as good as they need to be; the soundtrack and effects are pleasant but not particularly obtrusive or overwhelming. The plot itself is as interesting as it needs to be, with dialogue amusing enough to read- but all of it can be readily skipped past or ignored as one pleases. 

In terms of gameplay, this is a solid tower defense/tactical RPG. LUL manages to skillfully blend the two, producing a well thought out, fairly original tower defense where one identifies with, develops, and equips one's 'towers' much as one would one's characters in games like FF Tactics or Bahamut's Lagoon. What is particularly striking about this game however, is not the gameplay itself- it's present in the gameplay, to be sure; but what really marks this game as interesting is the attention to detail the studio has given to ALL of the aspects. The graphics aren't the best, but they're every bit as good as they need to be. The plot and dialoge are easily skipped because this is a casual game, where you are not expected to care in the slightest, and yet they are still amusing and substantial enough for if you do happen to care for some reason. 

If you need solid proof that LUL clearly understands you, the gamer, just look at the attention they pay to the control scheme. You can play this game without a mouse. Easily. The mouse can help now and then, but these people have dialed in the control system of their game to such an extent that a skilled player could possibly even do better without a mouse than with one, and all the keys are fully mappable, in case their super-intuitive control scheme isn't super-intuitive enough. 

To be fair, I've noticed a glitch or two, but they always seem to get corrected fast enough that you would miss them if you blinked at the right moment.

Overall, always good to see this level of attention being given at all levels of development. 8.75/10

23600753.review:
When I bought it I was somewhat sceptical. TDs for me always were gaming fast food. It's easy to digest, a small thing in between and after a few meals I got to have something real. It's somewhat tasty, but not really flashy nor really making me excited for coming back.

That's where DQ is different. It has an actual well thought out story and more importantly it has characters with personality. Thanks to the small trick that your characters are actually towers (which works surprisingly well), they also get connected to gameplay elements. The levels with skill"trees" create the feeling of progression that tds often lack and rare gear is sparse enough to make me actually somewhat hyped for rewards. 

It goes one step beyond the usual TD with rpg elements (sanctum, dungeon defenders), it's a full fledged rpg in a lot of ways. And it's actually good rpg.

Considering the pretty low price (it's in sale atm) I see no reason not to recommend it (well, 2d-graphics). It's deep, it is enthralling and most importantly it's fun. And as a cherrytop they just released a big update for free. If you like classic rpgs or tds give the demo a shot.

On a side note:
It's one of the two 2d-games in my steam library that I consider gems in disguise.

23588982.review:
There isn't much that hasn't already been said about this game, so I'm not going to write a super long review.

DQ:VF is a very fun Tower Defense-RPG hybrid game.  I bought it with hesitation, very unsure of if I'd like it or not.  It's loads of fun, the story seems good so far, the characters are detailed with their own histories and little quips they say to each other, sometimes humorous.  The gameplay itself works like most TD games except you place heroes that act as your towers, and they can level up and learn new active/passive skills.  Outside of battle you can also equip them with different gear to give them better offense/defense.

I got this game after they came out with the Deluxe edition (mainly upgraded visuals) and I'm glad I did.  I'm sort of a visual person, and I like what I'm playing to be pretty and polished.  I'm not sure I would have enjoyed the Standard version as much, but this free visual upgrade to Deluxe is awesome and well done.

According to their website the devs have already started working on a DA:VF 2 and I'm pretty excited about it.  I'll definitely look into it as more info is released and most likely buy it.

This is one of the best TD/RPG hybrids I've ever played.  The gameplay is light and fun, and you can tell they put a LOT of time into the story and characters.

8-9/10 Would highly recommend.

23540697.review: Here it is almost 4 years later and we're about to get a HD remake and then the sequel. This game still holds up as one of the best tower defense games of all time. It's got RPG elements like leveling, skills and equipment alongside an engaging and entertaining story. There's plenty of depth and content and with the upcoming HD remake I'm looking forward to playing through it all over again. The graphics still look alright despite the age, there's a certain charm to the cutscenes and art style in general. This is going to change once the HD remake comes out but it will still be there as an option for those who want it. The music's good and everything in general is really good. There are a multitude of difficulty customization options and even challenges for achievements or in game rewards, such as never hiring anyone and running through the game with only the story characters (which is really hard) and then running through it again on New Game+ with these same people and getting all the levels beaten on all difficulties (which is almost impossible). There's so many strategies and options available that you [i]will[/i] be playing this many many times.

Honestly, when I first got it I had a set of other "big budget AAA" style games that I decided to play instead because they were basically "shinier" and supposedly great, but so far I'm having a lot more fun with this game now than those games then. I wasn't expecting much from a tower defense style game, but it actually has a story, humor, some challenging gameplay, and rpg elements (all the things I thought I would have found in those other titles). Ein Tower Defense Spiel ohne Türme? Funktioniert das? 
Ja, und wie! Defenders Quest ist das mit Abstand beste Tower Defense Spiel, das ich je gespielt habe. Anstatt Türme gibt es hier Barbaren, Ritter, Bogenschützen und Magier. Selbst die Story, die in anderen Tower Defense Spielen meistens sehr schlecht ist, überzeugt hier. Man darf hier keine herzzerreißende Geschichte mit zig Wendungen erwarten, aber es passt einfach gut zu den abwechslungsreichen Defense-Runden.

22390694.review:
Die Kombination aus Tower Defense und RPG funktioniert für mich.

Story: Höchstens Teenager können sich über den Humor freuen, die Story ist sehr einfach gehalten. Insgesamt dient sie für mich nur als kleiner Übergang zwischen den Missionen.
Charaktere: Alle bedienen klare Klischees und sind mir entsprechend egal.
Mechanik: Skill- und ausrüstbare Türme sorgen für Abwechslung. Das motiviert die Kampagne durchzuspielen. Erst danach entfaltet sich aber der Reiz des Spiels, denn es gibt sehr viele Kombinationen, was dem Spiel strategische Tiefe gibt. Zudem ist das Balancing gut gelungen, weswegen man auch in jeder Mission taktisch gefordert ist. Dadurch kann man auch klare Spielstile entwickeln und hat eine individuelle Truppe am Start.

Fazit: Ich bin gerade dabei das Spiel auf dem + Modus erneut durchzuspielen und empfinde die Herausforderung besonders deswegen interessant, weil sie fair und ohne Zufall ist. Hoffentlich gibts den Teil 2 dann auch irgendwann :)

I don't like tower defense games, but this one is pretty neat. Why? Because it incorporates many RPG elements I do like. Take all the normal tower defense aspects and make them level up with skill selections and you have Defender's Quest. However, I only recommend the game for those who like tower defense games, as the game resorts to repeating content with higher difficulties as far as extending your skills and leveling your party rather than something random or a large amount of content. 22124081.review:
Достаточно интересный вариан Tower Defense:
1) Вместо башен у вас герои разных классов (мечники, лучники, маги и т.д.)
2) Есть Главный Герой - Библиотекарь (это собственно вы), который спаунится в определённом месте и является целью монстров, может за ману (PSI) кастовать заклинания, или вызывать героев.
3) После прохождения уровня герои получают опыт, на который можно повысить их уровень, прокачать навыки или открыть новые.
4) Мана (PSI) даётся в начале уровня, а потом выпадает из убитых монстров.
5) После установки героя его можно усилить (тоже за PSI) до 4 раз. При этом увеличивается базовый дамаг, жизнь и зона поражения героя. Все навыки кроме базового требуют усиления героя до 2-3 уровня для активации.
6) Возможны разные варианты прокачки разных героев одного типа: например один на сплэш-дамаг слабых мобов на входе, а другой на убийство бронированных толстяков.
7) У мобов есть броня, и не усиленный герой может их просто не пробивать.
8) Есть оружие и доспехи, которые можно покупать, и есть артефакты, которые даются обычно за прохождение уровней на максимальной сложности.
9) Мобы уровнем повыше могут навалять вашим героям. Спасает их регенерация и хилеры.

Одна из немногих игр, в которую я периодически возвращаюсь.

In that regards it doesn't play any different than any other TD. However, the leveling up aspect is fun. Adds a grinding element which forces you to play several levels multiple times. 21513179.review: At its core, Defender's Quest is a tower defense game in which your towers aren't just expendable resources that don't change from level to level.  In Defender's Quest, your towers are customizable heroes, with skill trees and a wide variety of abilities.  The story, art style, and music are all rather presentable, and even charming at times, and the core mechanic of leveling up your troops and acquiring new gear has tremendous Pavlovian allure.  It's a fairly expensive game for its relative simplicity, but it nonetheless hugely entertaining.  At full price or on sale, I can't help but recommend Defender's Quest.

20880725.review:
Eine großartige Mischung aus Tower Defence und RPG.

Es gibt verschiedene Klassen die man in Schlachten aufwerten kann, neben den Boost auf dem Schlchtfeld werden die Helden mit der Zeit stärker, also steigen Stufen auf.

Jede Charakterklasse hat einen eigenen Talentbaum, man kann sich frei entscheiden mit welchen Fähigkeiten er gut sein soll.

Somit kann man auf dem Spielbrett verschiedene Helden geschickt platzieren, der eine verlangsamt, der andere durchschlägt die Rüstung der Angreifer, damit andere genug Zeit haben die mit unter zähen Kreaturen schnell zu erledigen.

Die untermalung der Musikstücke ist sehr gelungen, ob fröhliche oder bedrückene Momente, der Soundtrack passt.

Die Story ist für ein Tower Defence Spiel sehr schön geschrieben, ist lange nicht die beste, aber mir hat diese sehr gefallen.

Fazit: Ein sehr schönes Spiel für Zwischendurch, für Leute die Tower Defence mögen, aber auch darüber hinaus, ein Blick wert.

Von mir 09/10 Punkte

20834552.review:
A really fun take on the Tower Defense genre that blends in just the right amount of RPG elements.  The game is well-balanced so that it's challenging but rarely frustrating.  The talent trees for each class are well-designed, and the game doesn't feel "over-balanced" to the point that everything is homogenous and bland.  None of the classes is blatantly overpowered (eh, maybe archers) or totally useless, but there are definitely options that are stronger than others and half the fun is figuring out what works best in what situation.

If I have one complaint, it's that the writing is absolutely painful.  Generick fantasy schlock mixed with cringeworthy attempts at humor.  This doesn't really drag the experience down too much, though, since the plot is perfunctory and all of the cutscenes are skippable.

20795016.review:
Что же, по мне DQ: Valley of the Forgoteen считается отличной игрой своего жанра. И денег она всё же своих стоит!
И сейчас распишу подробнее почему.
-Очень приятная картинка и своеобразная стилистика, которая очень подходит игре.
-Хороший сюжет(нет, не просто хароший, а ЗАПРЕДЕЛЬНОЭПИЧНЕЙШИЙ), где присутствует очень даже хороший юмор.
-Достаточно много уровней (32-сюжетных, 7-бонусных, 7-дополнительных в "Новой игре+"), имеющие 3-уровня сложности(Лёгкий даже и считать не хочется, так как и на среднем всё прекрасно можно пройти)
-6 защитников(башен), которые детально проработаны(от текстур до характеров), где между ними можно и наблюдать весьма забавные конфликт. Каждый из них имеет свою ветку прокачки. А так же почти на каждого можно нацепить какой-то шмот.
-Очень приятная музыка.
В целом игра отличная и недостатков мною не было замечено(Видимо Я был так потрясён этой игрой что и проглядел).
Хотя есдинственное что бы Я мог посоветовать. Так это отключить сразу же отключить "Боевые числа", так как они значительно уменьшают производительность, при огромном скоплении врагов.
За всё время прохождения она не успела мне надоесть. А так же сподвигла меня пройти её полностью.
Но это только моё мнение. Сыграйте в её и составьте своё мнение о данном творении.
Моя оценка(ведь без этого, смотрю уже никуда): 6 из 5 паловников.

20700925.review:
このDefender's QuestはジャンルとしてはTD（タワーディフェンス）なのだが、かなりRPG要素が強いゲームである。
そしてこのRPG要素こそがこのゲームの最大の特徴だと言えるだろう。

通常のTDでは基本的に出せるタワー能力はステージごとに固定で決まっていることが多いのだが、このゲームではタワーとなるキャラクターにそれぞれ個別にレベルとスキルが存在する。
キャラクターは戦闘ごとに得られる経験値でレベルアップしていき、また同時に得られるスクラップ（資金）を使って装備を整えることで、自軍を恒久的に強化していくことが可能なのだ。
ステージは難易度を変えていつでもやり直すことができるので、最新ステージで行き詰ってしまったらいったん戻ってレベルと装備を上げてから再挑戦するというまさにRPG的な流れで物語を進めることができる。
ぶっちゃけ戦闘部分がTDになったRPGという認識でほぼ間違いないだろう。

上に書いたように自軍を強化できるため純粋なTDとしてはやさしめの部類。
よってストーリーをクリアできないということはまずないと思われる。
しかし2周目からは敵も本気を出してくるため油断できない。
特に後半戦はこちらのレベルがMAXでも苦戦を強いられるためなかなか歯ごたえがあるバトルが楽しめる。

総じてかなりの良ゲーといえるでしょう。
一回の戦闘が短いので空いた時間にちょこちょこっとやれるのもよい。
TDやRPG系が好きな人に特にオススメの一本です。

20613653.review: One of the best tower defence games well worth the full price.

20596047.review:
Easily one of the best tower defense games ever made.

If for some reason you are a big fan of tower defense games but play this game and don't like it, then there is something wrong with you...

This game in particular is pretty interesting as far as TD genre goes, since the way it works it has both the familiar back to basics feel/aspect to it AND it has new innovative and refreshing aspects that haven't really been done before or much that just improve the genre to a new and good level.

20502330.review:
In kurzen Worten, storygetriebenes Tower Defense, mit simpler Grafik und Rollenspielelementen.
Das grafisch sehr einfach gehaltene Spiel tauscht die üblichen Türme durch auflevelbare und ausrüstbare Mitstreiter aus. Diese sind in 6 unterschiedlichen Klassen mit individuellen Fertigkeitsbäumen verfügbar.
Während einer Partie können die angeheuerten Recken mittels Psi-Energie platziert und verbessert werden. Dabei ist wie üblich nicht nur die richtige Platzierung sondern auch der richtige Zeitpunkt zum Aufleveln für einen Erfolg entscheidend. Zwischen den Missionen können Fähigkeitspunkte verteilt und neue Gegenstände gekauft werden. An sich alles bekannte Spielmechaniken, die aber durch die Personifizierung der "Türme" eine gewisse Identifikation mit seinem Kämpfern ermöglicht. Darüber hinaus bietet das Spiel solide Kost mit ca. 30 Leveln in je 3 Schwierigkeitsgraden.

Auf dem Markt für Tower Defense Spiele wimmelt es inzwischen von unzähligen Produkten, die alle irgendwo mit einem kreativen Touch um die Gunst der Spieler buhlen. Mit dem Normalpreis von 14€ gehört Defenders Quest dabei schon zur oberen Preisklasse. Die extrem simple Grafik und einfache Spielmechaniken machen das Spiel zu einem unterhaltsamen Zeitvertreib aber ich hätte es mir niemals für den Vollpreis gekauft. Und auch nach mehreren Stunden Spielzeit finde ich den Preis im Vergleich zu anderen Spielen als zu hoch. Wer diese Art von Spielen gut findet, der sollte bis zu einem Sale warten.

20404696.review:
簡単に言ってしまえば、レベルを上げて物理で殴れるタワーディフェンス。
総合評価　95/100

タワーディフェンスにRPG要素を加えたというよりは、戦闘システムがタワーディフェンスのRPGと言った方がしっくり来る感じですね。
従来のタワーディフェンスに比べると大味で戦略性は乏しいですが、爽快感と快適さでは他の追従を許しません。
日本語完全対応で、デモ版だけでも結構遊べるのも嬉しいところです。（ただしデモ版は英語のみ）

ステージ数は30、難易度が3段階あり、その他ボーナスステージやクリア後の二周目要素もあるため、ボリュームはかなりのものです。
1ステージ辺りが短く、4倍速モードもあるので、テンポがかなり良いのもポイント。
正直なところ、一週目の要素だけでも定価で損はしないレベルなので、セールになってたら即買い推奨です。

[b]特徴[/b]
[list]
[*]ステージは難易度ごとに報酬が異なるため、モチベ維持しやすい
[*]同じステージを何度もプレイして経験値とお金を稼げる
[*]経験値やお金の入手率を設定で変更可能（50％～300％）
[*]お金を使って武器防具を買ったり、追加の仲間を雇ったりできる
[*]一時停止や倍速モードなど、タワーディフェンスとして必要な要素は十分
[*]仲間（ユニットの種類）が6人と少ないが、それぞれにしっかりとした役割が存在するため、無駄なユニットがいない
[*]仲間は基本6人だが、町で各5人を追加で雇うことができ、最大36ユニットを使用可能
[*]ユニットのレベルアップに加え、主人公もレベルアップし、初期ユニット召喚コスト等が増加する
[*]レベルアップでは能力が底上げされる他、スキルツリーに自由に割り振れるポイントで好みの特徴を持たせることが可能
[*]スキルポイントはいつでも振り直しが可能
[*]ユニットは複数の攻撃スキルを同時に使用できるため、新しい攻撃スキルを覚えると単純に手数が増える
[*]二週目以降では能力を引き継いでプレイでき、新しいステージや武器強化要素も追加される
[*]スチームワークショップ対応でMODを導入可能[/list]

ストーリーも割と突っ込みどころがあって楽しめました。
台詞回しがやや意味不明ですが、それも逆に味があって良いかと。

欠点ですが、割とよくフリーズします。
オートセーブなので被害はないに等しいため、特に大きな問題とはなりませんが。

総合的に見てスチムゲーの中でもかなりオススメできる作品ですので、気になった方は是非デモ版をプレイしてみてください。
難易度的にはかなり優しい部類なので、タワーディフェンスが苦手な人や初心者にもオススメです。


[b]注意点[/b]
デモ版のデータを製品版で使いたい場合、ゲームを購入する前にデータを「エクスポート」しておく必要があります。
私はこれを忘れて最初からになりましたが、特に気にならずに楽しめるゲームですので、余り気にしなくても良いかもしれません。

20400210.review:
Great game. I love the story, the characters, and world. Great accessibility menu for hardcore and more casual players alike.

My only complaint is that there is a lot of stuff in New Game+ that felt like it should've just been left in the first playthrough. A normal play through feels like a light rpg experience you might get on a mobile game. The New Game+ on the other game actually feels more like a great new addition for RPG and Tower Defense fans alike.

PS- If you are a completionist, or just want to challenge yourself, there is an achievement for finishing the game without hiring any generic units. You basically have to win the game with only one of each unit type. It can be done, and I actually found the game more fun to play this way.

20389137.review:
I forgot I had this game and I am ashamed that I forgot I had it. I had a lot of fun playing this before, as I did just now, but it is late. I feel it deserves my thumbs up. I'll tell ya why.

You are a lady who finds people to join you and help out as the story progresses. The story is quite nice. The people are funny and will often make jokes and claim that they hate the hero, when really they don't.

The actual gameplay itself is typical of most tower defense. You have a grid where you place your units (the 'people' that joined you), and they fight when something is near. What I like about this game is that the different types of units work together. I won't go into any detail about this because you'll probably want to experience it yourself.

Each level is split up into four difficulties. So if you're feeling brave, you can try the hardest. Even if you fail your units will still gain experience points. If you're feeling like a wuss, try the casual setting.

The units have skill trees which you apply 1 point on each level up. I find this to be very rewarding, although sometimes when you complete a level you may have to apply a buncha points (I had to apply about 20 before after one level). C'est la vie.

It is well worth the whatever I paid for it. I don't remember buying it, but I am very glad I did. You'll not be disappointed if you're a fan of tower defense games with a hint of humour and a nice storyline.

20234919.review:
While this is a decent little game, I think it fails to really deliver on its core promises. It's worth some money and time, but I wouldn't recommend paying full price for it.

The game bills itself as primarily a tower defense game. Tower defense games generally require you to come up with a strategy to defeat the enemies given a particular map and set of resources. Defender's Quest maps are much simpler, and to a large extent don't require much strategy. That's where the "RPG" part comes in. There's not really any role-playing going on, but your characters get stronger and you can buy better weapons and armor for them. The maps don't rely so much on strategy as on having characters that are high enough level and have good enough equipment. And that generally means grinding for XP. So when it comes to the advanced and extreme levels, it's not that the levels are possible but you have to have a better strategy. The levels are simply impossible to start with, and the only way you can beat them is by leveling up your characters.

In short, it's not a good tower defense game (because the challenges rely primarily on having high-level characters not strategy), and it's not a good RPG (because there's no real role-playing, just "numbers going up" as you and the enemy gain levels and equipment). So I think it rather fails the "tactical depth" promise.

The second promise is customization, and it does have options to rebind all the keys and change the XP scaling, character names and colors, etc., but I don't think it's a big deal. The developer also put thought into how he could accomodate people with certain disabilities (like epilepsy), which is nice.

The third is story, and I suppose that's where this game does best. The story isn't great, but it does give a reason to keep playing and it is fairly humorous in some parts.

Technically, the game is well-made, even if it appears dated. I can't recall any bugs in the game, and it has been very stable. The game runs at 800x600 resolution, which is fine for me. The sound effects and music are well-done, but lack variety, which is okay for me.

I just wish the game rewarded thinking more than it rewards grinding. It's worth a try if you can get it on sale.

20043068.review:
Один из наглядных примеров как простейшая игра может быть круче любого ААА проекта. Начиная играть, я скептически относился к идее сюжета в tower defense, но Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten полностью превзошла мои ожидания. Эта игра погружает игрока в свой, миниатюрный, но все же такой живой мирок с эпичными приключениями, персонажами за которых переживаешь и толпами врагов готовых растерзать тебя на каждом уровне.

Итак, плюсы игры:
+Эпичный сюжет
+Действительно смешные шутки от персонажей игры
+Необычная система башен-персонажей с прокачкой и инвентарем
+Гора уровней, каждый с 4 сложностями
+Возможность поставить 300% опыта и денег и свести гринд на нет (или наоборот увеличить в разы если вы мазохист)
+Новая игра+ же! начни свое приключение еще раз с дополнительными возможностями и контентом
+Хороший баланс сложности
+Ачивки/карточки
+Русский язык
+Поддержка модов

А теперь, минусы(увы есть и они):
-Игра иногда вылетает
-Жуткие лаги при 36 юнитах 
-Несмотря что дефолтно в параметрах стоят 100% опыта и денег, через несколько часов понимаешь, что на них играть невозможно(приходится много раз перепроходить один и тот же уровень, я уж молчу про фарм на последних лвлах где некоторые шмотки стоят 50к)
-К концу нг+ игра уже поднадоедает ведь карты одни и те же(а я еще боялся что она быстро кончится, лол)
-Многие ачивки требуют 100% пройденной игры что весьма печально(по сути последние 3 уровня и уровень с овцой делают финальные порценты игры ну ОООчень задротскими, ведь на экстриме монстры толстые запредельно и приходится играть на 1/2 скорости чтобы успевать следить за всеми юнитами и одновременно кастовать заклинания вовремя. И это скучно, да.)

Достижение Hero Mode++ делал поистине адский садист, по сути отдельный режим ультрахардкора - 6 героев вместо 36, на последних уровнях нг+ заставляют напрячь мозг и приготовить запасные стулья (фейлы на последней волне по канону, да). На 300% опыта и денег я прошел его за 30 часов, сами считайте сколько бы его пришлось проходить на стандартных параметрах.

Один из лучших подобных проектов, чего ты ждешь, иди скорее покупай!

19553029.review:
Many people called this a "tower defense with RPG elements" at first I didn't know what that meant but it pretty much describes the game perfectly. 

Azra is the leader who can cast spells and also boost defenders - there are 6 types of defenders that have their unique abilities and advantages. While you boost the characters in battle, there also is a leveling up system in which you also add points to certain skills which actually adds a lot of depth to the game - it makes you think about what is mostly valuable of each defender and if you boost them enough for a certain skill to be used.

Some enemies go straight for Azra, some try to get Azra but attack defenders along the way, some are fast, some are slow, some have armor, some have an insane amount of hit points. The come in waves from different locations in different amounts.

It all sounds pretty basic, right? 

What makes this game so special is that it introduces new variables and level designs at just the right pace; there is never too much of one thing in the game, it's never a grind, it's never repetitious. The levels were never frustrating when they were heard either; it always just made me think hard about a better defense, who should get boosted and where I need to reposition during the battle. The idea of making something challenging without making frustrating is something they absolutely nailed on this game. On the flipside, if you are convinced you have everything figured out for your defense and even need to watch - just fast foward with the 2x or 4x button (this small feature is amazing).

If you want to go back and play the battles at a high difficulty, you can do that too, which I also found the be very fun (the higher difficulty didn't just add more enemies - it also changed what types of enemies and even changes the entry points. Once again, they did a great job of preventing this game from feeling like repetitious).

The game has an accompanying story which is kind of funny sometimes. I enjoyed the animations mostly and they were well done. A minor complaint of mine would be that the humor bits would take over the unfolding of the story occasionally and got in the way. I don't feel like the story development was conitinuous enough.

The music was pretty enjoyable and fitting for the game. I will say some of the songs seemed like they were ripped from Nobuo Uematsu (Final Fantasy I - X, Chrono Trigger) but he is the GOAT. 

Highly recommended.

19335846.review:
This one is a soft recommendation for me

Defender's Quest is an interesting twist on the tower defense paradigm. This time, your "towers", are RPG heroes you're summoning on the battle field. This makes for a much more interesting story, with many characters voicing their opinions on what you're doing (usually to complain about it :p). The story itself isn't revolutionary, but it's servicable.

Unfortunately, by making the game an hybrid of TD and RPG, Defender's Quest brings with it the bad aspects of RPG. Mostly, the grind. There will be times where you're facing a level which you simply can't win because your characters/towers aren't levelled up enough. So you will have to grind by doing other stuff (like replaying levels on a harder difficulty) before coming back. It's even more notable and grindy when you're trying to keep your adventuring party small, like the games encourages you to do (by raising recruitement prices, but also having some achievements that only unlock if you never expand your roster).

Another problem with the small roster is that in many levels, there are some optimal positions to place your 5 or 6 people, and then you're pretty much done, you fast forward to see your team hacking and slashing away for several minutes until the level is done. There are some levels where you will more active, with your main character having to use its spells, and you having to replace some of your team in better places. But on the whole, it's a rather static tower defense, since you have limited number of people, an enticement to bunch them together (for increased efficiency) and a limited mana pool to summon.

All that bad stuff being said, Defender's Quest is still way better than most tower defense. The writing is good, the levels are interesting and you can always stop at any point. The main game is pretty easy to finish, while the main game plus will offer a bigger challenge, but also new items, additional missions and optional quests to keep it fresh, and reward you for staying with the game. So on the whole while i wouldn't classify Defender's Quest as one of my favorite games, it does get a soft recommendation from me.

My previous experience with playing a tower defense game was for free one for couple of hours on a relative's iPad and an hour of the original Plants vs. Zombies. I know. 

The story and mechanics of this game are fantastic. The progression is balanced - I like that you can reassign experience points on the leveling (tech) tree. Once your characters are all leveled up, they still have most of the abilities that you want. 

Towards the end of the 2nd quest there are some 3 star levels that feel nigh impossible, but those are the exception and I am sure plenty of people have been able to beat them. On those hard levels the placement of characters has to be meticulously planned to counter the relentlessness and special abilities of the enemy waves. 

I highly recommend this game. It is a shame that there are not more well made 2D tower defense games on Steam.

18978368.review:
I wrote a review for this about a year or so ago but thought I'd rewrite it as I have some different and new views on the game.

First off, this is a tower defense game that revolves around a well written story with a nicely done narrative that includes all the who/what/when/where/why questions, along with moments of subtle humor and despair. On the first play through you get all the character dialogue that propels the story but not a whole lot more. On the second play through you get the main character's (Azra unless otherwise named) thoughts after each mission is completed. These journal entries go pretty in-depth for being subtext you don't even need to go through. There are some 30 entries and I do recommend reading them.

The game starts with the Azra wondering where the hell she is and finding the first warrior, Slak, entering into a battle against the Revenant (the dead). The story progresses and you will find all the other characters (read 'towers'). There are six others you find and you can have up to six of them in that class, in total allowing you to have an army of 36 towers and Azra.

The Berserker is a hack 'n' slash guy. He wields a sword, wears no shirt, and thirsts for blood.
The Ranger is your snarky and quick witted bow expert. She often griefs Azra on menial things such as, "not being pretty enough to have her plans work out."
The Healer comes off as overprotective and cautious but holds the team together.
The Ice Mage is cold and has cynical tendencies but wields the power to stop hordes of foes.
The Knight is rightous and pledges himself to Azra. He takes down the strongest enemies by ripping them of their armor.
The Dragon is the last to join the group. She acts like a god and thinks the humans beneath her yet is impressed at how far Azra and her companions have traveled thus far. She also enjoys eating sheep.

With these characters you can create varying strategies on every battlefield in the game. Some will require a near exact positioning that you'll figure out by trial and error, while others are more liberal in placement. You can pull off a ton of combos though and it's cool to find something that synergizes well.

Now, along with all the characters, each has a skill branch (not tree since there are only two directions it goes) and with each level you get one point to put in each skill slot. Most of them are damage boosts for their attack tier (each character has a five tier attack that is upgraded through Psi that is earned by killing enemies in the level) and the rest are passive buffs. They can include skill cooldowns, range, crit/poison/bleed/blind/armor piercing chance, slow/stun/burn, group damage amplifiers and tagging enemies so they take more damage.

Azra also has six spells she can upgrade. There are three damage and three buff spells. A direct lightning attack, an area of effect crystal explosion, and a full screen flame attack. The buffs are sending your characters into a frenzy to increase attack speed, massive healing, and pushing back waves of enemies. There are also unlockable spell books that can be equipped to provide boosts.

There are three weapons in game that two classes can use. Swords for the Berserker and Knight, a bow for the Ranger, and staffs for the Healer and Ice Mage. Progressing through the story increases the price and damage of future weapons. Armor can be equipped to them as well, heavy and light variants. 

The max level each member can achieve is 60 so you won't be able to max every skill on each character. The good thing about having multiple in a class means that you can have someone with a high bleed chance, and give the other person the higher armor piercing chance. At any point you can pay a small fee of scrap (currency) to respec their builds.

So that's the gist of the game. Pretty straight forward. Where things really get rolling are on the new game +. Much more challenging and rewarding. A new currency of "skulls" becomes used to upgrade the special weapons and armors you aquire through missions. It's pretty hard to get all the skulls as you'll need to grind to get your characters to a high enough level to beat the much harder than before levels. There are also a few puzzles hidden here and there that you need to keep an eye out for. I had some trouble with it and found a guide and without it there would've never been a way I'd have caught on.

All in all, more than your run of the mill tower defense game, great story, fun and unique characters, scaling rewards that only get better and better through all the challenges, and tons of replayability as there is mod support. 

Oh, if you really want a challenge, there's an achievement to beat the game and new game + with only the original characters, not using any of the extra hired ones. And then getting 180 stars (awarded through level completion). That took a ton of time.

Counter review to all the fanboy hype for this game, as I just bought it on sale since it looked good and I needed something to play on my mac book.

This is JUST any other tower defense game. Because every tower defence game has its own unique mechanics for upgrades. The only thing this game "blends" is RPG lore/tropes into tower defense as a theme. This is done in that you upgrade individual towers and each tower levels up on its own. That's it. The blend is just graphical, and it does that poorly because the graphics are poorly done. I don't want to be harsh because I want to give the indie devs the benefit of the doubt in that they couldn't aquire funding/talent for aethistics, but this is worse than a free flash game I could have played instead. Another problem which just elludes to really ameature/cheap UI development is that the game cannot go into fullscreen correctly. It just remains at 800x600 and the fullscreen option simply draws a giant black box on your monitor and centers teh 800x600 game. Why couldn't they have actually developed the UI before releasing it...? Not really a pleasing game to play, way better TD games imho. A game like "Castaway Tower Defense" has much better graphics/UI/visual-imersion than this for example and is free.

As for the writing, it is cute but not good. Some of it is just wrong regarding vocabulary which is odd since one of the selling points was that it was "actually written by an English Major". For example, [SPOILER]one of the bad guys loses his entire army and complains that his forces were decimated[/SPOILER]. Just bad and confusing writing, as the verb "to decimate" means to reduce by 10%. This is something that the Romans would do to their own troops to instill fear into them, to punish them, and to prevent rebellion. It is not something that would happen if you lose all of your army, that would be to have been obliterated or to annihilate.

18499760.review:
A fun little tower defense with RPG elements. The protagonist is a librarian cast into a plague colony, and sets out on a quest to escape. She quickly discovers latent supernatural powers that allow others to defeat the zombified infected. She serves as the objective that must be defended. Besides the standard ability to summon units to defend her, she's also capable of casting spells for harming or buffing, and can equip spell books to further enhance her abilities.

Throughout the game you'll encounter characters who join with you, unlocking new classes of characters (berserker, archer, healer, etc.) that you can hire and summon to defend you. The classes come with simple skill trees that unlock new abilities or enhance them in some way, and every individual unit can be leveled differently from the other, enabling a more diverse army to choose from.

The game is made for a wide variety of skill levels. New players and seasoned veterans alike will find something to challenge them when the game gets rolling, and you can replay maps as you please for practice or for XP/money. The map's rewards are better for higher difficulty settings, and can reward unique equipment for success. The game can seem like a grindfest, but the devs wisely included the option to increase XP/money gains and to ensure all units get equal access to it, regardless of whether or not they entered battle.

The story itself is very competent. The characters are largely likeable and the writing and humor is enjoyable. The cast tend to have something of an emphasis on their quirks, but mostly avoid becoming bland one notes with varying degrees of depth.

The game is not without its flaws. Completionists can find that the New Game+ might become something of a chore, the skill trees are rather simple in their execution, and certain parts of the story or characters can become tiresome (looking at you, Slak). If you can put this aside, you still have a fun and funny game that's worth a look. Grab the demo and give it a spin. You can even transfer your save file if you choose to purchase it, and the game is set to receive an HD update (at the time of writing) and sequel.

18444631.review: Defender's Quest is a short game, but provides plenty of options to extend the experience. Completing every level at the highest difficulty takes about twenty hours; increasing the experience and money levels in the options decreases the playtime. However, the New Game+ mode, which becomes available after completing the base game, adds considerable challenge. The core story stays the same, but combat's modified with new enemy powers, new maps, and new bonus stages. The New Game+ also provides a delicious means of upgrading the magic items earned in the core game, unlocking unique modifiers for each relic. As enjoyable as these new features are, Azra's journal is the best addition to the New Game+. After every major battle, Azra updates her journal with commentary on the story. In the process, she details her internal struggles and fleshes out the world. The extra character moments in Azra's journal are enjoyable enough that their inclusion as bonus material seems strange. They'd serve the story better as part of its body rather than as bonus material.

18318368.review:
タワーディフェンスとRPGを足して上手く調和させた作品。
RPGは好きだけど、タワーディフェンス（以下TD）はやったことないから･･･
というTD初心者にもおすすめできます。
日本語対応なのも嬉しいポイント。

見た目とインターフェイスが古臭く頼りない感じはするし、実際古臭いですが中身は至ってまとも。
RPG的要素（スキルビルド、装備、レベル）などをがありつつもユニット配置や攻撃範囲、
敵の足止めや回復、さらにユニットのパワーアップと
TDとRPGの面白いポイントをカチっとうまくはめ込んであります。
ひとつのステージに難易度が３つあり、特別報酬が貰えたりやり込み部分もしっかりある。
ステージ中の主人公スキル使用やユニットの強化、ユニットの配置に
主人公のMP（のようなもの）を消費するため配置をどううまくやるか、
どのユニットをどう強化させてのりきるかといったTDとの兼ね合いが楽しい。
また、どんなに難しいステージもレベリングや装備で乗り切ることが可能なため
TDは難しい！といった人にもおすすめできます。

反面、TDのような繊細な配置やパズルのような面白さには欠け、やや大味な点も。
全体的にステージも狭く、ユニット配置が固定になりがち。
結局のところレベルと装備でなんとかなってしまい、
逆にレベルと装備がないと無理ゲーに近いものがあります。
嫌でもレベルアップするシステムのため硬派TDやりたい人にはあまりおすすめできないかも･･･

とはいえ、MAPとレベルによってはTDのようなしっかりした配置をしないと突破されしまうし、
自キャラが育って前線で雑魚をさくさく倒してしまう様を見ると、
まるでハクスラのような快感も得られます。
さらに二周目や高難易度ステージも用意されているためやり込みも豊富。
種類は少ないながらWorkshopに対応しているなど至れり尽くせりの作品となっております。

おすすめ！

17646629.review:
I've played a lot of tower defense. I used to play Warcraft III custom maps where the tower defense genre was cut from. Defender's Quest does a nice job of putting a well developed story with well developed characters into tower defense gameplay without it feeling pasted on. 

It keeps it simple. There are only a few basic towers to choose from, but each tower acts like a character in your party and you can equip most of them with weapons and armor (no weapons or armor for a dragon and no armor for the barbarian/main melee guy). The maps are laid out well enough that consideration to where to place your troops does make a big difference.

There is also a nice take on the gameplay by offering 4 difficulty levels. You get rewards for completing the level, but you get bonus rewards for not taking a single point of damage. If you do that, you can get a lot of extra scrap (money) and unique items.

What I'm doing on my second playthrough is going as far as I possibly can while only buying recruits and never any items on the easiest mode. When I hit my first failure, I go back to the very start and try to complete each level on the hardest mode possible. After I fail once, I will go down to an easier mode and so on until I am right back at the easiest mode and therefore, the furthest out I've ever been.

The main game is not that long and there isn't a ton of replayability to this game once you complete it. That is why it is only worth a few bucks...but it's worth a few bucks. I hear they are making a Defender's Quest II and I hope that is at least as good. Even when it is, this is still a pretty fun tower defense and something that feels more refreshing than you might think when you come back to it after a long time.

Отличная игра и отличное доказательство, что всё гениальное - просто. Казалось бы, банальная такая история о юной столичной библиотекарше в фэнтезийной стране, которая вынуждена скрываться в компании своих разных интересных и чудаковатых друзей, отражая нашествие полчищ зомби и прочих тварей. Но главное здесь, конечно, геймплей. Десятки напряжённых карт, где на нас полчищами прут жуткие твари: плюющиеся кислотой, распадающиеся на тварей поменьше, дерущиеся, бронированные, трудноубиваемые, а мы выстраиваем у них на пути толпу наших защитников и с их помощью, а также с помощью кое-каких магических трюков (коих у нас постепенно становится больше) стараемся удержать, ведь если они доберутся до главной героини и обнулят ей хелф бар игре наступит конец. И своих бойцов мы можем прокачивать, обучая новым приёмам. 
 Очень увлекательная и напряженная игра, даже на легчайшей сложности. И даже русский поддерживается (что, к сожалению, для стима редкость). Игра, определённо стоящая своих денег. Оценка 8 из 10.

17060333.review:
Чудесная и крайне увлекательная игра, затягивает моментально. Подойдёт и тем, кто не хочет серьёзных вызовов, и тем, кто любит играть на пределе своих возможностей, так как есть специальное меню, где регулируются получаемый опыт и награды за битвы. Весь игровой процесс построен по принципу "легко научиться - сложно стать мастером": вначале сражения достаточно простые, но их сложность к финалу серьёзно увеличивается и от "прокачать всех, тыкнуть кнопочку ускорения и откинуться в кресле" быстро переходишь к лихорадочному слежению за ходом битвы. 
Другая особенная черта Defender's Quest - персонажи. Все они, включая нашу героиню, отдельные личности со своими характерами, целями и мечтами: одни просто хотят выбраться на свободу, другие ищут искупления за старые грехи. Но особенно приятно наблюдать как по мере прохождения игры эта пёстрая банда, объединившаяся из чистой необходимости, становится ближе и роднее друг другу, как меняются персонажи и становятся друзьями те, кто друг друга терпеть не мог. 
Подводя итог: игра полностью заслуживает своей оценки в Стиме и своих денег, советую обязательно попробовать даже тем, кто обычно в Tower Defence не играет, благо есть демо-версия. Я не фанат жанра Tower Defence, но осталась очень довольна и теперь с нетерпением жду вторую часть.

P. S. Не пугайтесь пиксельной графики, про неё забываешь через пятнадцать минут после начала игры.

16586256.review:
Pros
+ Fun tower defense game with great gameplay
+ Can adjust difficulty
+ Amusing dialogue
+ Can customize units
+ New game + adds new features that provide replay value

Cons
- Graphics are unimpressive (despite the Deluxe HD Update)
- Music is repetitive
- Cut scenes don't look that much better than before

Defender's Quest is a great tower defense game for fans of the genre. It is the only tower defense game I can think of that has a decent plot and humor. You can also adjust the game's difficulty without any penalty. (300% gold and EXP is very useful when you need to grind.) I also like how I can name and customize my units. So many tower defense games have you fill the screen with identical towers, so it's nice to create an army of unique people.

I'm not very picky when it comes to graphics, but I think the game could really use better graphics and music. It's not a deal-breaker, but it does take away from game to some extent. I know that the Deluxe HD Update has been released, but the art style still looks primitive. Also, the update did not touch the music, so get ready to hear the same 5 songs over and over again as you fight your way through this lengthy, zombie-infested pit (twice if you're up for New Game+).

Overall, Defender's Quest is a fun tower defense game that has lots of charm. If you enjoy tower defense games, I'd definitely recommend Defender's Quest for some classic tower defense gameplay.

16365290.review:
This game. This is most likely the biggest surprise in my entire library. 

I originally bought this game about two years ago. The Steam Trading Card system  had just launched into beta (remember when everyone thought it was going to be huge and a card could be worth $5?) and I had gotten in. Curious to test the system out, I found I at the time did not own any games on the short list of applicable games. I immediately did two things. First, I purchased Half-Life 2 since I had played that game on another account and knew it was good. Second was I started scanning the list for cheap games. This was on a daily deal sale the following day. 

I checked it out and saw that is seemed like a pretty generic, if solid, tower defense game. Felt like one of those particularly good flash games on something like Kongregate or Armor Games. Still, for 5 bucks, I figured it was worth a shot. 

And I wasn't entirely wrong in my expectations. This does very much feel like a buffed up flash game in a lot of ways. And then I asked myself if that was a bad thing. The gameplay is simple and understandable yet plenty difficult. Creativity is encouraged and different strategies will be required. The graphics weren't amazing, certainly not HD (though a HD update is on its' way at time of writing) but I feel like the art has character to it. This of course is helped by the fact that there actuually is a solid storyline in the game, more than many games I've played. The characters don't have a lot of screentime for development, yet I still feel like they are real. 

All in all, this game I found to be a very good surprise. Don't expect a AAA level game, but do expect a game whose simple charm and solid gameplay will leave you satisfied. This game doesn't amaze, but it does the one thing that all games have to do. It's simply entertaining. The devs (who btw are super communicative and dedicated to their games) really did a great job with this one, and I look forward to their future work. 

9/10 - Highly Reccomended

16350835.review: An enjoyable RPG-Tower Defense hybrid. I'm not generally a huge fan of Tower Defense-style games, but this one caught my interest and keeps me comin' back.

16318553.review:
Not a good game.

It was as if the devs made sure it had all the elements to sell, but none to make it fun.

Not an enjoyable 17 hours.  I wasn't smart enough to stop.

(1)  The tower defense gameplay was poor.  The appeal of tower defense games is usually to try and optimize your defense to be efficient and effective as possible against the oncoming force.   In Defender's Quest there are very few places where your characters can be placed rationally.  In other words, there was only one strategy to place your characters when you setup.  Since there were no other real elements to the game, this made it very boring.  When you lost a mission, you couldn't try and refine your process as there was nothing to refine.  You just needed to level up to get stronger.

(2)  The character leveling up process was poor.  I decided to buy the game because the game boasted an RPG leveling-up process.  Although this is technically true, you DO HAVE TO CLICK A BUTTON in order for them to get more powerful, it could have been done automatically as your choices were thin, uncreative, and obvious.  Again, there was no game element in it.  You put the point where it was supposed to go and done.

(3)  The storyline was not worth it.  I don't remember the storyline other than it seemed shallow.  The characters were the best part of the game.  Each character seemed unique and full of personality, but the storyline needed more to take away from the poor gameplay.  Because I liked the characters and I thought they were unique, it was a big letdown to find out later that you get more characters just like them gameplay wise.  Here you thought you had a unique crazy berserker guy or a badass ice mage, but no, they are just one of many.

(4)  The enemies were uncreative.  The enemies were similar across the board.  At no point do you need to change your strategy based on the different types of enemies coming our way.    Some tower defense games have VERY uncreative enemies, but they don't need varied enemies as the game element is in the placing of the towers/characters, abilities, and tower synergy.  Defender's Quest did not have that.

15697245.review:
Verdict: A wonderful take on the often stale Tower Defence genre, with light RPG elements, solid gameplay, excellent art and soundtrack and a simple but endearing story. 8/10


Story: The story is simple and humour-orientated, but endearing and, at times, surprisingly engaging given that is delivered through static art cut-scenes and text speech bubbles. The characters are distinctive, fun and memorable. 7/10

Gameplay:  The gameplay is solid Tower Defence with light RPG elements. You equip and level up your heroes, which you place as towers to fight off the waves of encroaching enemies. Placement is key, such as placing your ice mages a good distance from your fire-breathing dragons as their abilities will counteract one another, or ensuring your knights will be able to shatter the enemy armour before your archers rain down their arrows for maximum impact. 9/10

Graphics: Simple, pixelated graphics are stylistic and get the job done but have been done better elsewhere. Sprites look good, environments are dull and a bit repetitive. The cut-scene art is fantastic. 6/10

Sound/Music: The sound effects are basic and appropriate to the pixelated presentation. The soundtrack, on the other hand, is superb. 8/10

This game, to be honest, is one that I have not played for a few months, but it's not because of anything to do with this game. It's because of OTHER new games that I'd like to try out.

This game is an example of a game which looks bad, but is addictive and as fun as all hell and is worth playing. If you're second-guessing this game because "it looks bad" or "it looks like a waste of time and money", believe me when I say that those are all lies. A compelling, fantasy-like, and whimsical atmosphere, powerful and quirky characters, enemies that give you challenges, and even a second game inside of the game are only a fraction of the reasons why I love this game.

Are you bored of your currently-owned games? This game is the fun little challenge that will keep you asking for more.

15549466.review:
This is a tower defense/RPG hybrid where your towers and home base are all characters that level up between battles, giving you points to spend on stats and extra abilities. No tower mazing is involved, and there are enemies that can attack your towers, necessitating armor, dodge, and healing abilities in addition to strong damage output, slowing attacks, buffs, debuffs, and knockback. Defender's Quest succeeds in blending tower defense and RPG gameplay thanks to strong design on many levels.

pros:
+ core gameplay is fun -- character and enemy design are good and placing/upgrading your characters always feels strategic
+ excellent balance and tuning with multiple difficulty settings
+ the interface is intuitive and well-designed
+ there is a good amount of content in the game
+ graphics may not be fancy, but they're attractive enough and nothing is an eyesore
+ good soundtrack and SFX, although more length and variety in level music would be nice
+ somewhat engaging but not overly distracting story with effective world-building

cons:
- weak customization: although there are many global spells and character upgrades to choose from, there's rarely more than one viable choice for top effectiveness.
- the comedy in the game, while quite funny in its own right, is very silly and can clash with the dramatic aspects of the writing, hurting immersion and undercutting character development (looking at you Slak)

Overall, this game is a real gem and I highly recommend it.

14954355.review:
Marrying two uniquely intricate genres of games, RPG and Tower Defense, Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten displays a very well-balanced gameplay and an incredibly enticing combat system. Essentially placing stationary combatants that may be bestowed special abilities (your Towers) by investing numerical value of "Psi" into them, on a grid-like environment overlay, coming in a variety of different classes, unlocking new classes as you progress the main storyline. Each class a page out of a classic RPG history book, they each carry their own bevy of abilities based on the type (Berzerker, Archer, etc.) that will bolster your defenses either for the better or worse depending on placement and Psi investment. Characters may earn EXP by being used in battle, growing levels as the criteria becomes met and allowing the player to invest skill points into a basic (yet vital) skill tree.

The overall feel of this game is very old-school, but executes sleekly by today's standards. The World Map (level select screen) features a beautiful score, quite reminiscent of early RPG soundtracks. Interestingly enough, the site for Defender's Quest 2 claims to have musical talent brought forth from none other than Nobuo Uematsu himself. One of the millions (billions?) of Final Fantasy players and avid enjoyers of their dynamic, emotionally-captivating soundtracks, this notion that an industry veteran so well known is working with an indie developer brings me hope for the future generations of gaming. Imagine the experience this renowned professional can impart upon this team, and how this team may in turn inspire Nobou Uematsu, thusly conceiving the music that highlights some of gaming's most touching and well-loved moments. Relationships like these in the game industry are vital for its continuation as the younger generations may offer fresh ideas while in turn being nurtured by the experience and wisdom of seasoned developers having been in the industry since its near-conception (decades, folks!). I sincerely hope that veteran talent continues to  reach out to budding indie developers like Level Up Labs who clearly have a passion for delivering a lasting entertainment experience that is indeed inspiring to all. 

I thoroughly enjoy every moment I spend playing this game, and there is a very high probability that you will, too.

*Reading Rainbow Transition*

14801402.review:
A competent and enjoyable, if somewhat limited, tower-defense game

Most of the challenge comes from the mixture of enemies in each wave and the limited ability to create the prototypical "kill zones". Enemy times have specific vulnerabilities, and some of the player's defense units are direct counters for these vulnerabilities. Usually, a mixture of units in each lane, with an emphasis on archers, will suffice for most challenges.

It's not a super-difficult or revolutionary game by any means. Its production values are very limited, and that will bother some. But it has a lot of humor, a competent save-the-world storyline, and some interesting units (dragons, for instance, are hard to use well).

I'd recommend this game for someone looking for a little dash of charm with their casual, traditional tower-defense experience.

14595684.review:
I usually prefer to wait until I finish a game before I review it (barring episodic games but even then I finish the episodes that are available THEN review) but I enjoyed this game so much I figured I'd might as well review even before I finished it -- especially since it seems like there's so much to do! 

First of all, I'm not normally a tower defense fan; I actually picked up Defender's Quest as part of a Humble Bundle female protagonists deal. I don't even remember why I decided to try the game on a whim but I'm SO glad I did. The story is interesting and, even better, funny. There's tons of really good characters and the devs have done a good job of creating a story that walks the line between silly and serious pretty well. 

In terms of the gameplay, like I said -- I don't particularly enjoy tower defense, mostly because the ones I've played previous to this have all seemed far too complicated to be worth the time and effort. Prior to Defender's Quest, the game that I've enjoyed the most in the genre was Plants vs. Zombies. Defender's Quest is a step above that, really, because DQ actually attempts to have a story and character development, though the basic goals of the two games are the same. I'd say DQ is a little bit tougher than PvZ, if only because there's a lot more variability in the maps, whereas PvQ was a fairly straight-forward flat plain. DQ offers maps with multiple enemy spawn points (three is the most I've seen so far), different terrain (e.g., water vs. land), and various restrictions in routes for enemies (and placement for allies). I especially enjoyed the way you can change battle speed to slow down -- or pause -- the enemies spawning to catch up or speed up (4X is amazing) if you're sure your allies can handle the enemies without much management. It's a nice mix that I liked, because I prefer to micro-manage at the start, rather than during the battle. Even better is the different battle difficulty settings, so you can go back and replay battles on a harder setting (same map, different enemies) PLUS bonus challenges and (so the achievements would suggest) a new game plus mode -- means there's tons of stuff to do. Playing DQ actually makes me want to go out and find similar tower  defense games to play because I enjoyed this one so much -- which is probably the best compliment I can give a game!

Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten - одна из лучших игр в жанре Tower Defence, в которые я когда либо играл.
Здесь нет каких-то башен, все участники вашей команды - люди. Со своей историей, со своими проблемами и со своими возможностями.
Сюжет. Он и правда хороший и интересный. И сами персонажи хороши. Берсерк любит снимать штаны во время боя, лучница иногда напоминает стерву а мечник просто красавчик (особенно когда стоит в котле с супом). Хороший юмор, все вставки можно потом пересмотреть и еще раз улыбнуться.
Юниты нанимаются отдельно, в игре их шесть видов. Каждый юнит уникален, вы можете каждому купить свою экипировку и развить свои навыки.
Полно различной экипировки, даающей бонусы к статам.
Масса врагов, много боссов.
Отдельно скажу про новую игру+ (доступна после прохождения игры). Черт, она великолепна. Новые возможности, новые вещи, новые задания. Вот как нужно делать новую игру+ !
За такую игру разработчикам просто хочется сказать спасибо.
9 супер-баранов из 10

14367622.review:
From indie developer Level Up Labs, Defenders Quest is a Tower Defence game set in the fantasy world of the Ash Kingdom. Hailing to the final fantasy tactics series with its strategic character placement and pixel art sprites. The unique blend of tactical RPG and Tower defence mechanics offers something familiar but fresh. With a fully customisable cast of characters and intricate levelling system, Defenders Quest is a western effort to try reinvent a diluted genre.

You play as the heroine Azra, the former royal librarian of the Ash Kingdom who is exiled to the ruinous outskirts of the city when found dying from the plague. On the brink of death, Azra awakens in a purgatory state to be attacked by a swarm of zombie like creatures or 'Revenant', and by using newly acquired magic and the assistance of a fellow surviving berserk mercenary – you journey through the Pit to uncover the secrets of these creatures and the valley. As you progress you accumulate a small army of companions of different class from swordsman, archers and dragons to face off against a number of tyrants to free the land from the plague. 

The game primarily revolves around a linear story driven campaign that places you in the overworld of the pit. From here you enter battles that charge waves of enemies at you from designated points, trying to reach and attack Azra. To defeat each wave you tactically place your available units across the map using your Psi resource to do so. Each unit has unique abilities and resistances to overcome each wave. You can also recall and reposition each unit, but this consumes further Psi. Azra also has a host of abilities that can boost her own units and fend off the waves of enemies. Each battle has 3 levels of difficulty and as you progress on normal you can revisit a previous battle to gain further XP and stars.
The Overworld also acts as a hub for towns and lairs. Before battles you can visit these locations to recruit units or purchase more effective weapons and armour. 
You can also complete bonus levels that offer intense challenges for greater reward after gaining enough stars. 

Defenders Quest is highly accessible but introduces a depth to tower defence that elevates it requiring the player to strategize and carefully consider how each unit is levelled and their positioning in battle. The character development is clearly influenced by role playing games, whilst removing the repetition and time associated with grinding. This effectively ensures your steady progression through the story whilst each battle holds new challenges.
The narrative is also highly original and maintains intrigue and invention that is expected of a good RPG. Azra is the sympathetic protagonist facing off against an unknown villainy. 
The ability to pause a battle at any time emphasises the necessity to properly prepare your units placing them in the most effective positions and levelling them appropriate to the incoming enemies.
The game aesthetic is very nostalgic, calling back to the pixel art of classic JRPGs such as Final Fantasy and Chrono Trigger. Each recruit can also have a custom name and colours, allowing you to personalise your army.
The main campaign is appropriately paced across seven acts, but encourages you to revisit past levels for bonus equipment and increased challenge. You can complete your army with any class of your choice as their unlocked, further increasing the range of tactics when battling and tailoring your strategies the units you've selected. 


The breadth and uniqueness of the story is commendable and gives engrossing context to the battles. However the static cut-scenes through which its told at times become unnecessarily prolonged and tedious, after the initial character introductions we generally skipped through them to get to the battles. 
Furthermore there is a distinct characterised design to the figures in these scenes which drastically differs to the more befitting pixel models. This lack of consistency is also noticeable against the painterly backdrops.
Defenders Quest is strongly reminiscent of its influences, but also tries to introduce a more detailed textured interpretation of its characters, that unfortunately leaves to big a void in the games overall presentation.

What starts out as a charming and casual game soon evolves into a challenge. 
Unlike most tower defence games there is no such thing as the ultimate deployment to beat every level. Each battle requires a unique strategy, that sometimes requires you to fine tune each unit. 

Whilst tower defence remains primarily a casual genre, Level up Labs have crafted a game with a refined battle system and immersive world that requires a fair investment of the players time. Through adapting existing RPG conventions and introducing a few new parameters, Defenders Quest's perilous journey is worthy of the most battle-hardened players.

Watch at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5KVFiflbRco
