14333366.review:
At first glance, Defender's Quest appears to be a silly little indie game with big dreams. The characters are bright and cartoony, and their dialogue is marked with sass. Their battle sprites display whimsical touches, like the ranger who spins her bow before firing. One of the promotional spellbooks Azra can equip, the Book of Face, introduces the Internet's beloved Trollface to the otherwise sword-and-sorcery setting. Focusing on the one-liners would be simple, as they are good. However, the core plot has heft: it would make a good Dungeons and Dragons campaign or fantasy adventure novel. Royal librarian Azra must survive in a quarantine pit the size of a small nation, while she's pursued by mysterious figures. It features conspiracy, betrayal, and explosions. Careful gamers shouldn't be surprised a USDA-certified English major wrote the script. The wacky comedy and childish in-fighting among Azra's companions allows the team to quickly bond. These light-hearted intra-party friendships and feuds add personal stakes to the more pervasive dangers of the pit. The story is delivered in slideshow style before every town and battle, tying the narrative neatly to combat.

Combat is handled like a tower defense game. Enemies travel in waves from spawn points. As they walk into the attack range of stationary heroes, they suffer the effects of the heroes' attacks. The heroes are unable to move from where they're summoned, as they're doing combat on a spiritual plane where bodies just get in the way. The cornerstone of battle strategy comes from placing the six types of heroes in the appropriate location. After recruiting story characters (such as Slak, the madcap, murderous berserker), faceless extras of the same type become hirable. If that's all there was to combat, it would be a delightful diversion. However, each character gains experience points, which can be spent to learn new combat skills or boost existing ones. Once learned, most of these skills can't be used immediately. Characters must be boosted in battle, which draws from the same Psi pool Astra uses to summon allies and cast spells of her own. It can be a challenging balancing act to position the proper allies, keep them boosted, reposition troops to respond to new threats, and maintain wide scale battlefield control with Azra's spells. Thankfully, slowing the game's speed (and pausing it altogether) are simple options. The keyboard commands are simple to learn and encourage faster play, but nothing's wrong with the mouse either.

With all the moving parts that go into battle, the multiple levels of accessibility are a nice touch. Each character has nine different attack modes including "attack the strongest enemy" and "attack the enemy with least immunity to status effects." Understanding the interplay between these attack modes isn't necessary for most of the core game, but integral to completing the optional levels. Furthermore, failure isn't necessarily punished. The default settings infer experience and money penalties for losing battles, but these can be changed based on individual preference. Redistributing skill points to explore different character builds costs money, but not a fortune. The steepest cost is the time it takes to click through all the advancements. The largest concession to the casual-vs.-hardcore debate is the option to increase experience points. Players who care more for the story and the thrill of rapid advancement can run with it. Players who want their hardcore bragging rights can lift their noses at the low-hanging fruit. True challenge-jockeys can set their sights on the more exclusive achievements, many of which are challenging even with gushing wells of experience points.

Defender's Quest is a short game, but provides plenty of options to extend the experience. Completing every level at the highest difficulty takes about twenty hours; increasing the experience and money levels in the options decreases the playtime. However, the New Game+ mode, which becomes available after completing the base game, adds considerable challenge. The core story stays the same, but combat's modified with new enemy powers, new maps, and new bonus stages. The New Game+ also provides a delicious means of upgrading the magic items earned in the core game, unlocking unique modifiers for each relic. As enjoyable as these new features are, Azra's journal is the best addition to the New Game+. After every major battle, Azra updates her journal with commentary on the story. In the process, she details her internal struggles and fleshes out the world. The extra character moments in Azra's journal are enjoyable enough that their inclusion as bonus material seems strange. They'd serve the story better as part of its body rather than as bonus material.

In spite of all this praise, Defender's Quest isn't perfect. Despite the snap and crackle of the script, it features several glaring spelling and punctuation errors--especially in Azra's journal. Purchasing equipment isn't as interesting as other elements of character customization, but the numerical benefits encourage frequently clicking through upgrades. The music is initially encouraging, but loops quickly. Thankfully, it can be toggled independently of the sound effects, which provide texture and valuable combat cues. The final battle song is a notable exception. That beast should be blasted loud and proud.

Between its addictive gameplay and sliding difficulty scale, Defender's Quest offers gamers a great deal for such a small investment of time. It probably won't make a true believer out of anyone whose parents were killed by tower defense games, but it's good at what it does: drawing people in and refusing to let them go until they've finished "just one more level."

14302713.review:
Defender's quest is a mix of a tower defense + rpg elements and the result is a very addictive game.
You're Azra royal librarian casted into the pit because you got the plague, but for some reason you get a strange vision about a golden man and discover new powers capable of destroying revenants for good, now gathering new allies you on a search trying to get out of the pit for your freedom, but also learning why you're special.
During the game you will unlock a total of 6 classes of heroes each with different pros and cons, archers low dmg but great range, knight high dmg but slow attack speed, berserker high attack speed medium dmg, ice priest area attacks with crow control skills, priest healer and buffer and dragons overally awesome.
There's a total of 30 levels each can be replayed on higher difficulties for more rewards (xp or unique gear for your defenders) but doing higher difficulties requires higher leveled defenders so they can unlock/upgrade skills and passives, unlike other TD games you upgrade the hero to give him a bonus in all stats and unlock his following active skill, which requires previously to level them up outside, kind of confusing but easy to understand as soon as you can see it.
There's a set of really hard achievements such as get 180 gold stars without buying generic heroes, reaching wave 100 on endless challenge, and killing a extremely overpowered sheep.
Once you beat the game newgame+ gets unlocked, tougher waves, newer gear, 7 side quests which some of them add a lot to the plot, journal logs after every level for more detailed lore about Azra's thoughs about everything than been happening, and items to upgrade the unique gear obtained from doing 3 star levels in normal play, can switch back and forth between both styles at will.
Highly recommended even at full price, good TD system and interesting storyline with some (a lot) of funny scenes, i even played 4 hours on a row without even realizing.

10/10

I did not knew that DQ will become one of my favorite games of all time. I spotted a game on sale on Steam. Checked the screens, description, some players opinions. Mix of Tower Defense and RPG? That sounded interesting. It turned out that it was a game I was waiting for.

Graphics are really good. They're tidy, have charm. Well, ok cut-scenes could look better, but they're not bad. Still visuals are not important here.
What is important is gameplay. What can I say, it's brilliant. You're placing heroes, of few classes, on battle field, changing tactic with each new level. Characters varies, have nice skills, synergize well. With each battle they gain experience points which leads to new levels and skill points, making your heroes stronger. It adds a little grind to classic Tower Defense game. You can revisit once done levels, increasing it's difficulty to gain bonuses. And then, after the game is over, there is new game plus, making things even more complicated.
You will have Dragon in your team and you will kill sheeps!
Story starts suddenly, with our protagonist Azra, just like us, surprised with events that occurs. With time we will learn about plague and revenants, will find out who is the villain. It's nothing ground-breaking but is good excuse to continue the adventure. There is even a moral decision!
The key part is the dialogues. They're simply amazing. Heroes are crazy so we ends up with many fun jokes, that will leave you with minutes of laugh. There are few misses, still author's sense of humor turns out to be very good. Good stuff.

Defender's Quest is great game. Fantastic example of how well Tower Defense can work with RPG. This game gave me plenty of great time, it offers lots of content, making it one of my better purchases. I recommend it to everyone. You won't be dissapointed.

13904145.review:
Tower defense meets RPG.  Somehow it works really, really well.

Worth noting that I usually hate tower defense games.  I think I got this as part of a Humble Bundle or something and only installed it when I was really bored one night and suffering from insomnia.  It made my night a whole lot better.  Characters of different classes replace what would normally be different defense turrets in other games, but you level them up individually with a skill tree unique to each class.  These unlocked skills and stats stay between maps, so you might have one archer set up for fantastic range while you set another one up for massive damage and a third for rate of fire.  This keeps the game interesting.  Also, none of the maps feel impossible to achieve a perfect on, as long as you're strategic and patient.  There's also a New Game + mode.  In retrospect, I'd be willing to have spent full price on this.

EDIT:
I went back and played through this game over the last couple of weeks and realized how good of a story it has.  The game manages to mix serious and humorous very well.  The writing is better than most games that cost five times as much.  I even pre-purchased the sequel directly from the developer because of how much I enjoyed this game.

13826484.review:
[h1]TL:DR? See Conclusion[/h1]

[h1]INTRODUCTION:[/h1]
Defender Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is a 2D game with a unique blend of TD and RPG from Level Up Labs. It features characters / companions who act as 'towers' and need to be strategically placed around the map to defend your main character Azra. Unlike a tower defense game, however, you can level up and equip items for your companions to help them improve in combat.

You take the role of Azra, a royal librarian of the Kingdom of Ash which is currently being ravaged by a plague. Azra gets infected and thrown into 'The Pit', a place where all dead or dying are placed to keep the kingdom safe because those who die from the Plague become 'Revenants', undead monsters that are immune to physical harm. Azra soon discovers that she has the power to enter both the living world and the 'Half-Way' world, a place between the living realm & the realm of the dead. In this realm, she can summon her companions to fight the Revenants in their spirit form and eventually kill them.

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
+ Refreshing new mix of genres
+ 8-bit sprite art style that works well with the game
+ Character / Companion progression is deep and extensive
+ Well designed Maps and Mazes
+ Very challenging difficulty levels
+ 6 base classes (towers) which can progress into different builds depending on your play-style
+ Dialogues between characters are humorous
+ Steam Workshop support

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
- Cutscene art work could use a lot of improvement (especially the character designs)
- Story is a bit weak
- Balance issues (some classes are outright better than others)
- Some necessary but boring grinding sessions to progress
- No real 'HD' or Widescreen Support
- No Steam Cloud Support

[h1]CONCLUSION:[/h1]
It is a GOOD GAME and one of the better tower defense games out there. I can easily recommend this game if you're looking for a challenging and unique game since it mixes RPG elements to the tried-and-tested Tower Defense genre. The 8-bit sprites, animations and effects are nice and work well with the game's art style although the Cutscene artwork could really use improvements. The levels are very well planned and are fun to play. Finally, the in-game dialogue between your companions is funny and quite entertaining.

I can easily RECOMMEND this game even at full price since it’s only $14.99 or your regional equivalent. With simple graphics, this game is not system requirement heavy and can easily run even on netbook computers making this a perfect game when you're on vacation, working, passing the time, or in any other situation where you are not with your main gaming system.

13795869.review: This is an amazingly well-done tower defense game. It doesn't come with too many bells and whistles, but the gameplay is better than most other examples of the genre. I am looking forward to the sequel (and the HD remake, which will be a free upgrade to this version.)

13788694.review:
É um Tower Defense bem diferente, com elementos e RPG e investimento em história.

GAMEPLAY: Ao longo da aventura você conhece outros personagens que usa como "torres". Com as torres, você deve impedir que os inimigos avancem até a protagonista (que fica estática), e lhe causem dano. São seis classes de personagens, com características próprias. Cada classe tem um personagem principal, que aparecerá nas cutscenes, mas é possível recrutar mais personagens genéricos, totalizando seis torres de cada classe. É possível vendar as torres ou realocá-las, bem como fazer upgrade conforme se ganha recursos matando os inimigos. O número de torres que você pode usar em cada fase é determinado por quantas você conseguiu via história ou comprando. Ao concluir uma fase, ganha-se experiência para sua personagem principal e para os demais, e com isso pontos que podem ser distribuídos em uma árvore de talentos, sendo que habilidades mais avançadas requerem pontos nas anteriores. Durante as fases, é necessário fazer upgrade das torres para ter acesso às habilidades mais avançadas, compradas na árvore de talentos. No caso da personagem principal, pontos são distribuídos em magias, adquiridos conforme a história progride, e que podem ser usadas durante a fase, como raios que destroem inimigos, aumentar a velocidade de ataques das "torres" ou curá-las (alguns inimigos causam dano a elas). Também se pode equipar itens na protagonista e nas torres, que aumentam suas estatísticas ou dão habilidades especiais passivas. Esses itens podem ser comprados com recursos do jogo ou adquiridos em fases. Não é possível fazer maze nesse jogo, isto é, o percurso dos inimigos e pré-definido e não é possível inserir as torres em qualquer lugar. Você pode jogar as fases em quatro níveis de dificuldade, que dão de uma a quatro estrelas, sendo que os mais difíceis dão mais experiência e melhores itens, mas somente completando os níveis mais fáceis é que a história avança. É possível revisitar as fases posteriormente para tentar bater os níveis mais difíceis de dificuldade e ganhar seus bônus e estrelas. Conforme se ganha mais estrelas, desbloqueia-se algumas “fases-desafio”, que dão itens poderosos.

HISTÓRIA: A história é legal, mas também não é espetacular. Achei interessante como justificaram personagens de fantasia batalhando com monstros em formato de TD. Tem humor e personagens legais, mas às vezes o humor é forçado. Eu gosto de games com história, mas acho que exageraram ao colocar diálogos sempre antes e depois de todas as batalhas (dá para pular as cenas). Os personagens são diferentes um do outro e têm seu charme. Convenhamos que história em jogo de TD é um bônus, apesar de que a história saiu-se melhor do que eu esperava . Tem dois finais diferentes, baseados em uma escolha que se faz próximo do fim do jogo.

REJOGABILIDADE: Após terminar o jogo, é possível continuar pelo mapa batendo as fases nos níveis mais difíceis. Depois pode-se exportar os personagens para o New Game +, onde algumas coisas mudam. No NG+ a dificuldade aumenta, os itens vendidos são mais poderosos e é possível fazer upgrade em itens únicos adquiridos na campanha. Esses upgrades não são feitos com dinheiro, mas sim trocando itens adquiridos ao finalizar as fases, sendo que alguns só podem ser conseguidos batendo os níveis mais difíceis. Uma coisa legal do NG+ é que tem side quests, com desdobramentos da história, onde somente se pode usar alguns personagens pré-definidos, e conseguir bons itens. Algumas conquistas são difíceis de conseguir, e podem deixar o jogador entretido até o NG++. Há conquistas de terminar os game (sem comprar torres genéricas, o que acarretaria em finalizar o game no NG, NG+ e NG++ novamente. Digo isso porque também há conquistas de conseguir todas as estrelas, e fazer isso sem os genéricos é bem complicado (acho que impossível).

PREÇO: comprei o game de promoção. Gostei dele e recomendo, mas não pagaria o preço total.

13630555.review:
흔한 타워디펜스에 RPG요소를 넣어 차별화를 이룬 작품. 다른 타워디펜스처럼 한정된 자원으로 맵을 클리어하는건 똑같지만, 이미 클리어한 맵을 다시 플레이하여 돈과 경험치를 벌어 다음맵에서 사용할 수 있는 자원의 양을 늘릴 수 있다는게 특징이다. 덕분에 타워디펜스가 탑에서 망보는 게임인줄 아는 장르 초보자라도 시간만 들이면 얼마든지 엔딩을 볼 수 있도록 설계되어 있는 게임 디자인이 장점. 단 기본 난이도가 그리 높은 게임은 아니라서 장르에 익숙한 사람은 좀 난이도를 높여서 플레이해야 유닛 배치에 머리를 굴리는 재미가 살아난다.

스토리는 산채로 죽음의 계곡에 버려진 아무 힘없는 도서관 사서 아가씨의 운명과 그 막막한 종말적 세계관이 흥미로우며, 엔딩까지 진행하면 애매함 없이 기승전결이 깔끔하게 군더더기 없이 끝나고, 엔딩 이후 데이터를 그대로 이어 더 강해진 적과 처음부터 다시 싸워볼 수 있는등 파고들 요소도 있다.  

캐릭터 디자인이 멋진 게임이 아니면 안한다거나(상점 페이지의 타이틀 그림에 그려진 캐릭터와 실제 게임상에서 나오는 캐릭터 묘사가 너무 틀리다), 2D 레트로 그래픽은 도저히 참을 수 없다는 사람을 제외하고, 초보자부터 타워디펜스 팬까지 만족할만한 게임이다. 추천!

Overall, did you find this while it had a 5 dollar price tag like I did? Buy it. It's fun up until the grinding hits. Did you find this game as it's full, overblown 15 dollar price tag? Avoid it completely.

13069125.review:
Next to the Gemcraft series, this is the best tower defence I've played in a while. And, next to Kingdom Hearts, it's the best RPG I've played in a while. It's original in its design and concept, this cross of a more niche genre with a very large one, whilest still being familiar enough in its portrayal to be easily understood.

To put it more bluntly, the only thing that's new and original about this game is the cross between tower defence and RPG, and ONLY tower defence and RPG. It doesn't throw in unseen mechanics, or third person action gameplay, or any of that. It's just tower defence and RPG.

And it's wonderful because of it.

It's the first game I'll be 100% completing on Steam. I recommend this game wholeheartedly. It does a damned good job on just about all fronts.

13062278.review:
*Updated* English translation incoming soon...

Définitivement : Oui

Un vrai Tower Defender version Old School (en 2D isométrique), comme on aimerait en voir plus souvent... Les graphismes sont vieillots, et font très console pixelisée (pas de mode plein écran ?), mais c'est ce qui fait tout son charme, un vrai jeu "Effet Vintage", un peu comme Final Fantaisy Tactis, mais en moins Tactical RPG peut-être , avec un gameplay assez rétro. L'histoire et la trame narrative sont assez intéressants pour être signalés, et se déroulent comme un film d'animation en théâtre d'ombres, scènes par scènes, avec dialogues et expressions des protagonistes, de façon assez soignés, au point qu'il est difficile de dire ce qui fait son attrait, pourtant bien présent, et ce malgré une histoire en anglais uniquement (pour ma part) qui ne pose pas vraiment de difficultés. Un défi technique relevé avec brio et peu de moyens, un retour aux sources du genre qui fait du bien et à contre-courant du phénomène de mode des pseudo-A-Rts actuels parfois vite lassants. Une démo est disponible sur le site éditeur pour vous faire une idée avant de l'adopter si  l'intérêt vous gagne. Seuls reproches, le jeu est en anglais seulement, la réalisation n'est pas révolutionnaire en soi, même si l'idée est bonne, il peut peut-être devenir répétitif à la longue, pas d'éditeur de maps non plus, ce qu aurait été une bonne et généreuse idée de la part de l'éditeur, dommage. Support japonais et coréen disponible.

le prix est juste pour la performance proposée, les éléments rpg ajoutent en plus à l'intéret, il contient pas mal d'options (on peut renommer les personnages en cours de route), plusieurs niveaux de difficultés en jeu, une compatibilité avec une option de Mods bienvenue qui aide à casser un peu la répétition qui pourrait être présente au fur et à mesure de l'avancement dans le jeu. Si par contre vous vous êtes lassé rapidement sur Plants vs Zombies, la durée de vie peut vite chuter, car il me semble qu'il vaut mieux aimer le genre pour s'en satisfaire sur la durée...:


Les + :                                                                                  

■ Histoire  intéressante et humoristique
personnages attachants (le barbare cinglé y joue pour beaucoup),
même si elle ne sert que d'excuse pour amener au Tower Defense.

■  Réalisation simple et efficace, interface intuitive et bien pensée, 
on est en face d'un vrai Tower Defense pour tous (HCG et Casu). L'idée d'avoir choisi les compagnons comme des tourelles upgradables par le côté Rpg, l'arbre des talents différents pour les classes, même s'il reste simpliste. Les options à foisons (paramétrage clavier, difficulté en jeu, pause, vitesse), les différents types d'ennemis, les armes uniques.

■ Une durée de vie moyenne de 40h environ, 15-20 h pour les HCG rushers,
un mode uniquement solo, bienvenue (j' abhorre le coopératif en DotA).
Mais je suis à 230h et  l'intérêt ne chute pas, un record pour ce type de jeu,
On aime le recommencer, attention jeu culte en vue d'ici quelques temps...  =====(╯^□^)╯

Les  -  :

■ Le côté Rpg un peu mis de côtés, étant uniquement concentré sur l'achat d'armes/armures, même si un arbre de talent rattrape le coup. On peut difficilement demander plus vu le support mais les choix tactiques sont restreints et s'en ressentent, la linéarité à la Mario Bros, bien que différents choix soient présents.

■ Il aurait mérité mieux graphiquement parlant, le manque d'objets, une répétitivité perceptible sur le long terme une fois l'histoire terminée, un éditeur de niveaux cruellement absent, pas de mode multi-joueurs ou de partage de cartes qui font vivre la communauté des likers du Dota/Dott-type. La perte de sauvegardes récurrentes qu'on ne peut plus importer suite à mise à jour, mais les problèmes tendent à s'estomper...

Visiblement cependant les développeurs s'attaques aux problèmes rencontrés, on les en remercie, le jeu en vaut vraiment la peine...


Note finale : 8.9/10   (coup de coeur, gameplay intéressant, conception soignée, et évolution pour rendre le jeux plus abordable et corriger ses défauts, un très bonne idée de la part des Devs !!!).
La note prend en compte le fait que le jeu  est estampillé "indépendant".

Une copie de jeu qu'on aimerais avoir plus souvent dans sa bibliothèque numériques, et qu'on apprécie de payer pour AUTANT DE QUALITE...Les devs ne laissent pas tomber les clients, 
et les mises à jours et correctifs suivent (plus de problèmes de stabilité sur le jeu).
Certaines Multinationales du diverstissement numérique devraient prendre exemple sur ces gens (Take my Money, I Enjoy your Work !), Bravo à eux, et merci pour la traduction dans la langue de Molière. 

DQ II: Mists of Ruins, La suite est en cours de dev, Wait & See : 
http://www.defendersquest.com/2/

12941287.review:
Well, reviewing a title that is available for 2 years now seems useless, yet i'll do it anyway :-)

Judging by the graphics i wonder why i even bought it. Maybe because i like Tower-Defense-Games.
But i was suprised with this cute little quillet.

What exactly is it?
It's a TD-Game without towers. But with people. Typical RPG-People like berzerkers, mages, healers and rangers and...
And you'll keep your "Towers" throughout the game and they'll receive XP and level-up. You can even color them and give them names.
You move through a story with cutscenes, but mainly you'll fight waves of enemies with your party.

[u]The good:[/u]
[list]
[*] Borderless fullscreen AKA non-exclusive Fullscreen. Yay. Scaled to your resolution OR changed resolution. Nifty!
[*] Don't like the speed of advancement? Change XP/monetary reward to 300%! Or 50%.
[*] Leveling and outfitting your "towers" is a nice approach. You'll have veterans and noobs to place on each map.
[*] Speed adjustment from 0x (pause) to 4x. Nice. Pausable at all times. No pressure there.
[*] You can adjust your partymembers fighting tactics and even make them persistant (attack which target first, use high power abilities on lower foes etc.)
[*] Beside your party you'll have your main hero that has misc. spells at her disposal.
[*] TD-like you can play each map in different difficulties with proportional rewards. It pays to replay an older mission on EXPERT!
[*] The way they make you "like" their facebook/twitter-page was really cute. I almost felt bad NOT to click :-)
[*] Workshop! For those extra hours to waste
[*] It has a real story with cute cutscenes. I admit to have skipped much of it, but for some it may add immersion.
[/list]

[u]The bad:[/u]
[list]
[*] For some, it may possibly lack depth of strategy/difficulty. It looks more like a "casual" tower-defense.
[*] Ok, to be nit-picky: The skills you're able to choose are too few. No big descisions to make, you're getting them
all more or less anyway.
[/list]

[b]TL;DR:[/b]
Bought "Defenders of time" at the same time and it seemed much more promising. Oh boy was i wrong.
Kicked "DoT" off of my HD after 2 minutes and played this one for hours. Graphics is not everything.
This is a fun and refreshing towerdefense-game where you keep your "towers" and level them up. Also you'll
try to outfit them with better weapons and armor. I surely had my fun. Would be even worth fullprice!

12938600.review:
Short: [9/10] Awesome and challenging Tower Defense x RPG mix with 30+ hours of gameplay. Only a few gripes make this game short of perfect.

Long: "Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten" is a Tower Defense game in which you fight hordes of enemies by using different classes and spells. The classes (of which there are 6) all differ in playstyle and give the game its RPG elements via XP gains, talent trees and weapon/armor aquisition. Even though the game looks simple, it offers a very deep combat and leveling system which will have to be adjusted multiple times in order to beat certain levels. Examples include making your archers target fastest enemies first, putting the stun sword in the hands of your knight, or making sure your ice skills don't get cancelled by your burn ones.  The story itself is amusing as well and gave me a few chuckles along the way. New Game+, 3 star rating per level, and challenges such as endless mode only extend the life of this game and make you want to play more. 

There are however, a few issues. Some, like the "Undo" button, which removes ALL the points you just put into your character's skill tree instead of just the last one, should be renamed "Restart" because that's what it actually does. This gets very annoying when respeccing a character with 60 points in New Game+. However, the "Undo" button is not game breaking so it doesn't change my rating of the game. What does, however, is the terrible frame drop encountered during big fights. Even though I have a very powerful rig, it has caused the game to crash several times (once while on 95th wave of endless when attempting 100 wave achievement!). Another is the poor visual of the cursor, which when coupled with the fact the frame rates drop, makes it impossible to see. This has caused me to lose a few games or constantly pause to execute commands.

But the few imperfections get dwarfed by the fact this is a great game, and had me coming back for that "JUST ONE MORE ROUND" feel. The devs are actually pretty cool/active as well and respond quite frequently in the forums. Don't miss this game, it is very much worth it!   [9/10]

12934242.review:
At first glance, this is a decent TD.

Each map has dificulty scaling from brain-dead-easy to challenging-enough-to-keep-you-on-your-toes all the way to so-hard-you-will-have-to-come-back-once-you-have-leveled-up-more.

The story is more engaging than many RPGs and shows great humor.

The achievements are a decent mix of "collect as you go" and "work hard to get this".

The upgrading and customization of your "towers" adds a lot of strategic depth which is only hightened by the weapons and armor you buy/upgrade.

And then you finish the game and find out that there are achievements to play with just the story dependant heroes (Hero Mode). And the challenge increases by a factor of 7.

And then you finish the game doing Hero Mode and find out about New Game +

That's where the game really shines. Because not only is there a whole lot more story, greater challenge in all the previous maps, more achievements AND extra maps... there is also Hero Mode +

And then there are all the bonus maps...

The game is bursting with content, oozing challenge out of every pixel and spurting out humor.

No. Don't wait for a sale. This is not a game you MIGHT want, it is a game you can't NOT have.

PS: There is also a sequel coming. Oh, and a free HD version for everyone who has the game.

These are the kinds of devs you support. Do it.

12906615.review:
An enjoyable tower defense game with RPG elements.  (Characters level up and have skill trees that carry over, although you can reassign points for a fee.) 

The need to "gold star" everything keeps this game replayable for quite a long time, and there's a challenge to complete the game in its hard mode without the many generic units you can hire, making the game extremely difficult at times. (In fact, functionally impossible at the hardest versions of some levels. Fortunately, you don't need 100% completion for those.) 

The game is also pausable, for those who find some tower defense games too frantic to enjoy.  There are some points where you really need to set the game to slow-mo and pump out the spells you get as their cooldowns time out just to cling to life for another wave, though.  

It can, however, chug when you get to very high levels, and have INSANE numbers of effects going on at once.  I've also had it crash from a memory overflow from having too many sprites on the field in one of the "endless" maps where they just send infinite units your way.  

Beyond that one flaw, (which you can avoid by just not trying to play the endless mode truly endlessly,) it's a great game.  I highly recommend.

PLUSY:

- zachęca do ponownego przechodzenia już odwiedzonych mapek, za co dostaje się punkty doświadczenia, kaskę i unikalne przedmioty (tzn. oczywiście jeśli się uda zwyciężyć)

12747860.review:
Bought this on a whim, wasn't expecting much, to be honest. But I do love tower defense, and it runs on linux, so I went ahead with the purchase. Very impressed, this game is actually very excellent and has an old-school SNES feel with modern tower defense. I've been playing it over more publicly accredited games (it actually has pulled me away from DOTA 2), so decided that a positive review would help out a bit because I feel very strongly about how this hidden gem wasted an entire Sunday for me, and I'm still not done beating it 100%. I rarely care about beating games 100%, I think the last time I did it was for a little-known title called Goldeneye in the 90's.


Excellent concept: merges RPG with tower defense. That's all there is to say, really. Units seem to be all useful, but as with ANY old-school RPG combat it can get super easy or impossible depending on whether or not you grind. Regardless on that, there are technically four difficulties (if you count casual) that change each battle's difficulty hugely. Story is alright -- the humor isn't my cup of tea, but then again, I have a picture of the dude from The Human Centipede 2 as my steam picture, so I just gotta say it's a me thing.

Looks like they're making a sequel. Good, I'll be sure to buy it.



If you're on linux and can't figure out why the game doesn't start without an error message, you need Adobe AIR. Their website is quite good on showing you how to get it running. A minor setback, I'm sure with licensing reasons Steam can't install it as a dependency. However, it almost made me assume the game was poorly ported and bugged (like Dead Island which doesn't boot on linux for some and nobody knows why, LOL). 

The devs obviously cared a lot about this game: it's not junk meant to be sold to chumps where they buy it on sale, play for 15 minutes, then never open it up again. The writing is good -- not perfect, but meant to be (ugh) all ages. It's not a super deep story, though I feel with more practice they could pull it off if they feel it wouldn't detract from the gameplay in the sequel.

I would advise the devs to look at their website and tone down on the humor -- had my bored, cynical ass seen it without playing the game I would've assumed this game would be shit. 

The art isn't AAA title, but as an indie game, what the fuck do you expect? The battles are mid 90's SNES quality (though better than Breath of Fire II, worse than FF6) and the cutscenes are adobe flash-esque and very similar to the indie game Sequence (minus the voice acting, plus more character gestures).

If the game was a teensy little longer and made for the SNES, with a little more "professionalism" mixed in, it would've been a classic everyone would've known about. 

I came in expecting shit and found a gem I hadn't heard about before. I'm old, drunk, and cranky, and this stole an entire day from me and perhaps longer. Def buy @ $10, even $15. It's about on par with binding of isaac.

12658258.review:
Il mio primo incontro con Defender's Quest è avvenuto più di due anni fa, quando il titolo saltò fuori bazzicando fra le pagine dei giochi consigliati su Kongregate: affamato di tower defense com'ero, soprattutto grazie alla formula "mordi e fuggi" a livelli circoscritti adottata dalla maggioranza degli esponenti della categoria via browser, rimasi subito colpito da quello che prometteva di essere un ottimo connubio tra RPG e strategico, con "torri" rappresentate da personaggi veri e propri in grado di guadagnare livelli, acquisire equipaggiamento più potente ed affinare le proprie capacità.

Quando poi, in seguito, mi è capitata l'occasione di mettere le mani sulla versione completa (quella su Kongregate include soltanto i primi due atti e riesce appena a scalfirne la profondità), non mi sono lasciato scappare l'occasione di aggiungerla alla mia libreria Steam ed ho potuto quindi affondare i denti nella succulenta pietanza servita dalla Level Up Labs.

Tanto per proseguire con i paragoni culinari, devo ammettere che la presentazione del piatto non fa gridare al miracolo, anzi è al massimo funzionale: lo stile grafico a 8/16-bit adottato non è certo una gioia per gli occhi e, benché i nostri pixellosi combattenti possiedano una discreta gamma di animazioni e siano disegnati, durante le scene di intermezzo, in maniera assai più dettagliata, la qualità generale si attesta su una fascia medio-bassa anche per gli standard di un qualsiasi browser game. Colpa perlopiù del motore grafico (Flixel, una libreria per Flash pensata per giochi dal look retrò e visivamente non troppo impegnativi), che non ha permesso al team condotto da Lars Doucet di esprimersi come avrebbero dovuto. Una lancia va spezzata in favore della colonna sonora, realizzata dal talentuoso musicista australiano Kevin Penkin, le cui melodie dal sapore epico quasi contrastano con l'aspetto altrimenti semplicistico di Defender's Quest.

Il gioco si apre su uno scenario desolato: una giovane di nome Azra cade preda della pestilenza che sta decimando il Regno di Ash e, senza troppe cerimonie, viene scaraventata nel Fosso, un luogo remoto in cui quanti hanno contratto il morbo vengono abbandonati nel tentativo di arginare il contagio. Ciò che la attende in questa necropoli a cielo aperto è forse ancor peggio della morte, poiché scoprirà che al suo interno si aggirano dei pericolosi Revenant, vittime della piaga risorte ad una famelica non-vita e guidate dalle parole arcane di una misteriosa figura dorata. Ma non tutto il male viene per nuocere: Azra è infatti la depositaria di un potere ancestrale che le permette di raggiungere il Mondo di Mezzo, una dimensione fra la vita e la morte in cui è consentito vedere e interagire con l'essenza spirituale di ogni creatura. Grazie al fortuito incontro con Slak, un berserker vagabondo, la ragazza avrà così modo di affrontare e sconfiggere i Revenant, tanto invincibili nel mondo reale quanto vulnerabili in quello spirituale. Sarà dunque l'inizio di un lungo viaggio che porterà l'improbabile coppia e gli altri sopravvissuti che incontreranno a scoprire la vera natura del Fosso, le origini dell'epidemia e un male millenario che minaccia di annientare ogni cosa.

Una volta iniziata una battaglia, ritroveremo Azra in un punto predefinito della mappa sul quale convergeranno le unità nemiche, il cui scopo è quello di raggiungere la povera medium e azzerare la sua barra di HP. Per difenderci, potremo selezionare diverse unità da schierare tramite mouse o scorciatoie via tastiera, utili anche per gestire gli incantesimi che apprenderemo nel corso del tempo. L'energia psichica, o PSI, della protagonista è l'unico limite imposto al numero di personaggi e di stregonerie invocabili, ma ogni nemico ucciso ne rilascerà un certo quantitativo che andrà a rimpinguare le nostre scorte. Ciò che balza subito agli occhi è la notevole quantità di impostazioni strategiche con cui si possono configurare i difensori, anche dopo averli posizionati sulla mappa: oltre ad aumentare fino a cinque volte la potenza dei personaggi, è anche possibile personalizzare le loro modalità di attacco, dal tipo di nemico sul quale concentrarsi al modo di utilizzo delle capacità speciali, a loro volta attivabili e disattivabili a piacere.

Al termine del combattimento si aprirà la schermata di riepilogo del gruppo di avventurieri, mediante la quale abbiamo l'opportunità di esaminare il loro livello, modificarne l'equipaggiamento e assegnare punti in una classica struttura progressiva ad albero. E' qui che le influenze RPG si fanno sentire con prepotenza: i personaggi infatti guadagnano esperienza, livelli e abilità alla stregua di un qualsiasi gioco di ruolo. Il level cap è fissato a 60, insufficiente per massimizzare ogni singolo privilegio di classe, ma possiamo sempre redistribuire i punti previo un piccolo pagamento in denaro, oppure reclutare unità supplementari da evolvere in maniera differente. Il denaro o, meglio, gli scarti accumulati completando gli scontri (che rappresentano la valuta in vigore nel Fosso) serviranno anche per acquistare armi e armature più efficaci.

Ciascuna mappa presenta quattro livelli di difficoltà, che forniscono ricompense in proporzione sempre maggiori, nonché stelle che valutano la nostra prestazione. Azra non può impiegare alcun oggetto per difendersi da sola, ma ha invece la possibilità di sfruttare la potenza di alcuni tomi magici con effetti variabili, dal potenziamento degli incantesimi conosciuti ad una serie di penalità applicabili agli attaccanti. I libri si ottengono completando le sfide speciali, mappe particolari che vengono sbloccate soltanto dopo aver ottenuto un certo numero di stelle.

Menzione speciale per la sceneggiatura e la caratterizzazione dei personaggi, con i toni spesso umoristici dei loro variopinti battibecchi che fanno da contraltare perfetto al pathos e alla drammaticità della prima. Alla Level Up Labs sanno perfettamente come scrivere un racconto e renderlo coinvolgente, lezione che molti degli sviluppatori più blasonati dovrebbero prendere ad esempio.

Dunque, la promessa citata all'inizio è stata mantenuta? La risposta non può che essere affermativa e, se tutto ciò non bastasse, dopo la conclusione delle peripezie di Azra è presente anche una modalità New Game+, che include una moltitudine di subquest e di biforcazioni della storia principale, arricchita inoltre da un elemento supplementare: il diario della protagonista, sul quale vengono annotati molti approfondimenti legati all'ambientazione e alla mitologia del mondo, alcune brillanti considerazioni sui suoi compagni di viaggio... e brevi appunti degli stessi su di lei, che pare non riesca a nascondere il prezioso registro tanto bene quanto dovrebbe. Completano il tutto una nuova serie di sfide speciali e un mercante in grado di migliorare gli oggetti rari recuperati nella partita precedente.

Unica nota negativa di un prodotto così ben confezionato è il bisogno eccessivo di grinding per sviluppare al meglio i nostri eroi: sebbene l'avventura (sia base che New Game+) sia completabile seguendo la normale progressione della storia, i nemici dell'ultima fase di gioco sono semplicemente troppi e troppo forti ai livelli più alti. E' vero, si tratta di un elemento extra che non inficia il valore del titolo in alcun modo, ma avrei gradito un maggiore bilanciamento della sfida piuttosto che una dilatazione esponenziale delle stat dei mostri, che dunque necessitano di unità altrettanto "mostruose" per essere sconfitti.

Comparto grafico a parte, Defender's Quest sale di diritto in cima alla classifica dei migliori tower defense in circolazione: accattivante, ben scritto e con una pletora di contenuti da scoprire, se amate il genere non riuscirete a staccarvene con facilità.

12539901.review:
Defender's Quest (DQ) is a tower defense meets RPG hybrid. You go around with your ragtag bunch of misfit heroes, trying to save your skin and possibly the world. As you make your way, battle after battle, through hordes of zombies... I mean, Revenants, everyone's skills improve, making them harder, better, faster, stronger at slicing-and-dicing more undead meat.

Is that all? No. DQ has a delicious old-school feel, partly thanks to the pixellated sprites, partly because of the great soundtrack which will make you think of the glorious days of SNES JRPGs. It also has some notably well-written dialogue, snappy and fun (though let's face it, the art in those scenes leaves something to be desired...). DQ also has lots of challenges for you. Playing levels at regular difficulty is getting too easy? No problem, you can replay them at Advanced or Extreme to get bonuses and goodies. Finished the game? No problem, there's a New Game+ with more difficulties awaiting for you. The learning curve is extremely well-balanced and I especially enjoyed being able to complete the main story without ever getting really stuck but with a very real sense of increased hardship towards the end (the last two-three battles, especially, I barely managed to power through).

It's definitely a very good game, especially if you like tower defense. Get it.

EDIT: the developers released a "DX" patch for this game adding new content, remaking the engine with HaxeFlixel and redrawing the art to be better - thus the only complaint I could ever muster about this game has now gone. This is nothing short of a masterpiece, and quite possibly the best tower defense game you'll find on Steam. Search no more.

12470907.review:
Aviso, se você não quiser ficar viciado em um jogo afaste-se deste. Defender's Quest é muito bom, trata-se de um tower defense com elementos de RPG. Ao invés de torres você utiliza personagens (magos, cavaleiros, arqueiros) que são invocados por uma mulher que você deve proteger.

O diferencial deste jogo que o torna bastante interessante é o sistema de níveis e atributos que ele pega emprestado dos RPGs. A cada batalha seus guerreiros ganham experiência e níveis além e você recebe dinheiro para comprar novos equipamentos para eles.

O jogo em sí é bem extenso até. Cada estágio possui várias dificuldades diferentes desde casual à expert. Depois de zerar o jogo normal você destrava o modo plus que além de ter uma dificuldade consideravelmente mais elevada possui novos equipamentos e algumas side quests.

Meus únicos problemas com esse jogo são técnicos. Ele não possui opção de resolução 1080p então não fica bem em fullscreen no meu PC. Além disso não possui recurso de salvar em núvem na steam, você precisa exportar o save com uma ferramenta dentro do jogo para continuar em outro computador. O estranho é que existe a opção de utilizar a núvem dentro do jogo porém ao habilitá-la não muda nada. Talvez eles a implementem depois. 

Eu tive a sorte de comprar esse jogo em um bundle porque ele não possui um visual muito chamativo. Não se destaca muito entre tantos jogos tower defense pelo visual e deve passar batido por muitos jogadores mas com certeza vale a pena jogá-lo. 8/10

12453747.review:
[b][UPDATE: Less-amateur art, less-trash performance... still just a clicker.][/b]

Enjoyable at first, in the end, only tedious. No real challenge... or even tower defense.

Where most tower defense makes you think about how best to place towers and what to upgrade when, this game is completely stripped of thought. You learn the optimal locations for each "tower" type early on, and, as evidenced by "hero mode", the levels are almost all designed with a choke or two that takes full advantage of a single group's optimal patterns, so most levels play like this:

1. Plug one, rarely two, "tower" groups into obvious optimal [strike]sockets[/strike] locations
 OPTIONAL: Spam archers
2. Upgrade (Mostly whenever, you'll have plenty of 'power'.)
3. WIN

The "RPG" side certainly gives math nerds something to obsess over, but it's similarly simplistic:

1. Level up!
2. Damage +1
 OPTIONAL: Reset points at any time, because you somehow screwed that up

That's it. You want your healers to heal, of course, (skip Holy Light completely) and to take advantage of each "tower's" secondary effects, (armor break, chill, bleed, range, light/blind, devour) but for the most part, you'll just have to decide which usually low-end skill or two to neglect. Usually the lowest. You can safely ignore most defensive skills. (The actual numbers are utterly pointless because adequate info to calculate DPS and some secondary interactions aren't provided, and you learn how effective everything is by "feel"/sight same as any TD game anyways... but don't tell the math nerds!)

And that's the game for you. The art is bland, the story is absurd, but occaisionally amusing. Nothing to see here. While not a "worst game ever", if you're out for an actually good tower defense/game, look elsewhere. You might enjoy this if you're a math nerd, part of the Number Enlargement crowd, or just want something easy and amusing to click on and only plan to throw a few hours away with it anyways. Don't expect the game to get better as it goes on, it just doesn't. It never could, because it's fundamentally flawed.

[b][FOR OLD VERSION:][/b] Unfortunately, I have to add: [b]system requirements are a trollishly bad joke.[/b] The game runs in Flash/AIR and suffers from the usual "looks like an old DOS machine could run it/practically requires a super-computer" issues. On a less powerful CPU, it may take twice as long to get the same amount done, and you will lose input control if you button-mash the one spell you'll want to button mash. But don't worry, you'll only notice it at critical moments, and only cause you to lose your "perfect" completion on a couple 45 minute boss battles... before you learn. Or your RSI flares up.

12372507.review:
В последние годы крупные студии все чаще стали уходить в коммерцию и клепать однотипные игрушки в которых на высоте лишь графика, но вот души в этих проектах нет. Впору было подумать что игровая индустрия плавно скатывается в болото застоя и самоповторов, но на помощь пришли независимые разработчики у которых не было должного бюджета, но зато у них были оригинальные идеи, которые они не преминули воплотить в жизнь и «Defender's Quest» является ярким тому примером.

Казалось бы, перед почтенной публикой предстает стандартный tower-defense, коих в последнее время появилось как грязи. Ну да, есть возможность прокачивать свои башни (героев), но так и в этом нет ничего нового. Так в чем же дело? А все дело в том, что разработчики игры ставили перед собой задачу сделать нечто большее чем игрушку за которой можно провести пару часов, а затем о ней благополучно забыть. Разработчики добавили в игру пусть и простенький, а все же сюжет, что повествует об отчаявшемся человеке, что ради защиты родного мира решил пойти по кривой дорожке и вступить на путь тьмы. О да, благими намереньями вытоптана дорога в ад. Каждой из башен (героев) был добавлен характер и мотивы и пусть они достаточно шаблонны, но все равно приятно, что создатели позаботились и об этом. Ну, а раз есть история и герои, то не лишнем был бы и юмор. Простой и ни к чему не обязывающий, этакий далекий гость из девяностых, благо ни следа пошлости или шуток ниже пояса тут нет, что безусловно радует. Добавим сюда то что игра подстегивает к тому, чтобы ее проходили снова и снова благодаря новым квестам и испытаниям, что открываются после того, как игра будет пройдена в первый раз и мы получим нечто большее чем стандартный tower-defense. Мы получим игру в которую вкладывали душу.

7 из 10 revenant’ов

12368963.review:
A straight and forward tower defense game. If you like the genre, I very very highly recommend this game. If you don't like the genre, I doubt any game would be able to change your mind, and suggest that you carry on.

Defender's Quest managed to impress me by literally exceeding the average in every way I can think of.

+ Not a rehash of another tower defense game - it didn't really do anything extraordinary within the genre, yet I can't think of a single game I'd call it similar to.
+ Holy shit, the story is actually good, the characters fun, and the funny parts actually funny.
+ There is no ultimate strategy that works for the game (build/upgrade order, etc). Each map forces a new strategy based on the availability of locations to place your characters, and enemy monster types.
+ There are dozens of maps, with 4 different difficulty settings, all of which have a New Game+ version which play differently. This game will take many dozens of hours to complete.
+ The music is good. Nothing spectacular, but for the genre and the pricetag, exceeds standards.
+ Lots of things to play with in the options menu.
+ Family friendly - I would see absolutely no problem in an 8 year old playing this game.

非常にカジュアルなタワーディフェンスRPG.　日本語完全対応.
タワーディフェンスとしてはオーソドックスな作りながら、RPG要素を取り入れることで独自の味付けやとっつきやすさを盛り込むことに成功した作品です.

このゲームにおけるRPG要素はレベル上げ、スキルツリー、装備品収集など.　バランスの取り方はJRPGライクで、勝てないバトルが出てきたらレベリングを行うことで突破できるケースが大半とやや大味.　レべリングもオプションで報酬量3倍＆ペナルティなしにでき実績にも影響しないので作業の軽減が可能だったりと至れり尽くせり.
ゆえにヌルイ印象はぬぐえないのですが、途中から難易度が急上昇して行き詰まりそのまま積んでしまうTDが多い中で最後までサクサク遊べるのはTD入門者用には最適かと思われます.
TDとしては敵の侵攻ルートがほぼ固定で、迷路を構築する煩わしさがありません.　配置したユニットをランクアップさせる要素も他TDではいまいち効果が実感しづらかったりするのですが、本作ではスキルシステムのおかげで1ランクブーストする度に目に見えてメリットが実感できるのは長所.

淡々としたゲームが多いTDの中ではストーリー性やキャラクター性も高めで、話自体は単純で短いものですが個性的で愛嬌あるキャラクターのおかげで最後までモチベを崩さず楽しくプレイすることができました.
2周目以降は難易度も上がり、追加ステージやチャレンジ要素もあるので徐々にステップアップしていく遊び方も可能です.

12254068.review:
Defender's Quest is a case study in covering your weaknesses and emphasizing your strengths. Shoddy writing? A beautiful "skip" button in every cutscene and dialogue can be turned off. Difficulty? If you hit a brick wall in story mode you can go back and do slightly harder versions of prior maps to level up. Tower diversity? Unique equipment means your second Berserker probably won't be as good as your first, so it's harder to spam one tower. The slog of New Game+ not going fast enough? Triple experience is an option in the menus. All this lets you focus on the core tower defense game, which is best played at 4X speed.

Plenty of weaknesses can't be worked around, though. Workshop mods are few in number, and the first one I tried locked up the game in the first level. Character level is too huge a factor in whether you pass a level or not, meaning few maps feel appropriately scaled to your level at any given time. The game has a fixed resolution, even in fullscreen, and in fullscreen Steam notifications will leave artifacts on the screen. It's a little too easy to fall into a "two of each" mentality, setting up two identical sets of towers on the two major paths of most maps, with the only major variance between maps being what towers you level up first. The tower "skill trees" don't contribute much especially for those towers that only have variants of "melee attack" or "shoot arrows". 

For all the weaknesses I've pointed out, there are few high points in the game. The boss fights are excellent, requiring you to balance "kill the boss faster" against "kill the creeps faster". Otherwise it's the usual tower-defense game of setting up your towers and watching them slaughter thousands of zombies. The game demands enough of your attention in boosting your towers etcetera that it's not a good "put something on in the background while you play" game, but isn't demanding enough to be a thoughtful or engaging experience.

All in all, it's hard to recommend Defender's Quest unless you're just dying for a tower defense game where you make a bunch of bars go up a la Progress Quest.

12157471.review: Defender's Quest is an extremely fun and addicting tower defense/RPG hybrid.  There are so many viable strategies for you to experiment with.  The way you can get your different characters to work with each other is very deep with different talent trees to choose from, weopons and armor to collect and level up, spells for your main character to choose from, and placement of your troops.   I found it very enjoyable and satisfying to beat both the normal game and the new game plus (hard mode) first in "hero" mode where you only use the characters introduced in the main story line and then go back to recruit extra troops to tackle some of the more advanced extreme difficulties.  There is an interesting storyline to follow.  The dialog between the characters has a sometimes wacky sense of humor that I really enjoyed, while the overall storyline was still serious.  I thought they struck a nice balance.  While the game may look simplistic in graphic design, the experience is anything but and I got my money's worth many times over.  Just a very fun game and well worth your time if you have even a passing interest in either RPG's or good tower defense games.  Greatly looking forward to the sequel that is in development!

11955443.review:
Après avoir terminé le jeu en normal, que dire de ce Defender's quest....qu'il s'agit d'un très bon tower Défense. Certe il ne révolutionne pas le genre et en reprend les principes du genre avec application et sérieux. Pourtant le titre se distingue par son coté RPG plutot bien vu. Ici pas question que vos persos repartent à zéro à chaque nouvelle mission. Mais, à la manière d'un tactique/RPG ils gagnerons des levels au fil de leur combat. Un arbre de compétance vous permet également des les rendre plus balèze, à vous de bien placer les points chèrement gagnés. 
Graphiquement le jeu se veut assez minimaliste mais plutot agréable et l'ambiance éroique fantazy facon old school  nous charme de suite.
Coté durée de vie, le titre est solide et vous tiendra longtemps éveillé, surtout si vous décidez de faire le jeu à 100 %, sans compter sur le New game +, bref il y a de quoi faire.
Voila un bilan plus que positif pour ce DQ recommandable et à recommander ^^

11669716.review:
Defender's Quest is a tower defense style game with RPG-based elements added in.  I liked it; overall, it's a quaint little game.  The characters are likable and the story (although not too original) is well paced and engaging enough.  There were a few times where the gameplay felt a little grindy to me (make sure you level up more than one priest, for example - I didn't and had to grind one up before I could proceed) but you can redo levels on harder difficulties for more experience and money or on easier difficulties to move the game along.

Eventually, I just started playing on easy to advance the story along, then I just quit playing altogether.  Although I didn't finish it I still liked the game and would recommend it to fans of TDs, especially if the added RPG elements interest you.  

I also liked how it asked you to like the author on Facebook or something to get a free item at the beginning.  I always give games that ask me to do this a resounding, "Hell No!" and when I did with Defender's Quest it gave me the items anyway, so I thought that was nice.

Nothing to write home about, but it wasn't a bad attempt.  You'll probably enjoy your time with this game.

11591004.review:
This is a very simple, but fairly expansive Tower Defense (TD) game. you can gear out and upgrade your units how you want, and they all even have little tech trees for their abilities, though honestly I didn't really feel like the points I allocated did much to make any of the skills much better, but it's always fun to have that stuff I guess.

The levels are different formations and the monsters spawn from different points at different times depending on the level and difficulty. You can't do any forced pathing or anything like in defense grid but you still want to place your units so that they are getting in as many hits as possible. You can also set units to specific targeting types, whether it's whatever enemy is closest to the end of the trail, the one with highest HP, lowest HP, etc...

All in all this is a good little TD, I wouldn't recommend buying it unless it's on sale for like 5-8 bucks though.

Otra de las cosas a notar es que el juego tiene una amplia configuración, con lo que puedes hacer que el juego sea un completo grinding (si es lo que te gusta), normality o dejarlo mas ligero para disfrutar mas el juego.

La musica aun que es poca cumple con su proposito asi como los efectos de sonido.
La historia esta presentada de una manera relajada, sin ser en lo absoluto profunda pero si entretenida.
Los graficos asemejan unjuego de la era del NintendoDS (sin ser esto algo malo) que cumplen su cometido.

Altamente recomendado si te gustan los juegos de Defenza de la Torre, si no, pasa de largo.
8.5/10

11384047.review:
This is a retro tower defense game. It is small in file size, but big in play! I like that I can easily run it in the background while I do other things on the computer.

The story progresses nicely. The characters are engaging, and I was never bored with the plot. You can complete the entire plot in a day even if you take your time. The graphics are in pixel style for the gameplay. The cut-scenes were artwork with text underneath. The art would move in response to the text moving, like reading an illustrated book. 

This game has nice replay value. Every site on the map has 3 levels, easy, normal, and advanced. To unlock everything, you must beat all three. There are a lot of achievements in this game, and some of them are quite difficult to get. A single level can be solved in many different ways. And, the whole game can be played in newgame+ mode, which makes beating it a second time a new challenge.

Once I finished the plot, I found that I don't like to play for hours on end. The game is relaxing for me. I take my time with the higher level achievements. It's a fun, simple game and I recommend it.

11368500.review:
Simple, inexpensive indie TD with a nice twist. Each "tower" is a character and levels, equips and spends skill points independently. The campaign has a nice length to it. I'm not finished, but I'm over 20 battles. Each battle also has multiple difficulties that give greater rewards, including unlocking bonus missions.

The native resolution is tiny, probably 800x600 if not 640x480 and there is no way to increase it in windowed mode that I can see. Also the generic characters you make have the potential to be clones of your main heroes, each class' talent tree provides customization but (at least at low levels) leaves little advantage to stray. It would be nice if each character could learn different active skills from their brethren that share a class.

There is a sequel in the works and I look forward to it. It would appear they are addressing my main issues and thensome.

Bottom line, I'm enjoying this title and while I'm a sale hound, if I had paid full-price I wouldn't have been disappointed. If you are not a huge TD fan, this may leave little to desire.

11344720.review:
I'm not convinced that RPG progression + tower defense is a very good model. Or at least it's too underdeveloped in Defender's Quest. There aren't nearly enough varieties in skill trees or enemies or items to justify the levelling and equipping. And while the levels are well designed, the balance isn't quite right and I ended up playing through most of the standard game on max fast forward (granted I was doing +300% hero mode, but large parts of the game seem pressuring to go hero mode).

That said, this game is absolutely adorable and totally worth it on a bad laptop. And so far in New Game+ everything's a lot better.

11305545.review: If you like tower defense games, this one is one of the best. The layout of the game makes it easy both mass up towers or to just play with only a few towers and still win the game. While there is no option to advance the different waves, the difficulty of levels often makes you want to find ways to stop new waves from spawning. The RPG elements included in this game do not take away alot from a traditional tower defense game, but actually add a bit more strategy elements into the game. Like most games based around a story line, replaying the game usually ends up with you skipping the story elements in the game (yes, there is a skip button!) but I would strongly suggest reading the game+ version of the story as there are more plot twists and interesting parts in that story line than the orginal story line. While the game might not be worth the 15 dollar price they are asking for, get it on sale and you will not stop playing it.

I don't know where I got this game from (Probably Humble bundle) and I can't remember how much I paid for it. I don't really like Tower Defense games very much but I can recommend Defender's Quest. Kind of a silly name. Very amatuer-ish anime looking graphics (In Game is Pixel graphics similar to 16 bit games) but it's fun and it's challenging.

I don't really pay too much attention to the soundtrack but it's not outright grating so it can't be bad. The first playthrough, "story" difficulty is almost comedically easy. Your characters will easily be overpowered in almost every fight. It's the Hard and Expert ones that really shine. Going for that perfect rating. It's tough but do-able.

If you're a fan of TD games, pick it up. If you're on the fence, It's a good TD game. If you see it on sale for a good price and just collect Steam games for your account numbers, Pick it up. If you hate fun and all those who have it, Pass.

11177117.review: Fun way to kill some time. It is a nice mix of RPG and tower defense. It is only RPG in the sense that you level characters keep that in mind but there is a story and fun to play. 11177072.review:
Great tower defense game. I love the RPG leveling up of the characters (the "towers"). Graphics are obviously not the game's strong points but I really didn't mind them and I liked the simple cutscenes. Has a lot of replay value and players of all skill levels can enjoy it due to the multiple difficulty settings. 

There's also settings to increase XP and gold for gamers who just don't have much time to play as well as accessibility options! That's really great and more developers should add options like that!

11176860.review: If you like anything about the Tower Defense or RPG generes you will find something to like about this game.  Do yourself a favor and give this game a try.

11176374.review:
Don't be fooled by the modest visuals - this is a fantastic game. As an RPG Tower Defense hybrid, it's a blast. Solid mechanics that allow you to micro-manage as much (or as little) as you like, while offering simple tweaks to XP accumulation, allow for a high degree of accessibility. On top of that, the story is great. It does its own thing without relying too heavily on established fantasy tropes, and also mixes in some really successful humor - it actually reminds me a bit of Avatar: The Last Airbender.

If you're going to pick the game up, I'd highly recommend heading to the game's site. There's a sequel in development, which will have a score by no other than Nobuo Uematsu, and pre-ordering it there will net you a free copy of this game as well.

Bonus Note: For a more classic RPG experience, don't pick up any additional recruits in the towns you visit along the way. Instead, use only the characters you get directly through the story, and bump up experience gains to 300% - this will lend itself to a few special achievements, minimize micro-management headaches, and generally let you bask in the glory of your awesome, uber-powered characters.

Bonus Note+: The New Game+ is incredible, and so worth playing. It adds side quests, and a journal (which is actually really well written), giving loads of meat to the story and characters that was only hinted at on the first playthrough. Stick around for it - it'll be worth your time.

11175831.review: this game is lots of fun for people who like Tower defence and RPGs.  It has a nice store line and very fun game play

Mon avis est partagé sur cette bête la. Mais voila, le fait est que j'ai apprécié. Le scénario est sympathique, les personnages attachants, le coté rpg donne une certaine rejouabilité, et il est pas difficile de faire varier le gameplay au fil des parties. Un petit bémol quand même, sur le coté rpg pour les arbres de compétences, qui gagneraient à être dévellopés. 
Pour résumer, le jeu se laisse jouer agréablement, même si c'est un peu cher pour ce que c'est. J'attends surtout la suite qui m'a l'air bien plus audacieuse.

P.S: Et puis si vous précommandez la suite, on vous offre le jeu de base apparement. Si j'avais su.

Yes. 10/10 would buy again.
This is a example of a good tower defense game coupled with an actual story. While one could argue that the graphics are low tier and would fit more as a flashgame it deserved its placed on the steam market. Why you ask? Everything fits in the big picture. There is not a single thing that seems out of place. It's a well thought out game no plot holes to fill only loot to get.

I still didnt complete the whole game 100% because you can actually increase the game speed by a certain amount and sometimes on really busy maps the game crashes. I love the fact that you can revisit the previous dungeons so you can loot some more scraps for that awesome bow in the town. When you play this game there is no pressure at all. You can take your time and progress through the world without the thought of dying all of a sudden just because it was too hard. Each dungeon has a difficulty level. This game is a hidden gem. Some people will be fooled by the graphics, but if you can get past that and play the game you will be sure to enjoy. 11171770.review:
Je recommande chaudement ce jeu qui fut pour moi une véritable révélation. Moi qui n'était pas fan de tower defense, je n'ai pu qu'être admiratif devant Defender's Quest auquel j'ai joué bien plus que mes statistiques Steam ne le révèlent: j'y ai joué partout où j'emmenais mon ordinateur dont une majorité du temps hors connexion.
Mais listons ses qualités:
-la prise en main est facile, même pour un néophyte. La jouabilité est toujours excellente, servie notamment par un placement des tours simple même quand on dispose de nombreux guerriers.
-le titre propose un bon background même si l'histoire reste assez simple. Les personnages notamment sont assez attachants. Toutefois pour en profiter il faut accepter de lire de nombreux écrans-textes en anglais.
-la personnalisation des troupes. Même si les modifications graphiques qu'on peut leur apporter sont mineures, leur donner des noms crée de l'empathie (surtout quand, comme moi, vous leur donnez des noms d'amis).
-les classes sont très bien conçues et complémentaires, aucune ne peut réellement fonctionner seule.
-la rejouabilité est très grande avec le mode nouvelle partie + qui propose un sérieux défi, bien plus grand que la première partie, avec de nouvelles missions et une flopée de nouvelles capacités ennemies qui obligent à revoir ses stratégies de fond en comble.

Bref ce titre est une petite perle que je recommande à tous !

11171599.review: I thoroughly enjoyed the combined genres of tower defense and role playing being supported by a great storyline and scalable difficulty.

11171493.review:
Dieses Spiel hat mich wirklich überrascht.
Beim kaufen des Spieles haben mich noch Gedanken gejagt, wie zum Beispiel: "Muss ich wirklich für ein Tower-Defend bezahlen? Sowas kann ich innerhalb eines Tages selber machen!". Jedoch änderte sich dieser Gedanke sehr schnell. Natürlich, dies ist ein Tower-Defend, besitzt keine bahnbrechende Technik oder des Sondernden, darum geht es aber nicht wirklich.
Defender`s Quest ist der Beweis, dass ausbalancierte Level gepaart mit einer interessanten Story immer begeistert.
Die Charaktere sind lebhaft, und in den meisten Fällen sehr sympathisch. Die Grafik lässt zu wünschen üben. Die Grafik erinnert einen sehr stark an die Frühstunden der 2000er Spiele. Für ältere Personen könnte hier eine gewisse Art von Nostalgie entstehen.
Jedoch ist der Normalpreis etwas sehr hoch, ich empfehle einen Kauf sobald das Spiel heruntergesetzt wurde.

10965064.review: Defender's Quest combines the classic tower defense formula with RPG elements in a way that feels both classic and fresh at the same time. Because it works within the established TD formula, it's familiar and accessible. Because it replaces towers with hired heroes who level up, learn new active and passive skills, and equip new gear, it's offbeat and original. The art is both childlike and gritty. The story, the game's weakest point, is still functional and effective, and the simple characters are fun and relatable. It's a little short, but there's replay value both in beating older missions on higher difficulties and in starting a new adventure with new hero builds. Overall, a charming and unique hybrid of the Tower Defense and RPG genres.

10778131.review:
This is a diamond in the rough for tower defense games. There are six different classes of units, and you can recuit a maximum of six units per class. Each level has four difficulties and three stars. There's an overarching plot to tie the levels together. Some levels require strategic use of only certain units, and level layouts are such that you are forced to thoughtfully place units to maximize their contribution. 

Item upgrades were added recently, and New Game+ mode keeps the fun going for more than twice as long as the original game. I've played this game for a long time, since before it even landed on steam, and I still haven't acquired the highest level items. I still haven't finished beating levels. I still haven't gotten my fill of this fun game.

10773212.review:
Brilliant game!  I'm not normally a fan of tower defense games, but I got it via a "HumbleBundle" and found that this one has features that converted me to a TD addict.
Nice story and great replayability due to each battle coming in four levels of difficulty that can be mastered incrementally as the army is leveled up and gets better equipment.
Then there's "Play+", with stronger opponents and better weapons, that allows one to improve the team even more and then go back to the regular game and finish the really hard levels with a much stronger group.
So this is extremely satisfying: no challenge is totally frustrating because one knows one can skip it and master it later after more up-leveling.
Get it and play it if you like tower defense, and also get it and play it if you don't - an extremely well-done game!

10732968.review:
Com certeza um excelente jogo, vale muito a pena comprar.

O jogo possui um estilo de Tower Defense com gráficos originais, uma história consistente e muito cativante, além de uma jogabildiade divertida, cheia de desafios e com muitas opções de personalização.

O que mais conquista em Defender's Quest, na minha opinião, é a sua simplicidade. O jogo não possui gráficos em 3D ou explosões em alta definição, isso, porque ele não precisa. A sua história é muito cativante, a personalidade impressa em cada personagem é tão vívida que faz você rir e até odiar em alguns casos. Sua trilha sonora é impulsiva e imersiva, lhe trazendo ao trágico clima instável e sombrio "do Abismo" (The Pit). Além de é claro possuir uma jogabilidade que, em toda sua simplicidade e facilidade, conta com um sistema único de estratégia e que lhe rende boas horas de diversão.

Não se engane, não basta apenas posicionar suas tropas,é preciso manejá-las da melhor maneira. Controlar seu Psi (Energia gasta para se conjurar tropas e lançar poderes) ah e claro, soltar seus poderes na hora certa, 1 segundo pode ser tarde demais. Aí, então, quando já tiver terminado o jogo, ele lhe oferece duas novas oportunidades Game+ e Game++ para refazer sua história de novo, com mais personalizações e opções ainda, além de, é claro, novos desafios. É com certeza um jogo que lhe renderá horas e mais horas de diversão, além de umas boas risadas e alguns momentos de tensão. :v

10726738.review: This is a wonderful game with several interesting aspects for a tower defence.

10720940.review: Defender's Quest is an enjoyable tower defense style game with character progression that extends beyond individual maps. 10696955.review:
Gonna be a pretty short review; hopin' that the fact it's the game I've played most on Steam and the fact I'm recommending it is enough to say 'this game is good.'

Cause damn me if it isn't. It's an RPG/Tower Defence hybrid, as you can likely read the entry or Google to discover, with an interesting storyline, characters I came to like and in some cases love ('Slak' the Beserker is ridiculously funny in my opinion), and a balance of serious moments and comedy that I've always enjoyed. It never feels entirely like non-sense to me either when it flits between the two ends, so that's always a plus.

The game doesn't take anywhere near as long to play through as my time suggests; I've just enjoyed the game so much that, after finding it mysteriously uninstalled from my computer and thus all my progress erased, instead of getting annoyed I got excited to be able to play through it all again

So if you're a fan of Tower Defence and RPG's, I'd say to give it a look. For those of you that know me better, and can say our tastes in games are similar, I don't know why you don't own it already.

10600870.review:
Once you've played one or two tower defenses, you've played them all, right? YES. Well, almost completely yes.

I hate this genre with a passion. I enjoyed those first one or two tower defenses I've played, and I'm consistently disappointed with every successive iteration that there is basically no variation whatsoever, especially given how crowded the genre has been. I think it's to do with tower defenses being easy to make, in terms of design, programming, and graphics, so that a lamentably successful game can be made on a dime.

However, I do have to give this one game a recommendation. As much as I dislike the genre, this one definitely feels fresher. It blends significant RPG elements into the usual formula. Firstly, it has an engaging story, with plenty of humour and quirky characters. The levels support the story, including the occasional boss fight. Your "towers" are in fact your party members, belonging to six classes, who gain experience from encounters and level up to gain additional skills, or hone their own skills further. This allows for plenty of variation amongst your party, although I found myself sticking to a single formula for each of my types.

The gameplay itself is not typical of tower defense. There's no placing your people so that they block enemies; they must be placed on the sidelines of a preset path. Also, there isn't an emphasis on placing more and more towers to increase the length of the gauntlet. Although you can place all 36 members of your party in a level, doing so is generally not recommended, because it is far more efficient to simply upgrade the party members you have. The end result is a far more sparse tower defense game, one that greatly favours tactical placement, and consequently, can be fun for the most jaded tower defense anti-fan.

I also appreciated the difficulty system, whereby you can choose from three difficulty settings when playing each level (and a fourth that doesn't exactly count, for casual gamers). You can also come back and play the level on a higher difficulty setting, with different enemy types and levels, to get greater rewards (like unique items). It really added to the longevity of the game. Add in some challenges to complete, and you well and truly get your $15 worth.

So, for the first time, I have played a tower defense that has left me wanting more! I'm keeping an eye out on Defender's Quest 2, which is currently in development. If you too are as jaded as I am, don't instantly discount this one. Give the demo a try.
