10531458.review:
As a puzzle game, I think its better than the likes of Puzzle Quest, because you're essentially managing a party of heroes, and placing them in dungeon sets and hoping that your customisations and placements pay off. It doesn't hinge on playing a very abstract match 3 game. Its a hybrid of an adventuring party management game, and a battle based puzzler. 

The fact that it sort of follows Tower Defense rules, in that you have waves of enemies, and they follow known paths, is all by the by. Goblin hordes usually follow dungeon tunnels anyway as they charge the brave adventurers!  I've played my fair share of Tower Defense games and hundreds of them bore me to tears, but this one seems to get the balance between RPG party management and planning, and the try it and then refine it mechanic. It's not overly complex, each class (and there are about six in total, I think) have skill trees that are only two branches. You need to earn money (loot and scrap) to purchase more adventurers to sign up. Then you have to train them up from level 1, and customise their skillsets to complement the team you already have.

There are beserkers who lend the chopping/slashing muscle - for corner killzones - and your archers can thin out the horde on the way, as well as try and catch the speedy monsters early. You also have (so far) Ice mages, for slowing effects and mages for healing or area of effect spells. You can specialise zerkers as damage soakers or fast dps dealers. You can specialise archers as heavy critical hitter, or speedy bleeders. Plus you've got the inventory to manage with different armours and weapons etc. 

Some of the harder levels later on in the story, require a little bit of farming to get enough money and people to do them. It just hit a sweet spot for me, in terms of low maintenance RPG adventuring, with just enough tweaking, twiddling and puzzling to keep me going back to it over and over again. Repeating the same levels with harder foes doesn't seem to get old, you have to adjust your tactics for a longer harder game. All the while you're crafting up a team whose skills work intimately with each other, making the sum of the parts greater than the individual.

10269988.review:
Over the last five years indie games have gained a steady and impressive following among both PC and console gamers, giving rise to a rebirth of many classic game types and the birth of many creative new game styles as well. One of the game types that has benefitted the most from the rise the indie market is the Tower Defense genre, and there are few games that exemplify the quality an indie title can reach like Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten.

At first glance Defender's Quest does little to inspire confidence in the overall product. With a rudimentary title screen and an almost complete lack of graphics options the game will seem lean on content to start with. Even the cinematics in the game are somewhat jarring and a let down, consisting of still images that, in all honesty, would feel more at home in a flash game than a title developed for sale.

Delving deeper into the game, however, will quickly show you the quality that lies beneath this initially lackluster veneer. The in-game graphics are a wonderful modern take on the 16-bit era, colorful and with enough animation to keep battles fairly lively and interesting. While the graphics options are sparse at best, the game wows with how much customization it allows in its gameplay experience, allowing players the option to tune experience gains, character downtime penalties, and even monetary gains to suit most players from the most hard-core strategy gamers to those who are looking for a more relaxed experience. Despite the less than stellar presentation for cutscenes the characters themselves are all colorful and fun, and the art design itself only fails due to a lack of consistency between cinematics and gameplay. Characters offer a rudimentary RPG-style skill and level up tree, and combining that with the ability to level up characters mid-level to gain access to more advanced combat techniques gives the entire game a great deal of depth. The equipment system is underwhelming, with new swords and armor offering nothing in terms of rewards beyond an incremental stat boost, but the entire design shows a great deal of promise, if not polish.

Gameplay is often quick, but can be paused to allow the player time to consider strategy as often as one needs to. Overall the difficulty curve on the game is well managed: with rewards turned up the game is a relaxing affair that still manages to hold your attention, while turning them down increases the difficulty and need for strategy without ever becoming unfair. Controls with either the keyboard or mouse are generally responsive and convenient, and there is next to nothing in the experience that will frustrate most players unduly. Level design is well handled as well, with the levels scaling nicely to present new placement and enemy challenges as the player progresses through the game.

With an intriguing storyline, good characters, and incredibly scalable gameplay that allows it to appeal to audiences of varied skill or dedication, Defender's Quest succeeds in presenting its players with a high-quality product worth investing your time in. While visual presentation suffers due to a mish-mash of different styles, it is only a minor flaw in the face of an otherwise well-made and solid game.

Final Rating: 8 out of 10.

Despite its visual shortcomings many game designers could learn a thing or two from Level Up Labs about accessible gameplay. By appealing to users seeking a hardcore strategy experience as well as those looking for a more casual game the creators have come up with a stand-out strategy title for both markets.

10182230.review:
Oddly one of my favorite games that I continue to go back to.  There is no mindblowing gameplay or jawdropping graphics.  What it does it does small scale, but it delights in in each area.

Story:  A very solemn themed game about war, sacrifices, dark gods, etc.  Fortunately the main cast have great (sometimes insane)  personalities and have wonderful, surprising, and often hysterical interactions.  This is where the writing really shines and is honestly probably the strongest part of the game.

Gameplay:  It's pretty standard tower defense.  Each class has skills, attack range, hit points, etc.  Set them up in likely positions and away you go.  Fail?  Try a different set up.  Characters also level up with experience for new skills, high attack, so forth.  Getting too easy? There's a Newgame+ with harder enemies and achievements that will test you.

Graphics:  During gameplay it is high quality pixel art style, detailed and well done.  Cut scenes before and after battles are...I'm not sure what to call it.  Cell shaded stop motion?  It's nice and it does the trick without being flashy.

Like I said, I just keep coming back for more, figured I might as well review it.  If you like tower defense games with interesting stories and well written characters, get this.

This game is quite a treat. I love its art style and combat mechanics. Its a refreashing take on the Tower defense genre with some fun rpg elements mixed in. You name you heros, level them, and find new equipment for them. Then these heros are used in a tower defense acting in place of the towers. The combat is like Final Fantasy Crystal Defenders.

The conversations are quite amusing and the story thus far has been pretty entertaining and is keeping me hooked and wanting to learn more. I also love puns so this game gets points there.

There are two big complaints I have for the title though. The biggest is that you have to run it at a fixed resolution in windowed mode. The window is so small it could very well fit on an 8" tablet. This means playing for an extended period will likely hurt your eyes. I really wish I could make the game bigger without having to use fullscreen. The second complaint is the sound. It gets very bad when you have a healer and ice hero on the field. Especially a 4x speed. I would recommend turning the sound off and either listening to the in game music or playing your own. 9975667.review: Defender's QUest is a tower defense game that has a heart. The video trailer is pithy, suggesting that the game and its creators don't take themselves seriously, but don't be fooled. The story is simple but effective, not avoiding the cliches but embracing them and making them its own, but not with the wink and nod of the lampooner, but of a storyteller with an earnest wish to convey to you the world they've imagined. I found myself playing this game long after the challenge had worn away, drawn not so much by the game that had grown to be child's play after intense leveling, but rather by that very soul the creators instilled in it. I found myself surprised by this, and was sad to find it 100% completed and with nothing more to offer. I will pick you up again in time, my friend, for the happiness you offered was not forgotten.

9894872.review:
Clever is the word for this game.  The gameplay is tight, well-balanced, and clever.  Tower defense games are rarely this clever and the RPG system rewards good play.  The downfall of virtually all RPG systems is a sense of grind - you want the best stuff, you're going to have to perform repetitive tasks until you've got the prerequisite numbers.  Grinding reminds me of a job.  Defender's Quest lets you bypass that - anything you'd have to grind for is optional, and if you want the optional content, then you can toggle the exp and gold gain.  This also lets you set the difficulty to as difficult or as easy as you want.

The amazing thing is that the gameplay is so good, and the rest of the game is also so good.  The graphics aren't the modern blockbusters, but the character art is charming and clever, and the dialog is well-written and allows you to connect to the characters.  Fun gameplay, thoughtful gameplay, good art, good dialog, fun plot.  The game can even be replayed, and the new game+ has additional insight into the world if you're that hooked.  It also ramps up the difficulty if you like a challenge.  To top it off, the game is inexpensive.  Why have you not already bought it?

Genre: Tower Defense/RPG
Spieldauer: ca. 10 Std.
Preis: 13,99 €

Story 73% (Gewichtet: 10%)

Man ist ja von den meisten Tower Defense Spielen gewöhnt, dass man einfach Level für Level schafft und irgendwann das Spiel durch hat, ohne das man nur einmal ein Fünkchen Story zu Gesicht bekommen hat. Das ist hier anders, man bekommt neben den einzelnen Level auch eine kleine Story, die einen bis zum Ende begleitet und mit comicartigen Zwischensequenzen erzählt wird.

Gameplay 79% (Gewichtet: 70%)

Man muss wir in jedem Tower Defense auch in jedem Level seine Tower (in diesem Spiel Personen) richtig platzieren um möglichst zu verhindern, dass die Gegner durch das Level kommen. Im Laufe der Level bekommt man dann auch Seelenenergie von den Gegnern, mit der man seine Tower upgraden kann um neue Fähigkeiten für diese freizuschalten. Am Ende jedes Levels bekommt man dann noch Gold, um seine Tower auszurüsten und Erfahrungspunkte mit denen, die Tower Level aufsteigen. Wenn das passiert bekommen die Tower einen Skillpunkt, den man in einen Skill investieren kann, um dessen Grundwerte zu verstärken.

Grafik 52% (Gewichtet: 15%)

Die Grafik erinnert ein bisschen an die Zeit vom Super Nintendo, kann aber durch immer gleichen Texturen und Farben nicht mit den Bekannten Spielen von Selbigem mithalten.

Sound 25% (Gewichtet: 5%)

Die Musik hat mir persönlich nicht sehr gut gefallen, ich habe diese nach der ersten Stunde Spielzeit abgeschaltet.

Speziell

+Mods mit denen man die Spielzeit deutlich erhöhen kann +2%


Fazit

Defender's Quest hebt sich besoders mit seinem Skillsystem und der kleinen Story von anderen Tower Defense Spielen ab. Die Grafik und Sound überzeigten mich aber nicht wirklich. Der Preis von 13,99 € ist recht teuer und lohnt sich meiner Meinung nicht.

9704948.review:
This is my favourite game in years.
It's a tower defense game where each of what would normally be a tower is actually a character that levels up, like in an RPG, complete with a customizable skill tree, equipment, etc. These levels are earned from level to level, so you're constantly improving your party.

This superficially simple gameplay concept is backed up on all sides by a great story, deep strategy elements and amazing replayability.

[b]Story[/b]
Azra (or the name you choose) is the royal librarian that ends up in The Pit, a wretched place full of zombie-like creatures called Revenant. Using mysterious special powers (that excellently explain the tower defense gameplay) and the help of a band of ragtag adventures you'll pick up it is your job to guide her out of the pit. There is more at stake, and the plot has plenty of developments to keep you interested, but what surprised me the most were the story's pacing and its humour.
No story segment lasts more than a minute or two, excluding the ending but not the opening, yet it tells a cohesive and engaging story. You'll never feel like the levels are just there to pad out the story or vice versa.

[b]Strategy & Replayability[/b]
Within levels you get to place your defenders along the paths your enemies will take to reach Azra. Doing so spends mana, so unless Azra has a lot of Mana (maximum mana increases by increasing her level) you'll need to consider which allies to summon. You can 'boost' these allies to unlock more attacks and increase their core stats, up to 5 times, this is equivalent to the traditional tower defense game's tower upgrade. Combine that with being able to place allies whenever you want, advanced targetting settings and certain allies working very well together while others negate some aspects of other powers (frozen vs. burning) and you have a deeply rewarding tactical system.
Is this required to enjoy or finish the game? No.

The ability to play and replay any level you've cleared at any of 4 difficulties means that you set your own pace and your own challenge. On the lowest difficulty you can basically breeze through the game and just enjoy the story, never having to put a lot of thought into tactics or grinding, and the hardest difficulty will have you either rethinking your tactics or grinding a few more levels.
Clearing the game once, with any of its 5 endings (only 2 distinct ones really, one just has 4 different versions) will unlock new game+ mode parallel to the regular game mode. This features new powers for all enemies, several sidequests telling the story of one of the characters relevant to the plot, the ability to understand the 'ancient language' spoken in some of the dialogue and a 'journal' that offers lovely (and often hilarious) glances into the protagonist's mind as her journey progresses.
It will challenge you and reward you, and this is completely free extra content that was released months after the game was originally launched that is automatically included. I've put dozens of hours into this game and still revisit it regularly to see if I can't beat a few of the levels I still have problems with on a higher difficulty or to work on my Hero Mode run.

Summary:
+great plot
+great tower defense gameplay
+great RPG-style customization
+replay levels
+multiple difficulties
+multiple endings
+best way to do new game+
-graphics are serviceable, but nothing to write home about
-no voice acting (which to me is better than bad voice acting...)
-Defender's Quest 2 isn't out yet, give it to meeeeee!

9678261.review:
This is a surprisingly good little tower defense game with RPG mechanics. As a commander, you can recruit troops, equip them with weapons and armor and control their few skills when leveling up. It is pretty basic, yet very deep. The levels are single screen and grid based. You place your characters down and they automatically attack as enemies approach them. There are 6 classes, a basic melee, long range, healer, ice mage, slow defensive breaker and all powerful dragon with short and long range attacks. It costs PSI to place your characters, and more PSI to retract them (to move them).

How do you get PSI? Well you start with it, but then as you kill enemies, you gain more PSI and you have a maximum of course. You are defending a summoner against the waves of enemies and the summoner (your player character) can take a beating and has plenty of HP, so the game is forgiving, but rewarding if you make it through the level without being damaged.

You can 'boost' your characters at the cost of PSI. There are many levels of boos that enable skills that you've unlocked through leveling up your characters. When you level up your characters, you select their perk. Which has a simple perk tree of skills and passive abilities. It is a nice little system, but I find myself making the same perk choices instead of diversifying.

Oh and death is not perminant for your characters. If someone dies, just use PSI to bring them back. If your player character dies, you lose the level and need to restart. These levels are quick, especially at 4x speed, so nothing is really lost.

While the game boasts a rich story.... I found myself hitting the skip button. I just don't play games for the story. You read the story as you unlock new levels and progress through a Mario World style map with all of the levels plotted as map points.

The game is very easy to pick up and play, but not just that, it encourages replaying the levels with 3 different difficulties (and a 'casual' difficulty as a 4th). If there's an insurmountable level.... replay old levels *cough* grind. But replaying old levels never seems like a chore, its more of a joy. Even if you keep replaying the same level on the same difficulty, every playthrough is different, since your characters level up and you can change your tactics.

The game is a lot of fun, and while its deep, its never overwhelmingly deep. There's not an overwhelming micro management either, even if you can micro manage everything.

I highly recommend it. Its a fun little game, relaxing and never gets all that intense. I found myself playing it on 4x speed and that seems like it should be the average speed. Is it worth the $15? Its a game you can sink hours and hours into, so you'll get a lot of relaxing playtime for your dollar.

9674526.review:
塔防+RPG，其核心系统就是把塔防游戏里的各种塔以及基地都换成角色，然后拥有技能树、等级和装备，每个职业（每种塔）都一个最早加入而且参与剧情的特殊角色，其它则需要通过雇佣获得，并用这种方式决定了每种塔的个数上限（有一个成就是不雇佣过关，自虐向）。可以说这是一个很不错的想法，只是游戏中后期培养一个新士兵的成本很高，等级装备跟不上的话没办法成为战力，而前期穷也不可能大量雇佣（雇佣费用会逐个上升），所以作为塔防游戏的战术应变性不是很强是个小缺点，但看到自己长期培养的各种士兵也会有另一种成就感。而且游戏后期难度很高，并且鼓励多周目（解锁成就需要至少三周目），可惜像我这样平时不怎么玩这类游戏的塔防苦手到了二周目就各种艰难，如果喜欢塔防游戏的话强烈推荐尝试并挑战一下。

作为RPG的最大亮点是对话，虽然世界观和主线故事其实并不算特别出彩，但人物对话真的很有趣，角色的个性塑造也都很成功，二周目会解锁女主的日记和一些支线任务，日记里面记录了各种欢乐的小事件，同时也是对主线和角色背景非常好的补充，所以有能力的话推荐走一遍二周目看日记。排除剧情的话，RPG这个标签对塔防的影响其实并不大，玩起来依然是造塔升塔，偶尔放一些地图技能。所以塔防终究是塔防，即便多了RPG元素在塔防的玩法上面并没有什么本质性的突破，不会有什么特别新的体验，怪物也就那么几种常见类型（比起其它塔防游戏可能这作的怪物种类数量算是非常少的），没有挑战研究精神说实话走完剧情以后很容易厌倦并感到无聊，不喜欢的塔防的依旧建议回避。

因为游戏用的是Adobe Air环境，所以其实就是一个Flash游戏，只能说这是一个不错的值得一玩的Flash游戏，但在画面和运行上就不要抱太高要求了。另外据说Linux和Adobe Air的兼容性不好，所以虽然游戏宣称支持Linux系统，但请Linux用户慎重购买。

9600372.review:
A delightful indie gem, Defender's Quest combines some of the funniest writing I've seen in a game with a terrific twist on tower defence. 

The campaign is cleverly designed. Each battle has four difficulty levels. You can push through the storyline on a low level, and indeed you need to at the early stages. However, there is plenty of incentive to come back and try it again for special items, experience and rewards. Battles are short and varied so there is not really a sense of grinding; indeed, it is interesting to come back with new options through skills and classes.

There is plenty of scope for strategy in the battles. There are six different classes, each having different skills and attributes which can be levelled up. They can be boosted during the battle, and can be recalled and replaced. 

There can be incredibly tense moments late in a battle when a powerful enemy is closing in and you have to frantically recall fighters to put them into better positions. The ability to pause or slow time means that success depends on your strategy, not your reflexes. 

The variety of battle maps and enemies make for a different experience in each battle. 

There are genuine laugh-out-loud moments throughout the campaign, which adds to the pleasurable experience of progressing through it.

The New Game+ is the finest example of this mode that I've ever seen. It's not just another run through the campaign at higher difficulty, it actually adds side quests, wonderfully-written journal entries and other bonus to make it well worth playing through again.

In short, I highly recommend this game. It's one of the best I've ever played.

9442139.review:
An excellent tower defense game that is traditional in all the ways I love but innovative where it counts. Instead of placing towers, you're placing party members. Like a traditional TD game, there are resource points you acquire within a round that you can spend on placing new towers (i.e. allies) or buffing the towers you've already placed. In Defender's Quest, this resource is called "PSI", which is essentially the "mana" of Azra (aka: you, the commander).  Howevever, Defender's Quest also gives you two other resources to spend BETWEEN rounds: gold and experience. 

Experience is used to unlock abilities on an ally's skill tree, thereby making them available to use in battle. (Each skill is assigned a power level and is not available in battle until you buff this ally to that level using PSI points.)

Gold is used to hire new allies into the party or to purchase armor/weapon upgrades for individual allies, which immediately and permanently boosts their stats (i.e. unlike skill upgrades, these are conferred immediately at the start of battle---no PSI points required.)

Every level can be replayed as many times as you want to farm XP and gold, and every level has multiple difficulty settings that earn you better gold/XP rewards for beating them. (There is no penalty for running away.) Beating the highest difficulty on some levels earns you a legendary weapon or armor, far more powerful than anything you'll find in shops.

The only bad thing I could possibly say about the game is that the art in the cutscenes makes the game's aesthetic somewhat comparable to something you'd find on a flash portal. By flash portal standards, the artwork is amazing. By overall industry standards, the art seems a little amateur. The in-game art is pixely and SNES-tastic. I criticize only the cutscene art here. But in the end, it doesn't even really matter, because the cutscenes have no effect on gameplay, and you can even skip over them all if you like. The game itself is A+.

If you like Tower Defense, it's one of the better TD games in the Steam catalogue.

9410881.review: Я всегда относилась с определенной долей скептицизма к такому жанру, как tower defence. Пожалуй, я бы и продолжала обходить защиту башен стороной, если бы не наткнулась на Defender's Quest. Уже смешание жанров - RPG и TD - как-то притягивает взгляд, заставляет обратить внимание. Создателям этой игры действительно удалось создать целый мир со своей историей, противоречиями и конфликтами. Главная героиня - простая хранительница Королевской библиотеки по имени Ацра (ествественно, ее можно переименовать) и ее товарищи, которых она обретет по ходу своего путешествия, встречает на своем пути множество могущественных врагов, преоболевает трудности и тяготы жизни в Яме, дабы сразится с величайшим Злом - [спойлеры]. Однако, несмотря на весь этот пафос, игра наполнена юмором самого разного уровня - от бытового и вполне приличного до черного юмора и шуток ниже пояса. Основная сюжетая линия почти не дает пространства для выбора, но знаете, это можно пережить. Сложно сказать, что это в большей степени - ролевая игра или защита башни, - потому что все прелести этих жанров нашли свое отражение в Defender's Quest. Здесь не нужно глобальной превозможение (хотя при помощи астроек можно устроить себе нелегкую жизнь), не нужно терзаться моральным выбором - можно просто насладиться неплохим сюжетом и интересными тактическими боями. Игры подобного рода не захватывают обложки игровых журналов, не окружают себя масштабными рекламными акциями. Как и многие хорошие инди, эту игру можно порекомендовать другу, причем, что выгодно отличает именно Defender's Quest, не важно даже, какие у друга интересы и предпочтения - здесь каждый найдет то, что западет в душу.

9409539.review:
Примерно так выглядело мое знакомство с DQ: нажимаю на кнопочку "играть" в два часа дня, предвидя выход через пятнадцать минут и... прихожу в сознание в десять вечера на трети сюжетной линии. 
Разработчики взяли за основу игрушки жанров Tower Defence и RPG, и сделали все для того, чтобы игрок не смог оторваться от экрана: прекрасный баланс, разнообразие карт, условий и монстров, отличный сюжет (несколько сюжетных веток и концовок, Карл! В тауер дефенсе!), достаточно объектов для мачкинизма, но неадекватно масштабных задач перед игроком не ставят, а для тех, кому мало, еще есть и дополнительные режимы испытаний. Пройдя всю игру и собрав 180 звезд, вы нажимаете на кнопку "новая игра плюс" и... обнаруживаете еще более интересных противников, новый лут, дополнительные квесты, весьма занимательный журнал главной героини, и второе дно у и без того непростой истории. 
Об интерфейсе стоит сказать отдельно пару слов. Под вашим контролем и у вас на виду находится буквально все: прогресс в достижениях? Пожалуйста! Медленно качаетесь, становится скучновато? Увеличьте количество получаемого опыта и денег! Настройка всего и вся; импорт, экспорт, копирование, обмен и редактирование сохранений - присутствует; поддержка моддинга и мастерская - есть! Ручной контроль всех персонажей? Пожалуйста! Контроль скорости игры? Есть! Достигли высоких уровней и начали наносить по тысяче ударов в минуту? Настройте шаблон поведения для каждого персонажа! Захотелось уникальных имен и внешностей подопечным? Вперед! Напортачили с внешностью и прокачкой? Поправьте в любой момент! Даже при попытке вскрытия сохранений (к которым вас тоже проводит сама игра) вы обнаружите вполне читабильный XML-файл, начинающийся с текста:

[i]ATTENTION SAVE GAME HACKERS:

Messing with this file can totally destroy your game. 
If you're going to hack, know this first:

1) Make a backup of this save file before modifying it
2) Accept the risk you could totally ruin your save file forever
3) Understand that customer support won't bail you out

Other than that, happy hacking![/i] 

Отдельный респект ребятам за редактирование имен. Журнал превращяется в потрясающую вешь! Это теперь будет висеть у меня на стене :D
http://steamcommunity.com/id/Just_LeonS/screenshot/3281175165156174080

Ну и, кончено, минусы. Куда мы без них? 
Графика. Причем, притензии к имею только к внутригеймплейным спрайтам, CG нарисованы неплохо. Со временем, внимания обращать перестал, но в первые пару часов глаз резало ощутимо.
Второй косяк - производительность. Игра стоит на флеше и, хотя держится молодцом, на поздних частях "бесконечного выживания" и в экстримальных финальных поединках обязательны тормоза, и вполне возможны вылеты. Когда игра демонстрирует тебе рабочий стол вместо последней волны финального уровня, до которой ты шлепал без сохранения больше получаса, становится немного грустно.

Русский язык в игре присутствует.
Итог: личная оценка 9 оживших трупов из 10, предзаказ DQ2.

UPD: разработчк не забросил игрушку, и спустя некоторое время подтянул и графику, и стабильность. И локализацию. Детишки, этот тауэр дефенс идеален.  Брать и играть.

9224362.review:
I'm a bit unfamilar with the "Tower of Defense" genre as a whole, so I picked this up on a whim for $2.49. Turns out that was a pretty damn sweet deal. Defender's Quest isn't overly complex, innovative, super-artistic or genre-defining. What it is, though, is easy to get into, sort of addicitve, and a lot of fun.

Honestly, the core mechanics are pretty simple - you have six character classes, each with slight customizability (basically skill trees and pallete swapping consist of the variations in-class), and each serve their own purpose. The challenges definitely lend themselves to exploiting this variation - you WILL not beat this game using just your archers, for example. The key strategical elements will be where along the paths you place your characters, how you choose to boost them during battle, and how to time the protagonist's abilities (a feature which helps engage a player and prevents one from just sitting back and watching the level unfold). Add in a mild RPG-twist with how you choose to level up skill sets, and you have a very simple concept turned into something that has multiple layers of combat. Good move on their part.

The story, while simple, is sufficient enough to make you want to keep going. Characters are all pretty eccentric for the most part, and the humor is just average. I'm okay with that, though, as when I bought a game that looked like it could be run on a flash-based website, I really expected a cliche-ridden excuse plot with bland characters. Kudos to the creators on that front.

The real downside of the game comes in the form of some rather noticeable forced level-grinding. The advanced and extreme challenges often change the way you play a level, but the general root of how you play it is still going to be there. Most average players (see: me) will have to repeat a level one or two times before confidently progressing on to the next challenge. This is extremely obvious in the otherwise-enteretaining new game+ as the enemy traits mean you have to work waaaay harder to beat the level.

Other than that though, this is a straight-forward game with a lot upside. I certainly wouldn't be disappointed if I'd dropped the regular price on it. Try it out.

9192649.review: I am a huge fan of Tower Defense games, but it's been a while since I've seen anything this fun. Getting the rhythm of the game is relatively easy, and the difficulty slowly grows with your characters, so it never feels too easy unless you've done some serious grinding in order to gear out your Heroes. 9182110.review:
[b]RPG要素を加えたカジュアルTower Diffence[/b]

2周クリアまでプレイした感想はTDの入門編としては良く出来ているしお薦め。
とはいえ、ある程度TDに慣れた人には物足りないゲームな印象。

[b]～特徴であるRPG要素とその評価～[/b]

本作のRPG要素は主に以下2点

[u]1．ストーリー性[/u]
各ステージ攻略後にキャラクター同士の紙芝居によりストーリーが進行して行く。
ステージが全部で30あり、毎回紙芝居を読むのが面倒になり序盤以降は全てスキップ対応。
個人的にTDにストーリー性は求めないない自分には不要な要素だった。
キャラクターに個性や愛着を持たせる意味では有効かもしれないが、ゲームテンポを阻害する要因に感じた。

[u]2．キャラクターカスタマイズ性[/u]
各キャラクターはクリア報酬である資金/経験値を元にレベルアップ/購入により装備/スキルをカスタマイズ出来る。(任意で随時リクルート出来るキャラクターは名前、見た目もカスタマイズ可)
装備は武器防具に分かれ、各スキルはシンプルなツリー状の構成になっている(振り直し可)。
カスタマイズは楽しめたものの、武器・防具は種類が少なく、スキルツリーは良くも悪くもシンプルで底が浅い。

[b]～TowerDiffenceとして～[/b]

・基本要素 ステージは30(3つの難易度)、タワー(職種)は6種、敵はベースが3種?×亜種も3種程度、ボスキャラ有り。マップは非常に狭く、敵の進攻ルートも至ってシンプル
・各タワーはステージ中に5段階までアップグレード可能
・主人公はポイントを消費し任意で魔法が使用可能(強化可能)
・クリア内容によって☆で評価、☆の獲得数によりエクストラステージ(主人公の魔法の書が報酬)にチャレンジ可能
・スピード設定は×0.5～×4まで、タワーのターゲッティングも柔軟に調整可能
・Newgame＋が存在。2周目には複数の隠しステージが有り、1周目では語られなかったストーリーも楽しめる。

総じてタワー、敵、マップ共に基本的かつシンプルなものが多い。その為、タワーの配置やアップグレードを深く考えずともクリアが可能であり難易度は低い(一部難易度/一部ステージを除く)。

～その他～
・ワークショップ対応
一通りバニラでクリアした後に、初プレイ時におススメ出来るMODは以下。

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=182575723&searchtext=]Skill increase[/url]
レベルキャップを60→100に引き上げる＆各スキルへの最大割り振りポイントを増加させるMOD。高難易度の2周目後半やエクストラステージが容易に。実績獲得可否についてはMODを導入せずプレイした為、不明。ワークショップを参照下さい。

・日本語化可能
　公式に日本語化予定だが現時点でもプレイに問題ない日本語化が可能

・設定
　クリア時の経験値の量などを調整可能。
　最初から2周クリアを目論んで経験値×3ブーストの設定も良いかも。

・その他
　続篇が近日発売予定

9106252.review:
I always had a certain fondness for tower defense. In StarCraft, I'd spend more time stacking cannons than playing the ladder, and Team Fortress 2's MvM mode reveals a certain primal fun of killing tons of heartless, unfeeling dudes. To that end, Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten presents a well-rounded, core dude-killing experience, but the cracks in the polish are evident.

You're given six classes to play, all fairly standard for the genre: heavy damage, light damage, healer, ranged, status effects, and tank. Upgrade trees for each class are fleshed out for the game's length, and most powers are distinct from the moment you first receive them. Leveling up your characters before and during battle using "Psi" adds a certain urgency to the fight, and doesn't feel forced.

But between battles there exists some friction between the player and the imperfect interface. Between the fast-forward of battle and the clunky number-comparison engine to power up your party, you'll be wishing for a patch to streamline or automate the process. You could do worse but you could do better; not even trendy not-loading-but-loading-messages like 'reticulating splines' or 'powering up the thermal core' are to be seen. You might hope to find some solace in the story, but it's just as hacked-on as the interface and I couldn't be bothered to follow it.

My first playthrough entailed of spamming rangers (long-range) with the range upgrade and blew through the game without breaking a sweat, but in Hero Mode, where you limit yourself to one of each class, is where the game's difficulty felt most appropriate. Oftentimes you'll have three or four spawn points to deal with, and you'll need to consider the most optimal placement to cover all your bases, evoking the puzzle modes of yore.

All in all I'm giving this a weak recommendation. The game itself is pretty solid - gameplay is mostly balanced, and it can be as hard as you want it to be. The lore isn't engaging and you won't miss much from skipping it; on the other hand, if you're the type for a story maybe tower defense wasn't going to be your cup of tea anyway. If it goes on sale again for 90% off you'll get a fun one-off to pick up and play, not unlike something you'd find on a phone or tablet. Otherwise, you may feel you aren't getting enough bang for your buck.

Uno dei migliori Tower Defense o "Human Defense" in circolazione. In questo gioco non ci sono le nostre amate torri a difenderci ma bensì persone vive che fungono da torri e sono guerrieri, maghi, arcieri e draghi. Questi ultimi hanno abiltà e tecniche uniche che possono essere affinate tramite l'esperienza ottenuta in combattimento. All'inizio, ovviamente, disporremo solo di alcuni membri nel nostro gruppo, man mano proseguendo la trama potremo reclutarne altri, proprio come un Gioco di ruolo Old school.

Il gameplay è molto equilibrato, sia dalla parte dei nemici sia dalla nostra parte, infatti alcuni nemici possono attaccare i nostri soldati. Le varie missioni sulla mappa potranno essere ripetute in un secondo momento anche a difficoltà più alte prolungando la longevità del gioco. Non mancano le modalià Endeless e sfide bonus.

L'unica pecca, secondo me, è la grafica e il prezzo. La grafica è un pò in basso alle esigenze minime di oggi in un gioco a pagamento, che tra l'altro costa 14€. Ovviamente non infuisce affatto sul gameplay, ma non sarebbe sgradito un upgrade grafico, magari in un aggiornamento o in un possibile sequel, lo dico anche perchè esistono dei Tower Defense in Flash gratuiti con grafica migliore.

9039408.review:
Tower Defense games are pretty hard to get right - they have to be unique from their predecessors, have a sense of progression, and be mechanically sound throughout, lest they become a boring slog.  I'm pleased to report that Defender's Quest gets it all right.  The characterization of each "tower" lends a lot of investment into the game itself, the RPG elements are fun and interesting without breaking the game in half, and the starred progression system meant that I was always seeking - and finding - a new challenge that was scaled to my level.  It's a good story too - simple and filled with pithy dialogue.  

The best TD I have played - ate days upon days of my time and, oh god, there's a new game plus mode. Halp.

This game mixes the Tower Defense genre with RPG elements.

The gameplay is like a normal Tower defense: you must protect something from the enemies that comes from some paths. The  "towers" are berserkes, archers, dragons and more. You get the first new unit for free, which is a character that interfieres in the story, and then you can recruit more. Each character has his own level, and with levels you can teach him more skills. You can (and should) also buy them equipment.

Ingame you can level up these units so they can do more damage and use more skills. Your main character can use spells to help your units, so you can attack enemies actively, heal the allies, etc. All of this is not free, of course you need resources.

I can't talk too much about story because I'm skipping most of the dialogs, but it is not crap. The characters are good (one of them, Slak, is a fucking god).

The difficulty... well, I can't say too much, because if you get stuck on one level you can beat previous levels on a higher difficulty level to level up your characters.

I really recommend this game to people who like tower defenses.

I hate when TD games are overly simplistic and require very little strategy to win. Even when your characters are max level and you've obtained all the best gear it's still quite hard in the later stages of NG+.  Unit placement is extremely important as well as choosing the right skills/passives for your characters based on the level you're playing. On that note, the game has quite a few levels in the main storyline along which a bunch of bonus levels in the NG+ mode. The artwork is nice and the story is pretty decent. The characters are very likable and a bit comedic at times. I usually mute games and play my own music but I rarely did that with this game, the soundtrack is quite enjoyable. Overall I would give the game a solid 8/10. Looking forward to playing the second game when it's released.

8996272.review:
To start off, I just wanted to state that I am NOT a fan of tower defense type games. I find them repetitive, grindy, bland, and not innovative.

BUT, Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is a true gem in the tower defense genre. It combines the elements of a tower defense game along with rpg elements, which gives the game a surprisingly fun twist. Instead of just placing troops that do not have meaning around, I was able to level up my characters and as I progressed I learned their stories.

Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is not only a tower defense game, it has a story, unlike many games of the same genre. The story was nothing special, but there was a story nonetheless.

If you're an achievement hunter (whore) like I am, then you'll be disappointed because a few of the achievements are a bit grindy. On the other hand, the developers were nice enough to allow you to go into the Options and increase exp and gold gain by 300%. I cannot stress enough how this option is amazing and that I think more devs should implement it, because of how grindy some achievements are. This also makes the game a little bit more on the easier side. I hardly ever lost a round. I can count on both hands how many times I've lost. 

The game is very simple, I was able to beat the base game without generic recruits. I did recruit the generic characters in order to obtain all the gold stars/side quests. The UI is also very simple. Skill trees are simple. Everything about this game is very simple, easy to learn, and relaxing.

If you're looking for a casual game, then I'd definitely recommend this game. A lot of times, I find myself on this game when I am watching tv or a movie.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten. It's a true gem of it's genre and should not be dismissed so easily, just because it's a casual tower defense game.

8974726.review:
Let me start by saying one thing: I don’t like TDs. Too many of them revolve around mechanics I consider boring, such as interest, and generally, they don’t offer much beyond the core, basic gameplay expected from the genre. With that out of the way, I’ll try to explain how Defender’s Quest won me over.

It’s impossible not to mention the fantastic writing present in the game: The story is overall serious, but the script makes no commitment to sounding mature or gritty. To the contrary: while some may argue the cast is composed of very standard archetypes, it’s still highly varied, and the humorous exchanges between the characters are a joy to see. Ironically, it’s their likability that makes the story much easier to care about, not presentation or “visceral” experiences. Take notes, games industry.

While I’m at it, the soundtrack is also a very strong point, and is included in the game’s folder for free. Plot and music are hardly all the game has to offer, though. As I said, I don’t like TDs and what impresses me the most about Defender’s Quest is how it carefully avoids annoying mechanics I’ve come to associate with the genre.

In this game, you don’t have to worry about insane resource management (interest) or fast finger movement (since you can pause mid-wave). It’s only about character loadout and positioning. That doesn’t mean it’s easy, but that it’s the right kind of hard. That it offers depth.

Going through the game should take you about five hours, but that can increase tenfold if you try to finish all level variations and challenges. For me, it clocked at just over sixty hours, and was definitely worth its price. I can recommend it to anyone looking for a twist on the traditional TD formula.

8962293.review:
This game is quite addictive and I've been impressed with the details that provide a lot of replay value. As with any tower defense game, your goal is to prevent enemy units from reaching your tower. In this case, your tower is a librarian who has obtained magical powers to battle in the realm between life and death. To defend herself, she can cast some magic spells and she can pull her allies (berserkers, archers, healers, knights, ice mages, and dragons) into her realm and position them for defense. Besides the librarian, all units act on their own once placed. The defenders' skills and the librarian's spells can all be leveled up by earning experience. The skill trees, along with armor and weapons, provide the ability to customize each defender's strengths.

What makes the game addictive is the variation. Each battle provides a different set of enemies and a different map with sometimes challenging unit placement options. As the game progresses, the type, number, and skill of available defenders increases which provides for different strategies to be employed. Each battle can also be completed at one of four difficulty levels, with higher levels producing different, more powerful, more numerous enemies. Completing battles perfectly (with no tower damage) unlocks bonus levels for additional variation. Once the main story is completed (10 - 20 hours depending on replays, bonus levels, etc.), a "Play+" option allows the story to be run again, this time with additional side quests, newly-enhanced enemies, upgraded weapons/armor, etc. The librarian's journal is also unlocked, adding some more humor to the game (which was already very light hearted in tone).

And I must say I wasn't disappointed. It's not as confusing at it appeared and after some playing around its actually quite easy after you get the basics but there is still a challenge to it. I highly recommend the game on it's concept, design, story, and characters. And will probably keep coming back long after i'm done.

Probably the best Tower Defense game I've played, ever. I've never been so engrossed in TDs since the WC3 modding era. Sprinkle in RPG elements into a TD game and you have a winning formula and a meta game that stretches beyond each stage. You can level up your units, equip them with armor/weapons and teach them spells - these units are esentially your 'towers'. Loveable cast of characters and tons of replayability, there's even a new game plus+ mode and hero mode achievements if you're looking for a challenge.

Only downside is that there should've been more classes (tower variations). Overall a very enjoyable and engrossing experience. Found myself constantly playing into the wee hours of the night. Must buy, and do pre-order Defender's Quest 2 while you're at it.

8957547.review:
What sets this game apart from Bloons? What makes it more entertaining than most TD's I've played? I'd say it's the story and different kinds of gameplay styles that seamlessly make its way into the regular gameplay. It has so much content, finishing the final level only means that you have the New game+ and new side quests to explore. The comedic dialogue, though not the greatest, does provide an interesting read. The 'towers' or more specifically, classes, vary in type and techniques. There's not a whole lot of grinding, which plagues most RPG's. It's a simple game to learn and is easy to pick up. There's little to no penalty to losing a wave (though you can actually change that if you'd like in the options) and the game should run fairly well on most computers. It does rarely crash, though the game autosaves for you so no harm done there. It's not overwhelming for the casual player, and it provides a good challenge for the competitive types.

Plus, you can get friggin' dragons in your party for god's sake.

8934140.review:
Sehr gutes Tower Defense Spiel mit stimmiger RPG-Komponente und guter deutschen Übersetzung.
Die Türme sind Charaktere aus 6 verschiedenen Klassen, jeder Turm-Char steigert genau wie der Hauptchar seinen Level mit erspielter XP. Jeder Char kann individuell geskillt, eingefärbt und ausgerüstet werden. In jeder Mission kann ein Char maximal 4-mal upgedatet werden.
Jede Missionen ist in vier Schwierigkeitsgraden spielbar und das ganze Spiel kann später im Plusmodus nochmals durchgespielt werden, auch dann gibt es wieder 4 Schwierigkeitsgrade. Der Weg der Gegner kann nicht beeinflusst werden und man kann einzelne Wellen nicht zurückspulen.

Dieses Spiel gehört zur oberen Spitzenklasse der Tower Defense Spiele, besonders stark ist es in den folgenden Bereichen:
 - Ausgefeilte Spielmechanik
 - Sehr gute Einstellungsmöglichkeiten für die Zieleprioitäten der einzelnen Türme
 - Großartige RPG-Einbindung und Geschichte für ein TD-Spiel
 - Gut balancierter und ansteigender Schwierigkeitsgrad der Karten
 - Für jeden Schwierigkeitsgrad eigens zusammengestellte Gegnerwellen und Eintrittspunkte
 - Die Präsenz der Entwickler im dazugehörigem Steam-Forum
 - Auch Monate nach Verkaufsstart wird sich um auftretende Probleme gekümmert.

[u]Fazit[/u]
Die alte Version hatte mich trotz der einfachen Grafik gefesselt, wie kaum ein anderes Tower Defense Spiel. Seit Juni 2016 gibt es nun eine HD-Version mit verbesserter Grafik und das Spiel begeistert mich mich erneut. :)

Weitere Empfehlungen zu Tower Defense Spielen:
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/8896126/

As a person who started his TD career in WC2/SC i'd say this is some of the most fun I have had playing a tower defense game. Instead of using Towers you call forth allies to your astral plane (Current Map) to help defend yourself from Revenent's (The bad guys). 

There are several different Allies to choose from and each ally can be specifically tailored for any given purpose. There is a suprising amount of depth involved in deciding where to place your unused talent points. Each character is Namable and has cosmetic customizable options. Naming a Character after yourself makes you want to use that character which is alot of fun to role play. If your into that sort of thing.The town's have places to recruit new allies and buy new weapon and armor. 

The map plays out alot like Mario World or the equivalent and you can go back and beat older levels on harder diff's to get better gear and level. There is also a storyline written by some type of Wrinting/English major and the writing isn't too terrible. Some if it will give you a laugh and some will just make you scratch your head. But all in all this game is a lot of fun and is definitely worth the little money asked.

-Casey

JUEGAZO, eso es lo que tenemos aqui, le da una vuelta de tuerca a los Tower Defense añadiendo toques de RPG. Comenzamos el juego con Azra, nuestra heroína. En cada fase tendremos que evitar que los enemigos la alcancen, para ello a medida que avance la partida se nos iran uniendo compañeros que podremos invocar en el campo de batalla para defendernos. Hay 6 clases de personajes, cada una con sus pros y sus contras, que ganarán experiencia al final de cada fase. Por si esto fuera poco, cada clase tiene un arbol de habilidad que podemos recorrer como queramos, de forma que dos personajes de la misma clase pueden ser totalmente diferentes (podemos tener dos magos uno destinado a ralentizar enemigos y otro a hacer mucho daño magico). 6/10

-= READ =-

Don't be fooled with the rating even though I recommend this. I've spent hours analyzing while playing this game. It all boils down to several pros/cons


+ You can level up your units
+ You can go back to the stage you've done to train
+ Each stage has different level settings and rewards so you don't have to toggle difficulty
+ Different combinations to try out
+ Story is funny as much as it is serious
+ Multiple Endings?

- Story does get boring so I'm glad theres comedy in it
- After awhile, you get tired of the grind
- Story is short
- Once you reach that point where you're no longer playing but "working" through the game. Typical for most rpgs
- Limited content


With that said, I still recommend this game. It leaves you to wonder how much potential it has and hope the devs do a much better version next installment. It was enjoyable while it last. And don't let the price scare you. If you guys actually spent time learning how much time, effort and your own money is spent to develop the game... you wouldn't be b**ching and moaning about games being expensive. That's why you read reviews like this to help you make a better decision :P

I first played this game in an early stage on Kongregate, and only played the free bit. Found it on sale and remembered liking the mechanics, so I picked it up and have been very impressed.
The first playthrough was about what you'd expect.  Some fresh mechanics and good dialog.
But the game really shines in NG+.
They introduce side quests which might have detracted from the first playthrough, unique item upgrades to give more playability, and most impressive, a journal of the protagonist through the events in the game.  That journal alone makes a second playthrough worthwhile.

8895529.review:
Defender's Quest ist eine Bombe unter den Tower-Defendern. Die an den Gameboy Colour oder an den RPG Maker erinnernde Grafik, tut dem keinen Abbruch. Die Suchtspirale dreht sich noch schneller als in anderen vergleichbaren Titeln. Gerade die RPG Elemente steigern die Langzeitmotivation ins unermässlich. Hier ein besseres Schwert, da ein besserer Bogen oder vielleicht doch lieber einen Heiler oder Ritter mehr?

Dass die Tower hier durch Ritter, Magier, Bogenschützen und anderen Figuren aus dem klassischen Rollenspielgenre entstammen, verleiht dem ganzen Spiel eine schöne Atmosphäre in die man gerne und vor allem immer wieder eintauchen möchte. 

Die Musik untermalt die Kulisse und die Kämpfe sehr passend und wirkt an keiner Stelle im Spiel aufgesetzt oder nervtötend. 

Der Schwierigkeitsgrad steigt angenehm, führt aber nicht zur totalen Unterforderung. Gerade zur Mitte des Spiels wird es sogar fast notwendig vorangegangene Level auf einem höheren Schwierigkeits zu spielen, um bessere Waffen und neue Helden ordern zu können. Dies stört allerdings in keinster Weise den Spielfluss, sondern senkt lediglich die Frusttrationsgrenze.

Ein wirklich schönes Feature ist, dass die "Türme" und die Heldin nach jedem Kampf, egal ob gewonnen oder verloren, XP erhalten und so im Laufe des Spiels weiter aufsteigen und neue Fähigkeiten freischalten. Da ich bis zum Schluss nicht alle Fähigkeiten erspielen konnte, bleibt die Langzeitmotivation auch nach dem ersten Durchspielen, immerhin 12 Stunden Spielzeit, weiter erhalten.

Ein klare Kaufempfehlung für alle die gerne Leveln und denen ein Funkeln in den Augen steht, wenn links und rechts die Feinde darnieder gehen.

8895318.review: Fun game, enjoyable mix of strategy/RPG/Tower defense. It has a bit of a storyline to it although it's not the best writing. Some of the stuff the characters say is kind of funny at times though. It does however get a bit repetetive after a while and beating heroic difficulties requires playing maps over and over to level up your characters which I just didn't have the dedication to do. But overall it was a fun experience. Note - I only paid about $1.75 for the game when it was on sale. I found it to be worth that but it may not be worth the full price. 8892939.review:
When I first read reports about Defender's Quest and watched the initial trailer, I was expecting a pretty standard RPG plot and characters. Much to my delight, I was half-wrong. The plot might be your tried and true "unlikely hero saves the world because, well, destiny" fare, but the characters and the writing are frequently reminiscent of the humor that characterized the Penny Arcade: OTRSPOD games. 
One notable feature of the game is that it does engage in some of the good, old-fashioned grinding that some RPGs are famous for, but this game lets you control just how "grindy" it is, giving you control of how much XP and scrap (money) that you receive at the end of each battle. This allows players to either keep the default settings and go through the basic plot, or to turn up the rewards to max so that they don't have to spend days grinding the same level over and over for XP so that they can run the special challenges. 
Each level has four settings ranging from Casual, where enemies have lessened HP and damage potential, to Extreme, where you better be ready because foes will WRECK an underpowered group. Playing extreme challenges unlock rewards for your party, giving you unique equipment and larger XP and scrap rewards, so there is a reason to tackle these challenges.
A new game+ feature is a welcome sight, and the fact that this mode allows you to unlock upgrades for your unique gear gives you an incentive to play again. 
Overall, I found the game to be fun and engaging, well worth the price of admission.

The colorful dialouge keeps the story somewhat fresh, but the real meat to this game is in the combat and preperation. 8888643.review:
When I bought the game I thought "well, there's just another TD game". But, it turns out that it's not your average build and kill game. For the first 4 hours I've been trying to finish up the story of the game. The story took me in and I just wanted to know how it all ends. If you are thinking about buying this game read on to see why you probably should. 

After playing 12 hours of the game I have finished the main story and went on to do some harder difficulties and other challenges. This game is fun in it's own unique way. Not only do you get an interesting story to follow, but also get stuck in character menu thinking how you should level up the skills for each fighter. 

The only hotkey you will probably need to remember is "space bar" for pause. That is the only thing you will constantly hit to allow yourself some time to think before everything goes to hell. The game can be challenging even on the normal level. [i]( The level difficulties go as follows: Casual – Normal – Advanced – Extreme)[/i]. After your done with Normal, you can move on to a New Game+, which is way harder and more challenging. 

And yes, this is an RPG game. You will probably spend more time looking at the level up menu for characters rather than fighting monsters. It's not bad at all, but be prepared to think and compare different builds for the same class of fighter. There are 7 types of characters – Berserker, Ranger, Healer, Ice mage, Knight, Dragon and Librarian ( who is the thing that you actually need to protect).

The simple graphics was also done in a pretty good way. All characters are different and you can easily tell the difference. Everything looks the way it should in this kind of game. The only thing I noticed is that when the Ice mage casts his spells it can be quite hard to see the enemy and how much health they still have. On a positive note, the graphics look smooth overall and you won't feel like your playing the game from the 80's at the same time. To add to this I can also point out that the soundtrack is very good. It fits the theme of the game very nice and allows you to feel emotions from the battle field and from dialogues. 

I am yet not sure how many hours you can play until you finish everything, but I would guess it's quite a bit. I think this game will keep you from sleeping for at least a few hours after you should have gone to bed. 

I honestly think that this game is a must have product for not just RPG and TD lovers but also for average gamers. If you have missed the sale don't worry, you won't regret buying a game for a full price.

8869709.review:
저의 스팀 라이브러리 50번째 게임입니다.

스크린샷만 봤을때는 재미 없어 보였지만, 유저평가가 워낙 후하길래 구입해봤는데... 정말 재미있습니다! 평범해질 수 있는 타워디펜스에 적절하게 RPG요소를 잘 섞어넣었습니다.

타워디펜스 부분을 칭찬하자면, 기존 타워디펜스는 해당 스테이지에 실패해서 다시 할 경우 똑같은 조건으로 다시 해야하는 경우가 대부분이지만, 이 게임은 RPG요소 덕분에 스테이지를 실패해도 경험치 등 얻는 부분이 있기 때문에 재도전 때는 결과적으로 난이도가 상대적으로 낮아지는 친절한 시스템을 가지고 있습니다. 또한 게임 중 속도조절이나 타게팅 설정 등이 쉽다는 점도 좋습니다. RPG부분은 스킬(스탯)을 재분배하고 싶을때 초기화가 가능하다는 점이 맘에 듭니다.

참고로 스팀 클라우드를 지원하는 게임이지만 기본 설정은 꺼져있습니다. 스팀 라이브러리가 아닌 본 게임 안에서 Options → Miscellaneous → Cloud Saves → On으로 설정하시면 됩니다.

Увлекательный "Tower Defence". В качестве "башен" выступают герои нескольких классов, имеющие собственные навыки и оружие. Героев, их скиллы и оружие можно приобретать только между миссиями. Чтобы пройти очередную миссию как минимум на нормальной сложности иногда необходимо вернуться к уже пройденным, и пройти их на более высокой сложности, получив дополнительный опыт, деньги и оружие, и только затем продвигаться дальше. В какой-то мере это выглядит как гринд, но здесь он не так однообразен как в играх подобного жанра: все уровни уникальны, долго задрачивать одно и то же место не заставят. С повышением сложности добавляются новые, более сильные враги и дополнительные волны. Это же позволит пройти игру на 100%. Нужно это или нет каждый решит сам. На легкой сложности игра проходится без всяких проблем. На нормальной - придется малость погриндить, но получаемая награда того стоит.
Можно смело рекомендовать игру всем любителям жанра "Tower Defence", любителям минимализма и обладателям слабых пека. А также тем, кто ищет мини-игру для убийства множества часов свободного времени. Это затягивает.

8866365.review:
A fun spin on the tower defence genre. Adding character growth and party management similar to something like Final Fantasy Tactics stop it from becoming stale like a lot of other tower defence games. The stat trees don't seem especially deep, but they're interesting enough in the early game and everything seems well balanced.

The story is simple but well told, the art style is also very simple (the 6th party member/character type in particular looks a little goofy) but the character of the game shines through it, and your party members are all expressive, interesting and actually quite charming. Lots of good, strong female characters here as well which is refreshing.

Each level has an advanced and extreme version, which will require you to come back later when you're stronger. They're unnecessary to progress, but they will give you extra goodies if you go back and do them.

Currently on sale for $1.50, which is a steal, I'd consider it well worth it at the regular $15 for fans of good tower defence or tactics based RPGs.

8865793.review:
Seeing how the game was flash based and not too heavy on visual details, I was skeptical about this game. I usually compare tower defense and flash to something on Kongregate, but I was pleasantly surprised by the quality. Its a Tower-Defense RPG hybrid where your 'towers' level up as you progress through the maps. Each stage has extra difficulties to come back to for additional challenge and rewards through unique armor or weapons that you can give to your teammates. You can change the AI for targeting, which comes in handy during challenge stages and boss fights. When you're done with the game, you can also replay the game with New Game+ and unlock your previous team (while facing minions with new abilities, and unlocking unique item powers). The story isn't anything new, but the characters are engaging enough to let that slide. The music isn't anything to write home about, but it strays from being too annoying like most flash looped music (the title screen being the exception).  

If you like Tower Defense games, Defender's Quest is polished in the right places and worth the weight, especially on sale.

8865753.review: Are you looking for an old school RPG mixed with tower defence? ... No?... well you should because this game is awesome! Witty story mixed with fun combat, Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten will be the cause of taking you away from socialising for many hours. From the start where you have only one berserker defender who is about as inappropriate as a fat guy in a speedo... to the ending where you have a multitude of dragons who for some reason look like they are grinning at me in some kind of sneaky/pedo like fashion .  You will be entertained by the dialogue and the awesomeness of slaughtering more enemies than you can shake a stick at. Pick it up for $1.45 on the steam sale and you will not be upset.

8865555.review: Love it love every minute of it

8865544.review:
Let me premise by saying that I'm a fan of Tower Defense game and purchased this game at 90% off for a grand total of $1.49, as such, this game was an absolute steal!

The game feels well paced, making sure you have the ability to beat the next level with adequate skill, but rewards you for taking the time to perfect a level. If you're looking for a deeper challenge, you can replay earlier levels at a higher difficulty, or if you're feeling stuck or underpowered you have the option to go back a few levels until you're prepared to advance.

The actual game itself revolves around a band of characters replete with customizable appearances, skills, invetory, and a set base class that allows for a wide variety of playstyles and setups. The actual mechanics of the game are designed to allow you to either place your towers (units) down and work from there, or micromanage them for greater effect. As you progress you'll be unlocking spells to engage you further and allow for more in depth strategy.

That all being said, I find myself falling most in love with the games charming and quirky characters that really sell the rather contrived story. Through the course of the game you'll meet a wide variety of personalites that play off of each other with a dry sense of humor and extremely comedic results. They each feel consistant and defined, and it's always a pleasure to see how they interact when they're not dealing with the plot. Even the main character has witty dialogue and interplay with the party, making you feel legitimately connected to people who are essentially stationary sources of damage in the actual game.

The only point that could be held against it is the fact that the graphics and art style feel 'cheap'. The world map and actual gameplay is set in the old sprite style that we've all seen for the past few decades, and it makes the game feel dated. When you're watching the games cutscenes, you're stuck looking at a few stationary characters that look like the bastard combination of paper cutouts and Protector characters. It's nice that they took the time to set up full cutscenes and dialogue, but the graphics just aren't there.

As it stands, I'd say that this game is a real gem. On sale for 90% I'd say 'buy it' every time no matter who you are. If you find it on sale for anything over 25%, at least give it a good look, hopefully you'll like what you see. For the full price of $15, it's still a great game for fans of the genre.


This has been Necromanticer and 'Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten' is my favorite game in the Citadel

8862468.review: I like this game more than most because it captures a young adult aesthetic that i think is lacking in video games today. There's the "kiddie" games that try to be completely unoffensive and appealing to all ages, and the "mature" games that are filled with blood, but there's hardly anything that successfully matches the charm of the former with the seriousness of the latter. Defender's Quest, with its cute characters and satisfying buildup and resolution of tension, succeeds with flying colors.

8862016.review: Though I may not be one to play many tower defense games, this one has really grasped my attention. At first glance, it may look like a bit of a low graphic, and average drawn out sprites/characters, but that's not where the game is supposed to shine. Even the, the story is surprisingly detailed, and you learn to appreciate the characters. Where it shines most is the gameplay itself! A great game to have in windowed mode while doing other things, it's a pleasant distraction, very refreshing, and easy to learn. There is a ton of depth with characters having their own skill trees, each defensive unit becoming special in their own way. It has good areas to level up quickly if you want to power up, but it doesn't feel necessary. In fact, the game has a good pace, and you could pick it up and play just a few minutes, or a few hours! The ability to slow down, pause, or speed up combat is so pleasing to have also, allowing me to follow a flow I'm comfortable with, never too pressured, but always leaving you thinking. I highly recommend it for the price, and tower defense lover would enjoy this, and even those new or not keen on the genre will feel comfortable with it. I know I was!

8861151.review:
I have always found it really hard to get into the serious RPG game genre like "Final Fantasy" and "Chrono trigger", not because I dislike the hundreds of hours you have to put into it but the actual combat system have always been booring to me. It gets old way to fast and I get sick of it after a few hours, no matter the great story or character developement I never came back to those games. It was more of a pain and tedious grinding than fun and epic adventure.

"Defender's Quest" however kept me in my seat. It's basically an RPG mixed with tower defense, the best of both worlds if you ask me. I like everyone else play tower defense games because of it's gameplay, which is why this game is great. I took out the part that I hate in RPGs and replaced it with one of the most replayable gametypes that there is, which makes me wonder why no one have come up with this earlier. 

It seems that alot of games are jumping on the "Mix RPG with other genres" train which really makes me happy to see. This game is great from what I've seen so far and great for anyone who have always wanted to get into RPGs but been scared of due to the grindy and difficult gameplay. I have played "Final Fantasy XIII" and didn't know what the heck I was doing 15 hours into the game, it felt like a fancy pokemon without the fun. I'm currently only 6 hours in and feel comfortable already, 

Yes this game is hard and you will have to grind to get the best gear. However, each level has a difficulty setting like any mobile game, making it really easy if you want to speed through the story, still providing a challenge and bonuses for those willing to get them.

I am currently only 6 hours in I cant wait to play more, I'm just hoping the game is as lengthy as an actual RPG, which if it isn't might be off putting. And it's worth noting that I only stopped played due to a game crash, it is the first time it has happened so I cannot say if it i a regular.

Either way I do sincerely recommend this game, it is currently on sale, definitely worth it for the price tag, grab it now to save some cash.

This is by far my favorite tower defense game. It combines the fun of an RPG with a TD. It comes with six classes, tons of skills for each and loot to equip. Each level has 4 difficulty modes as well as a second playthrough with a bunch of challenges to master as well. This game is a whole lot of bang for the buck and I can't recommend it enough.

If you ever need proof that Flash Games can be worth paying for, take a look at this.
With so many TD games out there, it's hard to choose a good one. This is a good way to ease into the genre, with solid mechanics and just a sprinkling of plot and simple yet engaging characters. Mix in a little touch of RPG elements for upgrades and skill trees for your human "Towers" and here you are. There are many routes to victory, and challenging achievements to encourage you to try replaying with a different strategy. You get what you pay for and because it's built in flash it runs on ANYTHING! Worth a pop at the price, even more so in a sale.

8854315.review:
Очень годный коктейль из Башенной защиты и ролевой игры с простенькой незамысловатой графикой.

В качестве "башен" буду различные войны. Например, лучник, рыцарь, маг, каждый из которых по своему уникален. Нам придётся расставлять их на поле боя, чтобы защитить нашу героиню от наступающей нечисти. После окончания уровня наши "войны-башни" получают опыт, который можно потратить на новые способности или же улучшить уже имеющиеся. 
Сама героиня тоже не бездействует : Можно ударить близко подобравшихся неприятелей молнией, заморозить их, ускорить наши башенки и другое.

После тяжёлых сражений можно будет забежать в ближайшую деревню, чтоб купить новых наёмников и экипировку.

Плюс ко всему имеется неплохой сюжет и забавные диалоги между нашими героями. Музыкальных композиций не так много, но они довольно хороши.

В общем крайне рекомендую любителям TD, игра очень уникальна в своём жанре, таких мало где найдёшь. Да ещё и вторая часть на подходе.

Лучники имбы!! :) 8 / 10

8853009.review:
The first tower defense game I played was Desktop Tower Defense, a simple game that is on a grid and sends wave after wave of enemy at you.  This was a fun game mechanic and it would pop up with different themes in different games through the years. But, it was not until Defender’s Quest: Valley of the Forgotten that I found a game that used that mechanics to great effect in an Role Playing Game fashion.

The opening of the game shows you as the main character being dragged out of her house and thrown into the Pit. She has the plague but also realizes she has special powers.  From here it opens the ability to play the game.  She can bring warriors into the Half-Way Realm and allow them to kill the revenants, monsters people turn into after they die of the plague. The story starts taking twists from there as you follow what has really been happening to two kingdoms and what the ultimate goal is.

There are a host of characters that arrive in the game and each comes with their own personality.  The first people you find are barbarians, who wear no armor and are humorously suicidal in their combat tactics. Then you meet the rangers, who are far more practical about their need for survival. Each of the units you meet have a person who is going to be seen in cut scenes and helps give you a feel of the personality of that unit.

Each of the units levels up, gains new skills, and can even be upgraded with new equipment.  Most of this is done in towns.  When in a town you can recruit units you have access to, but need to keep a close eye on the cost as the more units you have, the higher the price for the next one.  Gear comes in two main forms armor and weapons. There are also things that your main character can equip, but those mainly augment her abilities and are not purchasable.  When a character gains experience they level up just like you would expect in a normal RPG. Each unit has a skill tree with two branches. This means one barbarian might do a lot more damage and another might recover from wounds faster, it is up to you how you want them to work.

This game was not  anywhere on my radar and that is sad because it is a great game.  The units seem well thought out so as to be different and fit a certain use at a certain time. The story told through still frames is well done with attention to facial expressions and a great sense of humor. This game is a great one, and the team at Level Up Labs is already working on another.

8851767.review:
Defender's Quest is a Tower-Defense/RPG Hybrid (Think Final Fantasy Tactics meets Tower Defense).

Defender's Quest tightly focuses on three things: tactical depth, customization, and story. That means no random encounters, no spikey-haired emo kids, no forced time sinks, and no tedious, repetitive battles.

The battle system builds off of tower defense, with individual characters taking the place of towers. Each character levels-up, learns skills, and equips gear individually, allowing the player to customize their battle experience and strategy. The overall game structure is similar to "tactical" RPG's, but with a real-time battle system. Game speed is adjustable, and commands can even be issued while the game is paused.

It also features an engaging, character-driven story written by an actual English major! The story strives to be fast-paced, snappy, and always relevant to gameplay. Events and dialogue explain things as they become relevant to the player, minimizing exposition. 

Finally, it's got options and accessibility settings out the wazoo, so that you can have the best possible experience!

8851754.review:
Never expected this much from this game.



As usual I logged on Steam and found this on sale with just 1.49 USD.
Looking at the screenshots it seems like it has some RPG-maker graphics and it is a tower defense game.
Man I am really not a fan of tower defense but after scrolling down the review section I see a lot of thumbs up; so I decided to give it a try.

And it sucks.... ME IN!

The game plays like traditional tower defense, with RPG elements like levelling up, buying armour and upgrading skills.
This gives a feeling of progression since in more traditional tower defense game its all about strategy. Every battle is a new battle, nothing carries on to the next level.

In this game, your heros are permanent allies. You recruit them from towns, form your own little army and grow them accordingly to your preference. 

Story wise its ok and the dialogues are funny at times. The presentation of the whole game is quite neat and easy on the eyes so you dont get alot of useless stuff displaying to you.

There seems to be quite alot of levels as well as a new game plus where you get unique stuff and enemies which adds replayable value.

The only downside is that it seems the skill tree could get some more diversity. Like it would be awesome if a standard warrior can have different styles or something.

But all in all this is a solid game and is definitely worth grabbing during this 1.49 USD sale. The fun far exceeds the cost. But if you missed the sale and it goes back to 14.99, I would recommend you to think twice before buying.

8851250.review:
I'll admit I am biased; I absolutely love this game.
The writing is smart and to the point. It gives these characters who could've fit a dull archetype much more personality and energy. There is both levity and gravity. Our leading ladies are represented very well and are good examples of female characters.
Gameplay is very user friendly, but in a good way. It doesn't matter if you are new to Tower Defense games or a pro, you can customize the game to fit your wants. Want a challenge but don't want to grind? Crank up the exp and only use the main characters. Is it kicking your butt? Decreased the penalty for losing. It's very intuitive.
Music although noted to be repetitive suits the mood very well. The mood of peril and danger is conveyed very well and the music is catchy enough to be memorable.

Here's a TL;DR
The Good
+Great writing
+Challenging but not required
+Anti-grind measures
+Replayability with New Game Plus

The Bad
-Flat character designs
-Certain maps with a lot of action can slow down computers
-Will likely have to resort to using the lightning spell which makes it a click-fest

Among the many, many other TD games, this game rises far above crowd.

It adds another layer of depth outside of the TD with progression and can be a difficult game but very rewarding in the end. If you are a fan of TDs especially wc3 ones, definitely tell you to give this one a try.  The only thing is your character is always a girl so there isnt anything you can do about it.

8850746.review:
I know there are a ton of tower defense games out there... and even a few that propose to add RPG-like elements.  Defender's quest is different, and different good.  The game strikes that perfect balance by replacing the "towers" with NPCs.  The difficulty ramp-up is near perfect for a game and gives you as much challenge as you want without subjecting you to any levels where you fall off a difficulty cliff.  If something's just a little too hard, or you're trying to get a better result?  Level up your guys or buy them beter equipment.

Yes, the game runs at a fixed resolution and no, the cutscenes (which tell an engrossing tale) are done with limited animation, but that's really OK.   The limitations don't detract from the game and you can tell all of the love and time and effort went into perfecting gameplay and giving you plenty of it.  

If you're lukewarm on tower defense because you don't like the repetition, this game's for you.  If you're a die-hard TD fanatic, this game's for you.  Accessible, perfect ramp-up, plenty of content, and a story.  Definitely this game is one to get.
