8847914.review:
TL;DR: If you ever even remotely enjoyed a tower defense type of game, you seriously need to play this one. If you haven't but like rpgs, this is your best bet to find out what a great TD can be like, with the RPG elements to help carry you along. Really, if the (very generous) demo to this game doesn't get you hooked, then tower defense may simply not be your genre, and at least now you know. ;)

*** ***

Defender's Quest is one of those games that without too much fanfare and fancy graphics simply get gameplay right. The rpg elements are well embedded, the story is not just an excuse for progression, the dialogues are well written and funny, the music is good and sets the mood nicely - but it's really all just about the balanced, fun, just-one-more-level gameplay.

It takes place in a plague colony, where the afflicted are turned into horrors controlled by a necromancer master villain. Your hero realizes she's capable of bringing herself and her allies into a halfway world, where the horrors and ultimately the villain can be fought with. While this is a simple enough premise, the way it brilliantly ties the story to the game's mechanics is one of the stellar design aspects of the game. (More on that [url=http://www.fortressofdoors.com/story-telling-as-problem-solving-defenders-quest-gdc-2013-narrative-summit/]here[/url], if you're interested in game design).

Due to the fact that you customize the appearance of your pawns, equip them with weapons and armour, and train them towards permanent experience that you can put towards an interesting skill tree, you end up becoming more attached to them then if you just had "towers" to play with. Especially your set crew of 6 archetypical towers/heroes is a fun bunch with entertaining banter in the (skippable) cut scenes, and by the end of the game you are genuinely interested in their actions and story decisions.

I appreciated the attention to detail that allows you to customize both the difficulty and the game experience: active pause, different speed controls, highly configurable hotkeys, customizable general difficulty on top of the ability to replay maps on different difficulty levels (which actually play differently, instead of simply increasing the number of enemies or turning them into sponges). And then there's the Game+, which may just be even more fun to play than the normal game - if you can survive it. Plus, there's the sheep. Good luck with that. ;)

With its 30+ grindable main levels, the endless levels, a couple of different endings, a Game+, side missions to unlock and many interesting achievements, there is a very generous amount of content there for the price. Plus, a full HD/60 FPS upgrade is coming soon, for free, with redesigned graphics (the one aspect of the game that many may find lacking), so what more do you want?

Maybe what you want is Defender's Quest 2, which is expected to come out some time in 2016 - giving you plenty of time to finish playing 1 first. :)

8846608.review:
Defender's Quest – история в картинках

Сразу скажу, что это очень и очень достойный [b]Tower Defence[/b].
А теперь по порядку:
В игре есть даже незамысловатый сюжетец, про попадание в другой мир, получения сверхспособностей и злых чародеев, которых сразу выдают их хитрые глаза.  История раскрывается в рисованных диалогах на протяжении всей игры. Нарисовано все простенько, как в примитивных флеш играх . Но сам гемплей игры просто на такой большой высоте, что все остальное не так значимо.
По ходу сюжета игрок путешествует по карте, по заранее заданным точкам (аля Puzzle Quest). Каждая точка - это либо карта битвы, либо магазин, где ты можешь нанять новых воинов (да-да, количество башен ты набираешь перед боем). Перед покупкой можно задать им цветовую палитру и выбрать имя. Также каждой "башне" можно покупать более совершенное оружие, с лучшими характеристиками и прокачивать их самих. Т.е. у каждого воина в игре с победами повышается опыт. А при повышении уровня, распределяются очки на новые умения персонажа, которых к слову не так то и мало. Причем у каждого вида воина они свои.
Также стоит отметить, что главная героиня игры тоже повышает опыт и прокачивает умения.. И у неё тоже есть особые умения. Их можно использовать в битве. Такие умения, как - заморозка всех крипов на карте, лечение своих воинов и т.п.
На каждой карте есть 3 уровня сложности, так что удовольствие от прохождения длится в 3 раза дольше. Так как каждый новый раз проходить карту нужно по другому.
Про игру можно еще много чего рассказывать, но лучше в неё поиграть самому. Это отличный представитель жанра.
[b]Вердикт: [u]купить и играть 100%[/u][/b]

8846200.review:
Defender's Quest starts off as a pretty simple tower defence game with a goofy fantasy story and basic presentation, but then you start getting deeper into the game, unlock all the character classes and upgrade your characters more, and you find that there is actually a ton of depth and playability here. What's more, it never loses its intuitive and elegant design as it becomes more mechanically complex, and the game does a fine job of presenting you with a tough challenge but essentially giving you all the tools you need to overcome said challenge. Success is not determined simply by grinding to level up your characters, but rather by finding a way to better manage your resources until you find the optimal way to succeed.

This was one of my sleeper hits from 2013, and it's one of my favourite tower defence games on Steam, up there with Defence Grid: The Awakening and Plants vs. Zombies. It's a great starter tower defence game and introduces less experienced players to its mechanics in a very manageable way, but it also provides the depth and strategy that you just won't get from most of the free flash-based TD games you can find online. It's a fresh take on the genre and its very well executed...just don't expect to be too engaged by the cutscenes and character interactions that break up the combat missions. They're occasionally funny, but often rote and unnecessarily long. But that's just about my only criticism of the game - everything else is rock-solid.

8350061.review:
An original approach to story design and a nice take on tower defense, Defender's Quest places you in the role of Azra, a librarian who gets epic powers to fight the otherwise invulnerable undead.

The story has been designed from the ground up: taking the game mechanics of upgradable towers who gain experience to become stronger ("like an RPG"), a story to fit the mechanics has been devised. Quite like when you were presented with the task of making up a story and including certain words or characters, only Level Up Labs made a game out of that. The benefit is mostly avoiding pitfalls growing out of weird game mechanics. IMHO, while the story did not blow my mind it is still very fine and the result works quite well.

So, like any tower defense, you defend a place from creeps that have different stats and abilities by placing "towers". In this they're game characters who have their own class and the associated, developable skills, i.e. attacks, buffs and debuffs. Azra summons them up and places them into the labyrinth in suitable locations. Every character is useful and has their role: to spell it out no one works as an instakill device against everything. The enemies always follow shortest path towards Azra, so you can plan accordingly even when some enemies can swim. Finally, if the troops fail, you can beat the horde back with spells. Everything uses kills for money.

On the world map, you move along a linear path that sometimes diverges for sidequests. Every space is either a level with attacking waves of enemies or a town where you can buy weapons and armor and recruit troops. Story advances in every space so you're never bored unless getting stuck in a difficult level. That does not happen often, for the easy levels are really easy and you can even go to casual difficulty and/or set experience and money gain to 3x normal for faster leveling up without any penalty. You do get better rewards for higher difficulties, and to master a level it has to be beaten on extreme: this always rewards you with a special item granting the incentive for beating them all, if the associated achievement won't do it alone. You can also return to beat the levels again after you've grown in strength.

When the levels run out, there are several "challenge" levels to beat, two of which are of endless type with ever-so stronger incoming waves. After beating the game you can also give it another go with NG+ that is more difficult with monsters getting additional special abilities. NG+ also adds several additional sidequests and its own version of the challenges.

While the flash graphics aren't eye candy, the music is engaging and the residing mechanics will let you enjoy the game for several tens of hours. However, trying to beat every level perfectly can become tedious, for the levels get tougher and tougher as you advance. Typing this, I've yet to beat the last few levels on extreme. Still, I would heartily recommend the game for tower defense fans: I sure got a blast with it. I especially recommend going for the Hero Mode+ challenge (and to lesser extent the Hero Mode++).

아군 유닛을 적절히 배치하여 정해진 코스를 따라 이동하는 적들을 제거하는 전형적인 디펜스 게임이지만, 스토리 진행에 따른 전투가 메인이 되고 아군을 영입하여 레벨을 올리는 등 SRPG적인 요소가 강하게 반영되어 있는 독특한 게임이다.
디펜스 장르라면 당연히 갖추어야 할 유닛별 특성도 잘 살아 있는 편이고, 각 전투별로 4단계의 난이도를 제공하고 있어 캐주얼하게 즐기고자 하는 유저부터 하드코어 게이머까지 입맛에 맞게 플레이 할 수 있다. 또한 난이도별로 적들의 패턴과 클리어시 주어지는 보상이 다르기 때문에 이미 클리어한 전투라도 재도전 하여 반복플레이 할 가치가 충분히 있다.
대화 형식으로 진행되는 스토리는 나름 독창적인 편이고 영어 수준이 높은 편이 아니라 이해하기 어렵지 않은 편이다. 굳이 단점을 꼽으라면 그래픽이 좀 심하게 클래시컬 하다는 점과 인터페이스가 다소 난잡하다는 점 정도. 그러나 인터페이스의 경우에는 일단 익숙해지기만 한다면 거의 모든 컨트롤을 스타1마냥 단축키로 편리하게 처리할 수 있으므로 큰 단점으로 보기는 힘들 듯.
전체적으로 봤을때 매우 잘 만든 디펜스 게임이고, 유닛 육성요소와 다양한 난이도, 그리고 나름 흥미진진한 스토리가 잘 조화를 이룬 시간도둑형 게임이라 할 수 있다.
아, 그리고 현재 제작중인 후속작에는 '더스트 : 언 엘리시언 테일'에서 미려한 2D 그래픽을 보여주었던 디자이너 출신 제작자, '딘 도드릴'을 포함하여 다수의 외부 그래픽 디자이너가 참여한다고 한다. 후속작에서는 그래픽에 대한 걱정은 안해도 될듯 싶다.

Tower defense is not at all my jam, but Defender's Quest adds enough other stuff (and pulls of the defense part painlessly enough) that I've ended up really liking it. I'm only about halfway through, but, well, I was only expecting to dip my toes into it when I launched it today, and instead it ate up most of my evening.

Essentially it's tower defense game with RPG mechanics and a story. Like, a proper story, that gives most RPGs a run for the their money.  That and the RPG mechanics give an attachment to your characters (who act as the "towers"), and a sense of progression, that make this game so much more than most tower defense games. The game seems to reward focusing on a small but powerful party, and I just find "making my friends way better at murder" more rewarding than "build a bunch of catapults." Also, it's pretty funny.

There are a few problems; the art for the cutscenes is pretty bad (although the pixel art in battle is pretty charming.) Some of the humor falls flat or, more often, breaks character. And adding the pointless subtitle didn't make the name any less generic. Still, it's overall a fun and addicting experience.

7912818.review:
this game has bad art

the rest is AWESOME. story is good. gameplay is solid. 

if i were to describe the gameplay its something like an rpg, except the combat has been replaced by tower-defence. each character you meet that joins your army can be placed down on the map, then it will attack with whichever move is off cooldown at the time. it speaks for itself that you have to place these "towers" in an tactical superior way, so they help each other kill the revenants (zombie type mobs with a variety of mechanics such as, but not limited to, attacking back, being able to swim,..).

RPG:
despite this being part rpg this does not contain any "choice" as regards to storyline (except maybe 1, though its very clear which one is superior). you do get to pick traits out of trait trees and make every character unique in its fighting style. also you can equip all your characters with weapons and armor (except the last kind, though you will understand when you get there). different weapons do no have different boons, the more expensive ones simply do more damage. same goes for armor, the more money it costs the more defense it gives. the customizability is in the trait system, definitely not the equipment system.

tower defense:
each tower is unique, and at the end of every match you get xp and perhaps a trait point (lvl up) to decide how you want to build it. you can improve your tower during the match though, with the match currency called spi, this will give him/her access to more moves. you can not block paths, or build any kind of obstruction to make the mobs change course. this is one of the tower defense mechanics that is missing (can't have it all).

overall i would have gladly payed the full price for this game. it took me 20 hours to finish one playthrough 100%, and a short dabble in the new game+ feature. that is less then 1 euro per hour.

played it on a windows 7 ultimate laptop, 3.3Ghz, 8GB ram, 3GB nvidia gpu with only 2 crashes, and very rarely some fps drop.

7905783.review:
I bought this game before it was greenlit after seeing a WTF is... about it. Played it start to end twice in a row and had a blast all the way thru.

For those uninitialized: Defender's Quest is a Tower defense with heavy RPG elements. Your "towers" are characters you recruit thru progress of the game. You level them up and give them skillpoints and equip them with weapons and armors. Your characters will be with you the entire playthru and level up with your character. 

The goal per usual is to stop the enemies from reaching your "pool" and taking away from your life. This is done thru set mazes where the monsters have to follow a premade maze, so sorry, no mazing for you that like to build your own mazes in TDs. You progress thru a gameworld where you can face each stage in three various difficulties, the harder it is the better the reward. You can also backtrack to previously defeated levels to try it on a harder level or just grind for gold/xp for your characters.

The game also offers a fairly interesting story with alot of written dialogue with some pretty nice graphics to go along. The steam version also features updated graphics to the game which makes the game feel apropiate for the pricetag. 

A must have for lovers of classic Tower Defense games with a twist and interesting new mechanics.

7797551.review:
If one were pessimistic or dismissive, it would be easy to look at this Tower Defence game and dismiss it for being generic and dated-looking. However, that would be doing the game and the developers a real disservice.

Granted, the 16-bit style is one you're either going to like or not, but it is executed very well indeed, as the use of colour is very done so that it remains pleasing on the eye and never jarring. The execution and balance of the game overall is very polished, and belies the developers' size - it really appears to be well-tested and difficulty is a very smooth and progressive curve. 

Pacing is similarly excellent, and it definitely evokes that magic "just one more go" response. The icing on the cake is the story, which is nice and humorous without being too cheesy or vulgar, so it greatly appeals to a wide audience. As comedy is a very difficult thing to write, they have done a fantastic job here; it's very tongue-in-cheek, and it fits the game perfectly.

The meat of the game lies in having characters as your "towers" to place on a map. You can purchase extra characters to a maximum of 6 of each, and level them individually. The range of characters are well-defined (such as straight-up brawlers, archers, mages, healers, and even big ol' dragons), and afford some forethought as to their placing on the maps.

The length of the game is good, running at a good few hours minimum, but with the added replayability of New Game+ and more. Whilst the game might seem a little high for something that looks like an old game, it is well worth money, as it will entertain you from start to finish.

For fans of the genre, this is a must. Even for casuals, it's highly recommended.

7785630.review:
Defender's Quest is a novel rpg take on the tower defense genre. That in and of itself would make an interesting game, but the designers saw fit to include an interesting story to explain away the game mechanics as part of the plot. While the central theme of plague and the risen dead is dark, the dialogue between characters is lighthearted and oftentimes funny. Such a combination of serious undertones and bright interplay amongst the characters helped me enjoy the game quite a bit.

Insofar as the actual mechanics are concerned, this is not a "maze building" tower defense game. The enemies will come in waves along pre-defined paths with limited placement for your defenders (the towers, essentially) available. Defenders can be upgraded by "boosting" them through five levels which unlocks any abilities they may have earned through levelling and a rudimentary talent system. Speaking of levelling, this is where the rpg mechanic comes into play; every level gained by a defender gives you talent points which you can use to tweak the character and gain new abilities. While the talent system is very basic, it does give you a feeling of satisfaction to distribute your points when a defender levels or you gain access to a new class. 

While there are only six classes of defender to use in the game, the customization inherent in the rpg progression system means there is the possibility of some differentiation. Additional defenders can be recruited in towns across the game's story map, wherein the plot is advanced and new battlefields are opened up. In battle, these defenders are placed with the same resource you use for upgrading, but recruiting new defenders gets progressively expensive with the game's story mode currency (won through battle). That same currency is used for equipping your defenders with weapons and armor, so there is an opportunity cost. As additional currency can be won by going back and fighting harder versions of prior story mode battles at any time, you never truly feel strapped for cash.

As the game is 2d, the question isn't whether the graphics are advanced, but how good and cohesive they look. Cut scenes to advance the plot are drawn with a style which gels extremely well with the battle sprites and look pleasing to the eye. Opinions on art styles will vary, but the cleanliness and cohesiveness of the game's visuals can not be denied. There are no sloppy looking sprites in this game and your defender's colors can even be customized to a limited degree to further suit your tastes. 

Unfortunately, while the animations of your defenders (and especially that of a certain antagonist at the very end of the game) are fluid and pleasing to watch, the animations of the monsters which you are tasked to kill are very basic and stilted. Still, most of the time said monsters are drowning in a sea of pleasing damage numbers as your defenders are chopping them to pieces, so perhaps some gamers will be able to overlook this as I did.

According to steam, I was able to extract 13 hours out of this game and there are still bonus challenges to complete and a new game plus mode to experiment with. Whether that is worth the price of admission is a decision that I encourage you to weigh carefully if you would normally pass up a game based on length: it is lovingly crafted and an enjoyable experience that I can recommend to any rpg fan, even those who aren't familliar with tower defense games.

The long and short of it: 8/10, buy it.

7783644.review:
Never thought RPG and Tower defence genre could have a great cross-bred like this!

Like any other TD games out there, your main mission is prevent any enimies from reaching the party leader standing at the end of the road. The horde which is consist of a few types of zombies, slug-like creatures,... keeps coming in pre-defined routes. In fact, there's nothing quite unique in the mechanic of TD in this game.

However, the true gem lies in the RPG aspect of the game. What's a TD game without towers? Nah, your towers now are replaced by class-based characters ranging from a psychopath to a cute dragon. Many elements of RPG genre are brought into the game like skill tree, equipments and again, classes. Trouble with fast moving creeps, you have an Ice Mage to counter, or facing heavy armor zombies with the might of a Paladin.

Not every maps are so hard, but you still need to grind a little for exp and especially epic items. (well, not really that epic but atleast they have purple titles)

To be honest, you can't expect a long and heart-touching story with dozens of play time for such a small game like this, but for almost 3 hours so far I'm quite satisfied. 

Finally, thanks jatan11t/GAR for this lovely gift :)

7780680.review:
Tied in my mind with Defense Grid for best tower-defense game to date. Where Defense Grid's strength is the perfect distillation of the tower-defense formula, Defender's Quest remains toe-to-toe with it because of how it radically adapts the basic idea of tower-defense -- deploying stationary defenses along a path or series of paths -- to work with a highly original fantasy setting and a set of solid RPG-like mechanics. The presentation, while not sophisticated, is incredibly appealing, and the writing is nothing short of superb.  It's also endlessly replayable, and the New Game + mode actually gives you a reason to do so.

Highly recommended to everyone, tower-defense fans and non-fans alike.  As with Defense Grid, If you're a fan, you will like this; if you're not already, this stands a good chance of converting you, and if it doesn't, then you never have to wonder about another tower-defense game again, as you'll know it's just not your bag.

7779686.review:
I don’t like real time strategy or tower defense games, you can’t out click a computer and they usually cheat.  So it’s seem odd that I would even buy this game, let alone log 196 hours (wait, how many? I’m not even done with the Play+.)  What made the game appeal to me was the RPG element.  I like RPGs, it’s reassuring to know you can grind and level up to make up for your lack of skill and intelligence.
The game offers 25 stages plus bonus levels that are all replayable (didn’t realize that’s not a real word) at not just different difficulties but also with a different mix of enemies.  There are only six characters (towers) but each has 10 or so skills which adds to the variety.  There are 19 enemies including repallets (figured that wasn’t a real word) and five bosses.
The best part is the characters.  The dialogue and interaction is engrossing often hilarious.  The replay mode unlocks Azra’s diary with extra (also hilarious) insight to her background and the other characters (SPOILER ALERT!! Slak knows how to read and write.)  
In conclusion (that never gets old,) Defender’s Quest: title too long is a great mix of tower defense and RPG.  Most importantly, it’s fun.  If you had to pay all 15 bucks for this game, it’s worth it.  If it should happen to be on sale around Thanksgiving or Christmas (or whatever other holiday you celebrate on your fast track to hell) you’d be a fool not to buy it (unless you’ve got something better to do with 196 hours, like work.)

7746217.review:
Buy This:
If you love tower defense 
If you love 8 bit era RPGs
If you enjoy a humorous adventure starring a bunch of misfit heroes. 

Defender's Quest is another tower defense game with a few twists that put it above the curve. For starters, rather than building soulless towers that you have zero attachment to, you employ RPG style characters to defend your "Librarian." These characters can be named, stylized (to a slight degree with color options) and then leveled the more they're used. They each even have a system of perks that can be unlocked through the course of the campaign. You can employ as many as you can find the dosh for, but each requires "mana" to be deployed in battle. This is a finite pool that is replenished by killing baddies. The maximum mana you can have increases as your librarian levels as well, so in essence it is a clever way of keeping the player from throwing 70 towers up at the start of a new mission and steam rolling. 

The game also has a pretty humorous story line, and memorable main characters. There's unique items you can unlock for your favorite minions, and even a brutally hard Game+ mode if you desire even more once you finish the campaign. With such a low price point, this is a must have for people who like old school RPGs, tower defense style games or both.

The story is also quite interesting, and didn't feel like it was just tacked on to the gameplay; both aspects are very well realized.  I highly recommend this one for fans of the genre.

The units are well balanced and versatile, and the enemies return the favor.  You can set the pace of the battles at anytime, from a complete pause, to 4x "get this over with" speed.  You also have the option to control the difficulty to be as easy or as hard as you prefer.  Harder the challenge, the bigger the payoff.  Real strategy players are going to find the regular game a little too easy, but the game does offer unique challenges for the elite.  Gamers new to strategy games will find it very welcoming.  It is a game for every level of gamer, from casual beginner, to advanced tactician.

This is one of my favourite tower defense games to date. Having your "towers" be unique characters that individually equip items and level up adds a surprising amount of depth and customization to the game. It seems so simple, but it's a huge improvement over the generic towers of most games in the tower defense genre. 

Also, the game does a really good job of letting players dictate how difficult they want the game to be, and provides a good number of incentives to replay levels at harder difficulties (including powerful unique items). More games need to learn from this; let players decide how they want to play!

Add to that terrific targeting options for towers, fast-paced gameplay, steam workshop support, and even some nice music, and I am very impressed by this game. Highly recommended.

890212.review:
I'm not strongly into tower defense (TD) games, but this game does away with some of the downsides of tower defense games which bother me. Your towers are characters you gain as you progress in the story, or purchase at various points. Your team protects your summoner, and both the characters and summoner, gain XP after each battle (win or lose, although that can be adjusted). If the game becomes too hard, you can replay an earlier level for extra XP / scrap (the game's currency). However, replaying levels is not grindy-feeling, since each level can be played at three different difficulty levels, which is a different than just the same monsters with more HP (for example, sometimes there are additional spawn points and sometimes the monsters have additional bonuses). (And if you really don't like redoing levels for XP and scrap, you can increase the gain of each of them.)

Unlike some TD games, there is no pathing manipulation: the squares the characters can be placed on are different than the creeps' travel squares. That doesn't mean that character placement is permanent: it is sometimes useful to remove and re-place characters (especially in boss levels or the bonus levels available during the second playthrough).

Speaking of the second playthrough, that isn't just the same monsters, but more HP. Usually the second playthrough monsters have additional abilities, such as attacking your characters as they walk by, or become temporarily immune to non-area damage. The second playthrough also allows purchase or unlock of the best weaponry. Another nice touch is that switching between the first and second playthrough is just a matter of returning to the menu; your entire party and loot remains the same. (I worked a bit on the second playthrough, got stuck, went back to the first playthrough to do some of the harder difficulties of the levels, got stuck, went back to the second playthrough, et cetera.)

Besides your party characters, the summoner has a few spells that unlock while progressing through the story and can be increased as the summoner's level increases. These spells can help out during tight spots in earlier levels, and are pretty much required for the hardest levels.

Slak says to at least try the demo; pants are optional.

The tower defense aspect of this game is pretty unique if you havent played classic Warcraft 3 "Mauls" for example, you summon units to the field and can upgrade them with mana you gain from killing enemies. the kicker is these units are unique, you recruit them throughout the game and as you progress, they gain levels, skills, and equipment.

The character you play as (Azra) is even equippable with spellbooks, and levels like the others. in this case however you level spells that are castable anywhere on the field for mana, much like Sol Survivors abilities.

Each win you make gives you a multitude of currencies that are usable in the overworld, scrap (for items), Stars (for challenges and spellbooks), Skulls (for something I havent found yet), and sometimes unique items to equip your retinue with.

The story is pretty blasé, but it does the job of driving you forwards at least. Overall a very enjoyable game with a excellent blend of mechanics that work harmoniously and result in a plethora of entertainment.

Two thumbs up!

1047497.review:
This game, is awesome. 

It's a very refreshing aproach to the classic visualized RPG genre. It combines the best aspects of "Tower Defense" games and what's usually considered rpg-elements (even though I disagree on the common definition of what these are). The game itself doesn't give you much freedom of movement in general, you just kind of advance to one point of the story to the next, but that didn't actually bother me, surprisingly. 

One of the nicest aspects of the game is the option of giving every single one of the characters your group gets a name of your choice. There's always some dialog, main char asking "What's your name?" and you get a prompt asking you for a name, which is then used throughout the rest of the game (and can be changed if desired).

The game puts you in the shoes of "The Librarian" (her name will be asked for first) who has the unique ability to summon her allies (regular fighters, archers mages and the like) into a "spirit realm" where the undead, which make up the bulk of the enemies encountered in the game, can be actually made re-dead for good.
Therefore she's the one who needs to be tower-defended. The army of defenders consists of six different classes of units which can become six of each type (additional characters can just be recruited in towns for ingame scrap). They all level up and have skill that can be improved by the player with each levelup.

The dialogues and the general story is actually quite good and really really funny, all the characters are quite sympathetic and just lovely insane.
Also, the game has a neat turn when it comes to playing it a second time (new game+) because the second playthrough mode actually adds several new sidequest, an upgrade option for the unique weapons found during the first playthrough and a simply hilarious journal, which recieves entries every now and then as the journey progresses... extremely funny =D.

Even though the game seems to be a finished release, I gather there's still people working on it, so it might even get additional content updates.


Definitely recommended.

3861749.review:
The game describes itself as "Final Fantasy Tactics meets Tower Defense" which is actually fairly accurate. It's a tower defense RPG where you gain party members that level up, get new weapons/armor, etc. 

It also has hints of stuff like Advance Wars and Fire Emblem except your units can't move around the battlefield unless you recall them and send the unit back out in a different position. Lots of replay value with optional side quests, a challenge mode, and the ability to start new games that carry over prior progress with your party. 

The difficulty settings are highly adjustable so it can be as easy or difficult a game as you want, although the mechanics are fairly basic (it's a tower defense game, they all have the same relative strategy). 

I don't really think it's worth the full price of $15 and the art style isn't quite to my taste, but it's decent. I got it for $4.95 and it's definitely worth that, at least.

6945731.review:
I like Tower Defense games, and I found this to be an enjoyable entry in the genre. There's a lot of management options throughout each battle: the ability to cast spells, to recall and replace units for better effect, and upgrade units on the fly. There are time acceleration/deceleration options to reduce the grind if you've got an efficient unit setup and just want to get the battle done, or for if things get intense and you need to suddenly micromange your setup. 

You can also modify the experience bonuses/penalties for the game so that, if you don't have a lot of time to play, you can compress the game progression to reduce the grind even further. Frankly, it's an elegant and user-friendly setup for even the most casual of gamer.

The RPG element to this one is a nice twist, and there is a decent amount of replayability via the New Game+ mode. 

But if there is anything which truly makes this game shine, it's the writing. 
This game has made me laugh until my lungs protested, and has resulted in my replaying the game multiple times just for the dialogue.  

I highly recommend it even at full price. And if you see it on special, grab it immediately.

1668442.review: This game does so much right. From the free demo to the New Game +, everything is in order. Tight narrative, customizable difficulty, versatile classes, challenges, rewards... I had a ton of fun and intend to replay. Keep an eye out for mods in the Workshop, as well.

739536.review:
Now that we have real reviews I wanted to give this game a better response.
As a long time tower defense player, I have to say this game is in the top 3 of all time. I'll try to explain why I love it so much, and why I'm so excited for the sequel that was recently announced.

Mechanics

This game provides somewhat traditional mechanics if you're familiar with TD games. Players can build units on the perimeter of the path only, so there is no blocking/routing mechanics to worry about. Unit's have different attack types that are better and worse for some situations
What is unique about this game is that units level up in a persistent manner between levels, allowing your units to grow over time, This included an entire skill tree for each class of units that can be customized to your play style. Additionally, units have a weapon and armor equipment slot and the game does a good job of making this meaningful by introducing rare equipment a bit later in the game.
Levels are replayable so you can grind your team a bit if you feel a little weak or would like to beef up a bit before a boss level. To compliment this aspect of the game, each level can be played on different difficulty levels, which provide bigger rewards at the cost of a higher difficulty. This aspect of the game kept me going back and trying to beat my records and old levels in order to get some of the better rare gear.
Lastly, the game features a fast forward mode which is a welcome sight for those who play a lot of tower defense games. It really helps grinding out those later levels.

Story

It's rare for a TD game to have an in-depth story, but Defender's Quest does a great job with this. It's not ground breaking, but it certainly sets a nice tone and even introduces a bit of moral dilemma that plays into the unit mechanics later in the game. I won't spoil it, but I will say that the level of narrative impressed me, and kept me engaged until the end.

Graphics/Sounds

All standard stuff here. You can look at the screenshots and get an idea of what you're into. In general I'd say that the graphics do a good job of matching the needs of the gameplay, and the animations are smooth and crisp even during hectic late game levels. The graphics change into a pleasant style during story segments and do a good job of relaying the emotion and facial expressions of the characters.

Summary

All in all, this game really scratched a Tower Defense/RPG itch that I'd been craving for a long time. If you can pick the game up on sale and like TD games I'd recommend buying it without hesitation.

297867.review: You know, just when I compared the genre of tower defense to a 90's boy band and most aspects of Final Fantasy as tedious wank, there comes a game that I probably would be beaming hate rays at. This is that game, and I can't beam hate rays onto it because it takes all the irritating bits out of Final Fantasy such as grind and artificially lengthened gameplay out, and combines it with what makes tower defense fucking awesome: Intensity, efficiency, control. It would be up there with the classic Immortal Defense (and if you haven't played Immortal Defense, rectify that), but the story, despite being written by a 'real English major', flat out stands there and doesn't do anything. It doesn't piss me off either, though, so I guess it can stay. The game's still pretty fucking good!

3018405.review:
I absolutely love Defender's Quest Valley of the Forgotten. When I read tower defence rpg I was a little lost. I have never heard of the two being combined and wondered how it could be done. 

The rpg side of this game is based around the story of Azra; Azra is a royal librarian who found herself in the forgotten zone - a plague ridden part of the kingdom and things went crazy. Along the way Azra met people to aid her in her journy to find out what is going on. People like Slak and khetti (names can be changed I kept them default though). the players met along your journy become your towers and placed in a standard tower defence way, slak for example is a berserker who slashes and slaughters light hp targets, and khetti is an archer. The characters are leveld up over time so the player can equip them with gear and put points into skills such as slaks flurry to hit 5 targets at once. 

Now back to Azra; since the game revolves around her what role does this librarian play. Well in combat you are summoned to the spirit world to kill the plague ridden posessed citizens. Azra levels up with your characters so she can cast damage spells, buffs, and heals to your people during combat. The heal is very advantagous because your people will die. . . HOWEVER they can be resummoned. To prevent deaths one of the options is to equip them with armor which can be purchased and unlocked at certain points in the game along with other mercenaries.

overall I rate this game 5/5  due to the 5 dollar sale price during steam weekly sale and the unique story and combat. The game also supports the steam workshop so that you can continue the game with player made levels which I have not tried yet.

For the cons of this game I have not found any but some players might be turned off by the non applicable voice acting, all of the narrating is texted out.

A fun and lovely written story allows it to shine among other tower defense games out there, and I for one does not have anything to complain about the graphics. Honestly my first thought when I saw this game was the same as with all the other Indie TDs that have come out: a game that can be fun for a short while but nothing more.. I'm glad to have been proven wrong.

The RPG mechanics like the continuous progression / levelling of your party / "towers" and managing equipment makes for a really interesting and enjoyable game with quite some depth to it. Everything else such as the little bits of humor and customization  is just music to my ears. ..and on that note, the soundtrack is captivating <3 It's a game you really need to play yourself to understand it's greatness.

Definitely a recommendation for both fans and newcomers to the Genre..!

5606838.review:
Defender's Quest Vallie of the Forgotten is my (new) favourite of this genre.


Through an intricate story and and choice in game mechanics, it manages to combine Tower Defense with a human element, something I didn't even know I missed in the genre, and a distinct RPG feel.


Besides the rich story (which is, you know, rare for these kind of games) this game has a very nice and original art style, clear game mechanics and overview, extensive and incredibly intuitive controls, and an awarding difficulty.
It's weak points are probably the low resolution, which unfortunately doesn't upscale very well (as of writing),  but I've found this to be a minor point at best.

With the original content, and a New Game+ mode, this game is definitely worth buying, especially for this price.

2104437.review:
Rating: Highly Recommended!

One of the best tower defense games I've ever played and a truly compelling role playing game as well.  The execution is almost entirely phenomenal bar some minor hiccups: overworld navigation can be a bit slow paced due to camera/view, potentially a bit too much humor at times,  and a couple sporadic difficulty spikes.  I also believe some of the new game+ features/areas shouldn't have been removed from the first playthrough, but the initial playthrough is still very engaging regardless.  

The accessibility and extensive options of this game really shine and open the game to all sorts of players and styles.  There are a couple features that would make this game a bit better; Steam Workshop modification integration and maybe an expanded built in level editor.  Overall, a well-executed, deftly-plotted, and damn enjoyable experience that deserves your attention and support. Don't pass this one over without giving it a fair shot.

P.S. Still not convinced?  Try the demo and embark upon your own quest.

Contra

2250401.review: This is the Best tower defense game I ever played.  Is it the best ever? Probably not.  It is a tower defense with set paths on every map, no path customizing (altering) at all which i would say is a strategic element required for it to be the best ever.  But it does have an actual story which makes sense of enemies getting to the goal point, never seen that in a TD game. Story is ok, some good humor, skill trees for units who gain persistent levels, over 10 hours of gameplay on initial game mode (far more if you want to unlock everything), and after beating it it unlocks a different and harder game mode.  All these things combined give this game far more depth and play time then any TD game I've played and I've played quite a few. It could be made better and I am hoping for a sequel. This game is worth 10 bucks if its up your alley, 7 or so if you arent sure. It's already been cheaper though.

1160646.review:
This is an AMAZING game. It is an RPG Tower Defence. Instead of towers, you have a party of people, which are put in to 6 different classes. You only get a max of 6 of each class, so placing them on the lvls more important than other tower defence games.As a bonus, everyone in your party gets XP even if they were not put out, which makes getting those lvl 1 guys you just got up to a lvl that they can be helpful much easier.

 Each party member has their own lvl as well, and each class has 5 different skills they can use in total. However, when on a lvl, you must 'boost' them to get access to the high lvl skills. This, in turn, makes the game very strategic. Do you put a few of your people out, and boost them to Max at the start, or do you put more people out, and only boost them to lvl 2 or 3. 

If you like Tower Defence games, and are looking for a challenge, then this game is right up your ally. And, as a bonuses, the story as actually pretty dam good too. XD

There is aslo a Game + mode, witch I am yet to start, so that will be interesting when I get around to starting it.

316280.review:
Defender's Quest è un titolo assolutamente imperdibile per tutti gli amanti del genere Tower Defence. Al classico gameplay è perfettamente integrata una gestione delle unità in pieno stile S-RPG: creazione e personalizzazione delle unità (divise per classi), crescita di livello tramite esperienza accumulata durante le battaglie, compra/vendita di equipaggiamento, abilità da potenziare... 
A fare da contorno al tutto una buona trama (che non guasta mai) e una pixellosissima e stilosissima grafica retrò.
Le missioni sono davvero tante, e la rigiocabilità è altissima (ogni missione presenta ben 4 livelli di difficoltà).
Il prezzo base è effettivamente un po' altino, ma vale ogni singolo centesimo.
Inoltre, se siete ancora indecisi, c'è sempre la demo gratuita da provare. Cosa volete di più?

799030.review:
A Tower Defense game with the serial numbers filed off, but filed off in such a way that it doesn't feel like a Tower Defense game. Your "Towers" are characters, and these characters are memorable and quirky, and interact with each other during cutscenes between maps. Each character has a persistent level and skill tree, giving the game as much of an RPG feel as it has a TD feel.

The main quest will take you 5 hours tops if you're good at TD stuff, but there's a New Game+, challenge modes, gear to collect, characters to level, side quests... Not bad for the price.

1898775.review: Un juegazo tower defense. El mejor que he probado, pero no cuesta 14 euros. Esperad alguna oferta.

1586372.review: If you like Tower Defense or RPGs, or, god bless your soul, both, you have no reason not to buy this game right stat now.

2972598.review: I literally bought this game for $5.09 on daily deal, and played for 7 hours straight. Great spinoff of standard tower defense games, with tons of customization of your "towers". So much fun for a tower defense fanatic, 10/10 for $5.09.

178621.review: Remember how Puzzlequest turned match-3-puzzling into a light RPG? This game does the same but for the tower defense genre. Well, except the story in Puzzlequest was cringeworthy and this one so far hasn't managed to annoy me. It's got that "one more level"-feel and the writing and art style are better than I expected. Not at all bad, it's a nicely polished little timewaster, even though when it comes to the actual tower defending it doesn't do anything revolutionary.

1577188.review:
This is a brilliant mix of Tower Defence and RPG. Great, and actually horrifying story, despite the cartoony cutscenes and pixelated gameplay, but also filled with wacky humour.
You can replay levels on harder difficulty for special unique weapons or extra exp or scrap (money) rewards, and once you finish your first playthrough, you can play a new game plus with a twist: you get extra (difficult) sidequests which sometimes are just extra rewards, but others thoroughly expand the story.
All in all, good gameplay, great music, hilarious but also serious and tragic characters and story. Definitely worth the smal price.

A very fun blend of tower defense and RPG with a boring title. The level of polish that went into this game is impressive for an indie game. The art, music, and gameplay are all very good. The story is passable but the characters and the dialogue itself is great and often funny. 

There was a lot of thought that went into the gameplay. Even though you only get 6 units they are all very specialized and have their own use. Their introduction and upgrades come at an appropriate pace. The difficulty scaling is near perfect.

If you like tower defence games then this is a solid buy.

A great addictive indie Tower Defence / RPG.  Recruit more heroes to join your party, earn XP in battle and level up your units.  Place them strategically in missions and boost their power to be more effective.

3607538.review:
Edit again: Okay, now I can change my review back to a recommended. While the rerelease had a really shaky start, the devs have been great about talking to people, filing bug reports, and a really quickly released series of patches that have put the game in a good state again. I'm glad that the game is stable again because it remains one of my favorites and most played in my entire Steam library.

Edit: Three and a half years later, I'm having to edit my review on the HD rerelease of the game. Do no buy it in its current condition. It is an incredibly buggy mess. The game constantly crashes, graphical and UI glitches abound, certain equipped items will make maps literally unwinnable. How this version of the game was allowed to see the light of day is baffling. Wait until it's been patched a few times, which the devs ARE being very quick and responsive about.

If you at all enjoy tower defense games, buy this. Now. It injects cocaine through your mouse and keyboard right into your body. It's so addictive it's ridiculous. The graphics are a bit basic and it doesn't have a huge epic storyline, but it's like one of those really good Flash games polished to a mirror sheen. A mirror you snort crack off of.

201314.review:
Defender's Quest is a great game with excellent dialogue, level design,and music, and is an excellent blend of tower defense and RPG mechanics. Your party members are your "towers" and they level up and can be equipped between battles. If you are comfortable with the game I suggest going into Accessibility and turning XP and Scrap (money) gains to 300% each so you don't have to grind, ever. On the default settings you might need to in order to make enough money to keep your whole crew (up to 36 members) outfitted to the max all game long.

There is a new game+ mode, lots of achievements, and special challenge maps. This game can keep you busy for a few days of non-stop playing once it gets hooks into you.

there's like 30 stages with 4 difficulties on each one, and a new game + mode making even more longer and lots of unlockable equipment and stages.
...oh and if it matters you can change the exp/money rate up to like 300%, or down to 25% so you can adjust the pace (i'm sure most would just put 100% though)

4518512.review: Defender's Quest breathes new life into the dusty genre of tower defense by mixing it with the story and characters of a role-playing game. I must warn you that it is incredibly addictive; it contains oodles of extra content as well as multiple rewards for choosing more difficult paths through the game. And once you're done with it all, you can begin anew to see if you can complete the famed "Hero Mode". Add in mod support and a gracious team of developers and you can see why this game has something for everyone.
